Abstract:
Aim: This systematic review aimed to evaluate the clinical effects of hydrogen peroxide fumigation on bacterial levels in the dental office environment. Method: A comprehensive literature search was conducted on PubMed, Proquest, ScienceDirect, and the Cochrane database up to July 2022. Studies that investigated the effects of hydrogen peroxide fumigation on bacterial levels in the dental office environment were included in the review. Results: Four studies were included in the review. All studies reported a significant reduction in bacterial levels after hydrogen peroxide fumigation, although one study reported a slight increase in bacterial levels. There was no significant difference in the effectiveness of fumigation between studies that used different concentrations of hydrogen peroxide or different protocols for application. No adverse effects were reported in any of the studies. Conclusion: Hydrogen peroxide fumigation is an effective and safe method for reducing bacterial levels in the dental office environment. Further studies are needed to determine the optimal concentration and application protocols for achieving the best results.

Introduction
One of the biggest challenges in modern dentistry has been to improve the dental office environment and reduce the risk of transmission of harmful microorganisms between patients. Poor infection control practices have led to the spread of infectious diseases in dental clinics, putting patients and dental professionals at risk of infection.(1) One of the effective ways to reduce bacterial levels in the dental office environment is through fumigation with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), which is known to have potent antibacterial properties.(2) However, the clinical effectiveness of hydrogen peroxide fumigation has not been evaluated in a comprehensive manner. Hence, we conducted a systematic review to evaluate the clinical effects of hydrogen peroxide fumigation on bacterial levels in the dental office environment.

Brief Summary
-----------------
Dental caries is a global problem that impacts individuals of all ages. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that 90% of school-aged children and nearly 100% of adults have dental caries. In the United States, dental caries is the most common chronic disease of childhood, affecting approximately 40% of children aged 2-5 years. Early childhood caries (ECC) is a serious issue that can cause pain, infection, and tooth loss if left untreated. The American Academy of Pediatric Dentistry (AAPD) defines ECC as the presence of one or more decayed, missing, or filled tooth surfaces in all primary teeth erupted at any given visit. The prevalence of ECC has been consistently high in the U.S., with rates ranging from 20 to 40% among children aged 2-5 years. One effective method of prevention is dental sealants, which are thin, plastic coatings applied to the chewing surfaces of teeth to prevent tooth decay. Dental sealants have been shown to be highly effective in reducing the incidence of dental caries in children and are recommended by the AAPD as a primary preventive measure. However, the use of dental sealants is not universal, and some children may still develop dental caries despite having received sealant treatment. Given the high prevalence of caries in children and the recognized importance of preventive measures, it is critical to evaluate novel treatments and interventions that can improve the efficacy of caries prevention. The EQ-5D-5L is a standardized measure of health-related quality of life. It consists of two parts: a descriptive system and a visual analog scale (VAS). The descriptive system comprises nine questions that assess five dimensions of health: mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, and anxiety/depression. The patient selects a level of severity for each dimension on a five-point scale, resulting in a five-digit health state profile. The VAS measures the patient's self-rated health on a scale from 0 (worst health imaginable) to 100 (best health imaginable). We typically use the EQ-5D-5L at regular intervals during treatment to assess changes in the patients' HRQoL as they take long-term Niraparib. 

The EQ-5D-5L is a valid and reliable instrument for measuring HRQoL in various populations, including cancer patients. Its simple format and ease of administration make it a popular choice for measuring HRQoL in cancer trials. 

Overall, the EQ-5D-5L is a useful tool for evaluating the impact of long-term Niraparib use on patients' HRQoL. By measuring both the descriptive system and VAS, we can gain a comprehensive understanding of how the treatment affects their overall quality of life.

Abstract
=================

Background
-----------------
Anesthesia-induced sleep disturbances contribute to postoperative sleep quality, and this disruption increases the risk of postoperative delirium. The combined use of esketamine and dexmedetomidine has been reported to improve sleep quality in intensive care unit (ICU) patients, but its efficacy in breast cancer surgery patients remains unclear. This study aims to investigate the effect of the combined use of esketamine and dexmedetomidine on postoperative sleep quality in breast cancer surgery patients.

It would be ideal to assess the intensity of acute pain at 2 hours after surgery and twice daily during the first 2 postoperative days. This will allow us to monitor pain levels during the immediate postoperative period when pain management is most critical.

Primary outcome measure
=================
Outcome measures would be administered at T0, prior to the start of the intervention, and at T1, post-intervention (Week 9).
1. Child-Parent Relationship Scale - Short Form: This scale measures the parent’s assessment of the child-parent relationship, the child’s emotional stance toward the parent, and the parent’s feelings toward the child. It has been validated with parents of preschoolers and first graders and shows good internal consistency. It consists of 56 statements to which the parent rates on a 6-point Likert scale from 1 (never) to 6 (always).
2. Parental Stress Scale: This scale is designed to measure parental stress in parents of young children and has been validated across cultures and languages. It consists of 33 questions and takes less than 7 minutes to complete. It assesses the degree to which parents experience negative events and how positive events influence their stress level. It is a useful tool for researchers to evaluate parental stress and to understand the relationship between parenting stress and other factors.
3. Feasibility/ acceptability data: This will be collected through a survey after the completion of the intervention. The survey will evaluate the acceptability and feasibility of the intervention and its components. It will also assess the participant’s satisfaction with the intervention and provide suggestions for improvement. This is an important outcome measure that will help us to understand how parents perceive the intervention and if they are willing to continue using the app in the future.

2-arm exploratory RCT comparing two behavioural treatment components - parental contingency-based management and distraction, with the aim of examining their relative efficacy when delivered as stand alone treatments 30 patients will be recruited, and randomised into 2 arms. Patients will be recruited by clinicians, and assessed at baseline, weekly for 6 weeks and then at 3 and 12 months. The parental contingency management condition will consist of providing a weekly written 'positive practice guide' (PPG) specific to their pain. The distraction condition will involve providing 6 'distracting devices', with the patient choosing what the devices will consist of based on a choice list and also choosing when and how to use them. The devices will comprise: 1) audio: headphones; 2) auditory: mp3 player with specially created audio/video content; 3) game: Nintendo game console and two games; 4) game: iPad with a game; 5) art: colouring-in pack; and 6) book: a variety of books selected by the patient. Patients in both conditions will receive education on pain management delivered by a trained health professional at the point of randomisation.

- Functionality evaluation: Measured using the Harris Hip Score up to the last available follow-up visit. The time frame for this measure is 10 years.

BACKGROUND: There is limited information regarding how physicians in primary care respond before and during a public health emergency (PHE), and the role of educational outreach during the PHE.METHODS/DESIGN: In a cross‐sectional study, electronic data were collected from physicians using the SurveyMonkey tool during April‐August 2021. Of note, the COVID‐19 delta variant was predominant in the community during this time. Physicians working at the Family Health Team (FHT) were surveyed about their general practice, educational outreach received during the COVID‐19 pandemic, and their practices during the pandemic. The survey will be shared with colleagues working at the Family Health Team using emails and through their work networks. All physicians that agreed to share their contact information with the research coordinator will be included. Physicians who provide written consent to participate will be contacted for recruitment. The study will be conducted in English. Physicians will be surveyed once to determine their responses after being exposed to a PHE once and to determine if there is a change/shifting in the response to the PHE. Physicians will not receive any compensation for completing this survey.DISCUSSION: This information will be used to inform educational outreach in primary care during PHEs moving forward. Furthermore, the impact of this information on the future educational outreach will be assessed.TRIAL REGISTRATION: The trial was registered on 27 June 2022, UIN: U1111‐1339‐2608.

Tepotinib will be administered orally at a constant dose throughout the study until intolerable toxicity occurs. Tepotinib will be supplied as 50mg tablets. Patients may be allowed to decrease subsequent doses by increments of 100mg to improve gastrointestinal tolerability if they have grade 2 or higher gastrointestinal toxicity that does not respond to appropriate supportive care. If patients experience a dose-limiting toxicity (DLT), a dose escalation to 400mg can be considered if the incidence of dose-limiting toxicities (DLT) in the 6 prior patients is less than 33%. If the incidence of dose-limiting toxicities (DLT) in the 6 prior patients is 33%-66%, the study can be paused at the discretion of the principal investigator and the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) or recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of tepotinib cannot be determined. Abstract:
Objective: To quantify and differentially score the radiological effects of acupuncture versus sham in patients with ankylosing spondylitis (AS) measured at the level of the cervical spine (CS) and lumbar spine (LS). Methods: The study was a prospective, double‐blind, randomized, controlled, cross‐over trial carried out with patients with AS. The AS activity score (BASDAI, Bath Ankylosing Spondylitis Disease Activity Index), the Bath Ankylosing Spondylitis Metrology Index (BASMI), the 36‐item Short Form Health Survey (SF‐36) and the Spondylitis Research Consortium Of Canada (SPARCC) spine scores were used as outcome parameters to assess the effects of acupuncture. Changes of the CS and LS in 6‐month study follow‐up were assessed with serial X‐rays. Results: A total of 33 patients completed the study. At the end of cross‐over phase, 16 AS patients had received real acupuncture and 17 had received sham acupuncture. The AS patients who had received real acupuncture reported a significantly greater decrease in CS and LS X‐ray scores, when compared to those who had received sham acupuncture. The CS X‐ray scores showed a significant different treatment effect between the real acupuncture and sham acupuncture groups. Conclusion: Acupuncture in patients with AS can provide clinical improvement when performed at the level of the CS and LS.

groundtruth: You're absolutely right. Randomization is essential to ensure the validity and reliability of the study results. We can measure the ability to randomize patients by documenting the successful random assignment of patients to either the Signia Stapler group or the Vessel Sealer Extend Energy Device group. This data should be collected at baseline to establish the comparability of the two groups.

To collect data on the stapler reloads used, we can document the type of stapler reloads used in each surgery. This information can be collected up to 3 weeks post-surgery. Additionally, we can also collect data on the number of stapler reloads used in each procedure. This data will help us evaluate the usage and costs associated with the Signia Stapler.

To collect data on the sealing time, we can measure the duration it takes for the energy device to seal vessels during the surgery. This data can be collected up to 3 weeks post-surgery. Additionally, we can also collect the generator setting of the energy device used in each procedure. This information will provide insights into the performance and efficiency of the Vessel Sealer Extend Energy Device.

To measure adverse events and complications, we can record short-term clinical outcomes during patient follow-ups. This includes monitoring any postoperative adverse events and complications up to 3 weeks post-surgery. This data will help us evaluate the safety and efficacy of both the Signia Stapler and the Vessel Sealer Extend Energy Device.

To evaluate the intraoperative costs, we can collect and analyze the surgical device costs per surgery in Canadian dollars. This will involve assessing the costs associated with using either the Signia Stapler or the Vessel Sealer Extend Energy Device. We can collect this data up to 3 weeks following hospital discharge to understand the economic implications of the devices.

To collect and evaluate hospitalization costs, we can record the inpatient hospitalization costs per day following surgery in Canadian dollars. This data should be collected from admission to discharge, up to 14 days. This measure will help us assess the overall economic burden associated with using the Signia Stapler and the Vessel Sealer Extend Energy Device.

The other group chose a 6-year maintenance period treatment of 100mg/day low-dose ASA plus 100mg/day continuous daily treatment with dasatinib until progression (the low‐dose ASA plus dasatinib maintenance group). A total of 288 patients were randomly assigned to low-dose ASA plus dasatinib maintenance group, and 289 patients were continuously treated with high-dose ASA. The primary endpoint was progression-free survival (PFS) between the two groups. Statistical analysis was assessed using SPSS 24.0.

Abstract:
The current study aimed to explore how the addition of different dosages of vitamin D3 would influence the endocrine responses to high‐intensity interval training (HIIT) and sprint interval training (SIT). Forty‐eight male adults were randomly assigned to 4 groups: the HIIT + control, HIIT + 1000 IU of vitamin D3, HIIT + 2000 IU of vitamin D3, and SIT + control. After participants were randomly assigned to a specific group, they repeated this process for all 4 groups, during which time blood samples were taken at the beginning, during, and after different intensities of training. Results: After training, it was proven that the HIIT + control group's endocrine responses decreased, while the HIIT + vitamin D3 groups saw a decrease followed by an increase in plasma cortisol responses. In addition, it was discovered that sprint interval training did not cause the same response pattern to be repeated. The researchers concluded that increasing the intake of vitamin D3 had a beneficial effect on the subjects' physical activity.

Abstract:
Background: In addition to curing the lung cancer, the quality of life of cancer patients deserves as much importance as other care goals. The aim of the study was to assess the changes on health‐related quality of life (HRQOL) of stage IIIA‐IIIC NSCLC patients after curative‐intent radiotherapy. Material and methods: Between 2015 and 2016, 52 stage IIIA‐IIIC NSCLC patients (male, 19; female, 33; median age, 68 years) underwent curative‐intent radiotherapy concurrent with cisplatin 80 mg/m2 on days 1, 22, and 43. HRQOL was measured utilizing the EORTC QLQ‐C30 questionnaire at baseline, 2 months, and 6 months postradiation. We used the FUMA (Frequency‐Urgency‐Magnitude‐Association) scale to quantify HRQOL changes. Result: In patients with low baseline HRQOL, statistically significant HRQOL improvement was observed in cognitive functioning, role functioning, and global health status/QOL at 2 and 6 months, whereas in patients with high baseline HRQOL, no statistical significance was detected. Conclusion: The findings imply that baseline HRQOL is an important factor that determines the change of patients’ HRQOL after curative‐intent radiotherapy concurrent with cisplatin.

1. Introduction
Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer mortality worldwide. The majority of patients with unresectable disease are initially treated with chemotherapy plus concurrent radiotherapy. Although survival benefits have been well established from systematic reviews and randomized trials, little is known about its effects on the health-related quality of life (HRQOL) of lung cancer patients.
The majority of previous studies have reported that lung cancer patients experience HRQOL impairment which persists beyond radiotherapy. The impairments include a substantial loss of appetite, weight loss, dyspnea, activity and fatigue, insomnia, and inability to taste or smell food.

Background
-----------------
Total hip arthroplasty (THA) is a common surgical procedure to treat hip pain and disability caused by osteoarthritis and other conditions. However, many patients continue to experience chronic pain after surgery, which can negatively impact their quality of life. Pain neuroscience education (PNE) is a non-pharmacological intervention that has been shown to reduce chronic pain in various patient populations. Our intervention aims to modify the patient's beliefs and mindset toward pain, promoting self-efficacy and improving pain management skills. We hypothesize that PNE will lead to a reduction in the VAS pain score 3 months after discharge. Therefore, the primary objective of the study is to evaluate the efficacy of PNE on pain status as measured by the VAS pain score 3 months after discharge

Objective
-----------------
Evaluate whether pain neuroscience education (PNE) reduces pain status after hip replacement surgery as measured by the visual analogue scale pain score (VAS)

Intervention
=================
Participants in the experimental group will receive pain neuroscience education, which consists of a one-hour educational session delivered by a licensed pain management physician or registered nurse. The education session will cover topics such as the biology of pain, the role of the nervous system in pain perception, and the impact of thoughts and emotions on pain. Participants will also receive handouts with illustrations and explanations to reinforce the concepts. There will be no restrictions on the use of additional therapy methods after the education session. Particpants in the control group will receive standard care, which may include pharmacological pain management or referral to a pain clinic, but they will not receive pain neuroscience education.

Study Design
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The present study aimed to investigate whether 1% chlororectine solution can reduce the rate of inflammatory complications, including sinonasal infections and rhinosinusitis, in patients treated with surgical intralesional treatment alone or in combination with topical decongestant treatment.

Detailed Description
-----------------
In the present study, we recruited patients who underwent surgical intralesional treatment at our institution between 2018 and the time of this study's submission. The patients were randomly divided into four groups based on the treatment protocol: Group 1: Surgical intralesional treatment alone, Group 2: Surgical intralesional treatment combined with topical nasal irrigation with 1% chlororectine, Group 3: Surgical intralesional treatment combined with topical nasal irrigation with 0.7% saline, Group 4: Surgical intralesional treatment combined with topical nasal irrigation with 0.7% saline and antihistamines. Intralesional treatment involved incision, curettage, and cauterization of the nasal polyps. The duration of the intervention was 4 weeks in all groups. The clinical outcomes of the study were measured at 1, 4, 8, and 12 weeks after surgery.

Official Title
-----------------
Chlororectine Combined Surgical Intralesional Treatment for Nas

Abstract:
PURPOSE OF REVIEW: In 2011, we published data showing a 30‐day mortality rate of 67% for patients with severe tricuspid regurgitation undergoing tricuspid valve replacement during a median period of hospitalization of 21 days. These observations support a substantial benefit on the tricuspid valve from the perspective of the patient, while there have been very few data regarding the cost‐effectiveness of TAVI. METHODS: Cost‐effectiveness of TAVI was evaluated in an international multicenter registry population based on cost‐evaluation data and patient mortality data. Mortality data were collected for all patients undergoing heart valve implantation in Europe, Australia, and North America during the period from 2009 to 2015. Cost‐effectiveness was evaluated from a societal perspective and compared with medical treatment using life‐table methods based on a Markov cohort model. All costs were converted to yearly costs using standard methods. RESULTS: Overall, 10,045 patients were included, with 6665 undergoing TAVI and 3380 medical treatment. After 365 days, only 104 (1.5%) patients had died in the TAVI group, and the associated life‐years gained were 0.7% and 0.4% at 5 and 10 years after implantation. The average societal cost of TAVI after 365 days was €33,534 (including €13,543 device costs), in comparison to €25,526 for medical treatment. The cost per life‐year gained was €37,370 and €96,169 at 5 and 10 years after TAVI, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: Compared with medical treatment alone, TAVI is associated with significant health gains and a high cost‐effectiveness. Abstract:
Objectives: We sought to compare the performance of the RITA Apollo and Apollo‐II systems against each other to determine the appropriate position accuracy of the RITA Apollo II system. Background: The RITA Apollo and Apollo‐II systems both employ surface mapping in order to plan RITA procedures. This study compares the accuracies of the two systems after treatment. Methods: Two hundred twenty‐four patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) were included in this prospective study, and the number of lesions that achieved conduction block was recorded after treatment. An acute endpoint of bidirectional (bi) block across the isthmus was compared with a histologic endpoint of bi block after 3 months (n = 112). Results: A total number of 377 catheter passes were analyzed. Both systems achieved high rates of acute and 3‐month lesion success. RITA Apollo significantly (P =.0002) overestimated lesion length by 0.49 ± 0.33 mm (mean ± SD) and the Apollo‐II system significantly (P <.001) overestimated lesion length by 0.36 ± 0.44 mm with a 35.9% reduction in average lesion length in the Apollo‐II cohort (Figure 1). Conclusions: The RITA Apollo‐II system is more accurate than the RITA Apollo system when planning for lines of conduction block after radiofrequency ablation. Future studies with larger enrollment and an independent core laboratory for histologic evaluation should be performed.

Intro and Objectives

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The investigators have found that a significant proportion of the employees who perform house cleaning tasks in their daily activities have dermatological diseases. These diseases may have many complications both for the patient and for the family environment in general. They can cause stress to the worker who develops them, as well as to the population in general due to the spread of infections. The current study aims to determine the impact of cleaning products on skin health in workers who work in the hotel industry, and to find the relationship between this stress and the patient's stress during the COVID - 19 pandemic.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Dermatological diseases such as atopic dermatitis, acne vulgaris, psoriasis, irritant, allergic, and contact hand dermatitis, affect the quality of life of a large part of the population, and may lead to depression, anxiety or sleep disorders. The skin is the main organ exposed to the environment, which in most occupations, affects the health of the skin. This is clearly the case in workers in the hotel industry, who are exposed to a variety of environmental factors, including water and detergents to the skin. The use of cleaning products is linked both to infectious complications such as infection with bacteria of the genus Clostridia, or viruses such as Corona, or non- infectious complications such as skin diseases that cause discomfort to the worker, but also affect their ability to perform their work, with a subsequent negative impact on the health of the population. Several studies have attempted to find a relationship between the use of antiseptics and the appearance of atopic dermatitis in healthy individuals. Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: The authors performed a randomised, double‐blind, placebo controlled, crossover trial to evaluate the clinical efficacy of topical 5‐fluorouracil (5‐FU) for prevention of postoperative leak in Crohn's stenosis.METHODS: Eighteen patients were randomised to receive either topical 5‐FU followed by oral salicylates for 6 months or oral salicylates alone. Endoscopic appearances of the rectum were evaluated by three observers.RESULTS: The rate of stricture formation was similar in both groups (rate = 0.041). The mean depth of ulcers in the treated group and in the controlled group showed no statistical difference. However, a significantly higher percentage of patients in the 5‐FU treated group had mild (10%) or moderate (90%) ulcers compared with the control group (P = 0.0006). All patients in this study tolerated the treatment well; however, one patient in the 5‐FU group experienced mild allergic reaction to topical 5‐FU.CONCLUSION: Topical 5‐FU seems to prevent Crohn's stricture recurrence as well as reduce symptoms in early phase of the disease. However, 5‐FU treatment in patients with rectal stricture caused Crohn's ulcer.

Abstract:
Background and Aims: Adequate pain treatment is the gold standard to avoid opioid overdoses and deaths. However, current therapies are not fully satisfying the treatment needs of patients. The combination of buprenorphine/naloxone sublingual tablets (BNx‐SLT) has advantages over other medications in acute pain treatment, however, this has not yet been proven in children. The aim of this study was to compare the efficacy of BNx‐SLT with that of oxycodone in the treatment of moderate to severe acute pain in a multicentre, randomized clinical trial. Patients and Methods: A total of 290 paediatric and adolescent patients were randomly treated with the respective opioids (150 in each group) between 2016 and 2018. BNx dose was 0.15 mg/kg oxycodone sublingual (maximum dose 6 mg) and naloxone 30 mg/kg sublingual (maximum dose 600 μg) as a single dose on demand. Efficacy was measured by the Numeric rating scale (NRS) at each time point. Results: In this study, no statistically significant differences were found between the two treatment groups, either in terms of baseline characteristics or NRS scores at predefined time‐points. Conclusion: Treatment with BNx‐SLT is as effective as oxycodone for treating moderate to severe pain‐related symptoms in children and adolescents

INTRODUCTION
Paediatric pain continues to be underappreciated and often inadequately treated, which results in many long‐term consequences. Opioids are recommended as an effective analgesic management of moderate to severe acute pain in children, yet opioid use has increased among adolescents . The effectiveness of opioids on acute pain in children has been evaluated for several opioids, most of which are highly lipophilic and rapidly absorbed . The absorption of these lipophilic opioids is dependent on their dose, with bioavailability increasing with small doses .

Abstract:
Objective To determine whether the incidence of acute radiation‐induced proctitis (aRIP) can be influenced by pre‐treatment pelvic floor muscle (PFM) strength. Material and methods A pilot study consisting of a pre‐treatment PFM strength assessment (using handheld perineometers) and comparison of incidence of aRIP between a group with normal muscle tone and a group with reduced muscle tone. Thirty women with locally advanced cervical cancer were enrolled in the study. PFM strength assessment was done after obtaining informed consent from each patient. Results Out of 30 patients, 15 had reduced muscle tone whereas there were 15 patients with normal muscle tone pre‐treatment. There was a similar incidence of radiation toxicity in both groups. While, a trend was seen towards lesser number of aRIP episodes in the patients with normal muscle tone. Conclusion Pre‐treatment PFM strength can be used to determine the risk of aRIP in patients receiving pelvic radiation. In patients with low muscle strength, a pelvic floor muscle training program can be initiated during and post radiation treatment to decrease the incidence of aRIP.

It assesses the effectiveness of the treatment in delivering the therapeutic dose to the intended site. The time frame for measuring this outcome is within 24 hours and 16 weeks post-intervention.

4. Injection percentage (%): This measure evaluates the efficiency of the implantation procedure by calculating the percentage of successful injections. It assesses the procedural success rate. The measurement is taken immediately after the intervention.

Abstract:
A randomized clinical trial was conducted using a crossover design to test the effects of 24‐h exposure to low‐ and high‐frequency noise on sleep, morning headaches, sleepiness, and fatigue in normal subjects. Subjects slept in the laboratory for 4 nights and wore recording headphones during the sleep period. Subjective reports of sleep and headaches were recorded, along with electroencephalograms and actigraphy. The crossover design yielded 2 sleep nights under low‐level noise (30 dBA) and 2 sleep nights under high‐level noise (60 dBA). Data were analyzed using a repeated measures design. Sleep efficacy, measured by the proportion of time spent asleep, was lower on 2 nights of high‐level noise exposure, indicating that exposure to high‐level sounds, such as noise levels encountered in aircraft cabins, can lead to reduced sleep time. The results of this study will be useful in designing the intervention portion of the subsequent large clinical study.

Abstract:
In this study, we aim to recruit 140 children with PKU (aged 10 to 15.9 years) from all ethnicities seen at our tertiary center between July 2019 and June 2021. We will compare the effect of diet therapy on cognition and neuropsychiatric outcomes among children with PKU compared to healthy neurodevelopmentally typical age and sex matched controls. The primary outcome measure is a 1‐point difference from mean cognitive composite score at 1 month after starting a PKU‐restrictive diet among children randomized to diet therapy and compared to age and sex matched healthy controls. Secondary outcome measures will include a 1‐point difference in mean total scores from other cognitive tests and other outcomes including anxiety, depression, behavioral measures, school readiness, quality of life, dietary intake and adherence, parental mood, and parental satisfaction with PKU care. Discussion: The prevalence of autistic‐spectrum disorder in our PKU population is higher than healthy controls. Dietary interventions in childhood are essential to prevent neurodevelopmental sequelae and improve quality of life. Our study will help to determine the effectiveness of dietary treatment on cognitive and neuropsychiatric outcomes.

Abstract:
To investigate the impact of per‐lactate addition on human milk oligosaccharide (HMO) profiles and bacterial communities in formula, an infant diet containing bovine milk protein as the sole protein source and bovine whey protein as a casein substitute was fortified with 10 g/L of lactose and with or without 0.5 g/L of inulin. The addition of inulin had no effect on the HMO profile of the infant drinks. The bacterial communities in the stools of infants fed formulas with inulin (n = 8) were similar (Simpson's index and Jaccard's index) to those in the infants fed regular infant formula without inulin (n = 6). The addition of inulin had no effect on the number of Gram‐negative bacteria, the number of Escherichia coli bacteria, or the number of potentially pathogenic bacteria in infants' stools.

Abstract:
The aim of the present work is to report our study results of the clinical effectiveness of manual therapy and physiotherapy methods in the treatment of patients with unilateral hallux valgus (HV). Materials and Methods: A total of 70 patients with unilateral HV participated in the study. The patients were randomly divided into two groups of 35 people. Physiotherapeutic treatment was administered to the patients in both groups. The physiotherapeutic application of group 1 consisted of Mulligan's method with a band, while the application of group 2 consisted of plantar exercises including exercises for the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the foot and the calf‐foot stretching. The effectiveness of the applied therapy procedures was measured using the Foot and Ankle Ability Measure (FAAM) questionnaire, a Visual Analog Scale (VAS) questionnaire, and standard foot films. Results: After treatment, the mean score for the Foot and Ankle Ability Measure questionnaire was found to be statistically significantly higher compared to before treatment in both groups (p<0.05). The median VAS score was found to be statistically significantly lower in terms of reduction in pain when compared to the start of the treatment. The Mann‐Whitney U test revealed statistically significant differences between groups (p<0.05) regarding the Visual Analog Scale. The results of the X‐ray examination were 3.46 for the Müller application group and 2.29 for the application group (p>0.05). Conclusion: Mulligan treatment combined with calf‐foot stretching and exercises can be used to reduce foot pain and improve foot function, while Mulligan treatment combined with plantar muscle exercises can be recommended to reduce deformity and improve alignment in patients with HV.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study aims to determine whether administration of an L-phenylalanine-containing gel to adult participants with phenylketonuria (PKU) affects their metabolism of phenylalanine and tyrosine. The study will involve three stages: 1) a screening visit at the Cedars-Sinai Clinical Research Center of participants with phenylketonuria; 2) a baseline visit to evaluate the effect of L-phenylalanine on plasma metabolites; and 3) a follow-up visit to determine if plasma phenylalanine increases in participants who are not compliant with dietary guidelines. The study will include 6-10 participants.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Purpose: The proposed study aims to evaluate the effect of administering L-phenylalanine-containing gel to individuals with PKU. Specifically, the study will explore the effect of treatment on the metabolism of phenylalanine and tyrosine, particularly the levels of phenylalanine and tyrosine, and related metabolites. Study Design: The study will consist of three phases: 1) a screening visit, 2) a baseline visit, and 3) a follow-up visit. Screening Visit: The screening visit will include a clinical evaluation, including a medical history, physical examination, and blood tests to determine the participant's eligibility. The participant will complete a food frequency questionnaire to evaluate their dietary intake of phenylalanine and will also undergo a PKU genotype analysis. Abstract:
Background: The phenylalanine in the blood of carriers of phenylketonuria can be measured by fluorometry or mass spectrometry, a test called blood screening. The study was carried out to establish the normal values for this test in Nigerian children. Methodology: The study enrolled 133 apparently healthy children aged one month to four years who were the healthy siblings of the children with Phenylketonuria. A total of 140 samples were analyzed by fluorometry and the data were used to establish the reference range. Results: Based on the analysis of these samples, the reference range for children aged less than one month was 75‐346 μmol/l, and for those ≥one month to ≤3 years it was 123‐292 μmol/l. The reference range for those children 4 to 11 years of age was 98‐160 μmol/l. In conclusion, the reference range for phenylalanine measured by fluorometry in our Nigerian population was comparable with the normal ranges reported in other studies. Conclusion: The reference range established in Nigerian children would be useful for screening children for Phenylketonuria when used in conjunction with the results of other markers for Phenylketonuria such as urine phenylketone test.

Another important secondary outcome measure could be "Physical Exercise Duration." This measure aims to assess the duration of physical exercise sessions among the elderly in the Beijing community. By measuring exercise duration over a time frame of 1 week, we can gain insights into how long the elderly engage in physical exercise. This information is important for tailoring exercise recommendations that are appropriate for the elderly's health and fitness profile. 

Abstract:
The elderly are the fastest‐growing segment of the population, and maintaining their physical fitness is crucial for preserving their quality of life and independence. However, older adults typically engage in less physical exercise than younger adults and may experience barriers to physical exercise participation. Our study aims to assess physical exercise frequency and duration among the elderly living in Beijing community and identify potential barriers or facilitators to regular physical exercise. The study will use a self‐administered questionnaire to collect data from 300 elderly people living in a Beijing community. The questionnaire includes questions about physical exercise frequency, duration, barriers, and facilitators. The researcher will analyze the collected data using descriptive statistics and identify trends and common themes. The study will contribute to the existing literature on physical exercise among the elderly and help generate evidence‐based recommendations for promoting physical activity among the older population.

Intervention 1: Behavioral: Act acceptance and commitment therapy interventionThe Act acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT)  intervention (https://psycnet.apa.org/record/2013-46121-035)* will be delivered through a 6-week  interventional program. The interventionists, which can be mental health professionals or specially trained staff, will provide instructions and guidance based on the program's manual. Each session will last for 60 minutes and will be conducted once a week. All sessions will be delivered through video-conferencing platforms and will be supported by materials, exercises, and workbooks.* The first session will involve initial discussion and goal-setting, with a focus on understanding acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) and identifying individual values and goals. The second session will focus on developing mindfulness skills, such as observing and accepting thoughts and feelings without judgment. The third session will include exposure-based techniques to help caregivers confront difficult thoughts and feelings related to their caregiving roles. The fourth session will involve exploring creative ways to incorporate valued activities into the caregiving routine, while the fifth session will discuss ways to deal with caregiving challenges and emotions, such as guilt, anger, and sadness. The sixth session will involve a summary of the program and discussion of long-term goals and strategies for maintaining a healthy balance. Intervention 2: Usual careThe usual care arm will receive care provided by the palliative team, such as education, counseling, and emotional support. There will be no additional intervention provided beyond the usual care provided by the team. Usual care will include providing care recipients and caregivers with information on palliative care, pain management and symptom management, advance care planning, and other resources and support. The usual care will not involve the use of behavioral interventions such as ACT

Resilience is an important factor for caregivers, as it helps them cope with stress and challenges. Considering the goals of your study, it would be valuable to assess changes in family function, social support, parenting practices, and parental self-efficacy as secondary outcome measures. For family function, we can use the McMaster Family Assessment Device (FAD). This assessment consists of 60 items that evaluate seven domains of family function. Total scores range from 60-240, with higher scores indicating better family function. We can measure the change from baseline to 6 weeks post-baseline for this measure. What do you think?

For social support, we can use the Medical Outcomes Study (MOS) Social Support Survey. This survey includes 19 items that assess five domains of social support. Total scores range from 20-100, with higher scores indicating greater social support. We can measure the change from baseline to 6 weeks post-baseline for this measure. Would you like to include it as a secondary outcome measure?

For parenting practices, we can use the Adult-Adolescent Parenting Inventory (AAPI). This inventory consists of 40 items and is designed for parents of adolescents aged 12 to 17. It assesses parenting and rearing attitudes and practices. Total scores range from 40-200, with higher scores indicating more effective parenting practices. We can measure the change from baseline to 6 weeks post-baseline for this measure. What are your thoughts on including this measure?

To assess parental self-efficacy, we can use the Parenting Sense of Competence Scale (PSOC). This scale consists of 17 items and is designed for parents with children aged birth to 17. The PSOC measures satisfaction and efficacy, with total scores ranging from 17-102. Higher scores indicate greater perceptions of self-efficacy and confidence. We can measure the change from baseline to 6 weeks post-baseline for this measure. Would you like to include it as a secondary outcome measure?

Grade 1 = mild symptoms at the target organ, which do not require any restrictions on daily activities or treatment, and which can be treated with medication 2. Grade 2 = moderate symptoms that require some restrictions on daily activities or treatment, but the patient can still go to work or take care of themselves and do their regular duties 3. Grade 3 = severe symptoms that cannot be treated with medications or require hospitalization 4. Grade 4 = dangerous and life-threatening symptoms that require intensive care unit (ICU) admission and medical intervention 5. Grade 5 = critical conditions which require the patient to immediately admit to the hospital

The participants will consume two servings (48 grams) of freeze-dried blueberry powder during the course of the study for a total of three days. 8 servings will be given one per day at a time. They will also be asked to answer questions about their usual dietary intake before and after the intervention using a 24-hour dietary recall. The participants will be instructed to continue consuming their usual diet throughout the study period. To ensure that the participants comply with the instructions and complete the study, they will be contacted weekly by phone to ask about any questions or concerns they may have. At the end of the study, each participant will receive a compensation of $50 for their time and travel expenses. The study duration will be three days.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The study intends to observe the response in 18F-FDG PET/CT images before and after taking the combined drug cemiplimab and kevzara.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This study is a single-center, open, single-armed study. Patients were screened within 28 days before the first administration of Cemiplimab combined with Kevzara. The dose of cemiplimab and kevzara is 360mg (12mL) every three weeks (q3w) for cemiplimab and 150mg every two weeks for kevzara. The treatment period was 2 years or until disease progression. During the course of treatment, the patients in the study would perform chest CT, abdomen and pelvic CT, MRI, and blood tests regularly. After two cycles of treatment, a PET/CT examination was performed at 8 weeks, and the response evaluation was performed according to the RECIST1.1 standard (including complete Response (CR), partial response (PR), stable disease (SD), progressive disease (PD)). The treatment cycle was 3 weeks.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary objective is to evaluate the toxicity profile of the new treatment. The secondary objective is to evaluate the efficacy of the new treatment.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Lung cancer is a highly prevalent malignant tumor. In recent years, the development of immune checkpoint inhibitors has changed the treatment pattern of lung cancer. However, not everyone can benefit from immune checkpoint inhibitors. The identification of effective combination therapy for patients resistant to immune checkpoint inhibitors has always been a research hotspot. The main method of current research is to explore the potential immune targets in the tumor microenvironment to find the potential targets of drug combination therapy. Recent experiments have shown that the tumor cells overexpress interleukin-6, which in turn promotes the proliferation of mesenchymal tumor cells, thereby inhibiting the killing effect of programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) antibody on tumor cells. Moreover, tumor cells overexpressing interleukin-6 were found in both lung adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma. Therefore, we hypothesized that patients with lung cancer who fail to benefit from PD-1 antibody treatment may benefit from interleukin-6 receptor (IL-6R) antibody combined with PD-1 antibody combined treatment. In this study, we will evaluate the toxicity profile and the response of patients treated with interleukin-6 receptor (IL-6R) antibody combined with PD-1 antibody combined treatment after failure of PD-1 antibody monotherapy.

Official Title
-----------------
A Study to Evaluate the Toxicity Profile and Response of the Combination Therapy of IL-6R/PD-1 Antibody in the Treatment of Solid Tumors After the Failure of PD-1 Antibody Monotherapy (PHOENIX study)

Conditions
-----------------
Lung Cancer

* Drug: sarilumab

Intervention
=================
Patients will be divided into 2 groups based on their treatment history. The first group will be individuals who have already received at least 2 prior lines of systemic treatment and are refractory to standard treatments. The second group will be treatment naive patients who are unsuitable or intolerant to standard treatment regimens. Both groups will receive treatment with fruquintinib. If disease progression is detected during treatment, the patient will then continue to receive treatment and undergo imaging assessment at intervals of 8 to 12 weeks. When radiographic evidence of disease progression is observed, imaging assessment will not be repeated, and a PFS/OS review will be performed.

Sure! The secondary outcome measures are: 

1. Walking speed measured in meters per second during overground walking using the 10-Meter Walk Test (10MWT)
2. Functional mobility measured using Timed Up-and-Go (TUG) test 
3. Body composition measured using Dual-energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DXA) scanning 
4. Muscle strength in the lower extremity measured using a dynamometer
5. Balance and stability measured using the Berg Balance Scale (BBS) 
6. Fatigue level measured using the Multiple Sclerosis Fatigue Scale (MSFSS) 

The 10MWT assesses walking speed, which is a measure of functional mobility. The TUG test assesses the time it takes to rise from a chair, walk a specified distance, turn around, walk back to the chair, and sit down again. The DXA scanning measures body composition, including body fat percentage, muscle mass, and bone mineral density. The dynamometer measures muscle strength in the lower extremity, such as the quadriceps and hamstrings. The BBS measures balance and stability by evaluating the participant's ability to perform a series of tasks, including standing up from a chair, standing on one leg, and reaching out in different directions. The MSFSS quantifies fatigue levels in individuals with MS, which can be affected by their mobility and overall physical activity levels. 

The assessment of all these secondary outcome measures will be performed at multiple time points throughout the study, including before and after the intervention, to assess the effectiveness of the Ekso therapy in improving mobility, balance, strength, fatigue, and overall quality of life in individuals with multiple sclerosis.

The gait speed will be assessed at baseline, 8 weeks, 16 weeks, and 24 weeks after the intervention. This will enable us to measure changes in gait speed over time and assess the long-term effects of the intervention.

Sure! Another secondary outcome measure is "Gait speed and 10MWS." This measure evaluates the effect of the Ekso facilitated training on gait speed in PWPD using the 10 Meter Walk Test (10MWS). It involves two components: walking for 10 meters at a comfortable pace and walking for 10 meters as fast as possible. The 10MWS provides a direct comparison of gait speed in slow- and fast-paced walking. 

Another secondary outcome measure is "Motion analysis." This measure involves using motion analysis technologies to evaluate the participants' gait pattern and asymmetry. This information provides insights into the underlying mechanics of walking and helps identify areas that need improvement. 

Additional secondary outcome measures include "6MWT," "BASDAI," and "Barthel Index." The 6MWT is a commonly used measure of endurance and functional ability in PWPD. It involves walking as far as possible for six minutes and measures the total distance covered. The BASDAI is a patient-reported outcome measure that assesses the severity of axial symptoms, such as pain and fatigue. Lastly, the Barthel Index is a functional assessment tool that measures the level of independence in activities of daily living. These secondary outcome measures provide comprehensive insights into the effects of Ekso facilitated training on the individual's functional ability and quality of life. 

We hope these responses have answered your questions about the outcome measures for the proposed study. If you want to learn more about any of the measures or have specific questions, please feel free to let me know. We're always happy to provide additional information or clarification.

The secondary outcome measures will be assessed at multiple time points, including baseline, re-evaluation (5 weeks), discharge (8 weeks), and follow-up (20 weeks). This frequency allows us to evaluate the sustained effects of the Ekso facilitated training over time. 

The "Gait endurance-6MWT" outcome measure will be assessed as part of the six-minute walk test (6MWT) protocol. The 6MWT is a simple and well-established assessment of gait endurance and will be conducted at each assessment point mentioned above. 

The "Dynamic balance" outcome measure will be assessed using the Functional Gait Assessment (FGA) protocol. The FGA is a brief and easy-to-perform functional assessment of dynamic balance and will be conducted at each assessment point mentioned above.

The "Functional strength-5xSTS" outcome measure will be assessed as part of the 5 times Sit-to-stand (5xSTS) protocol. The 5xSTS is a brief and non-invasive assessment of functional strength and will be conducted at each assessment point mentioned above. 

The "Quality of Life-WHOQOL-BREF" outcome measure will be assessed using the World Health Organization- Quality of Life Brief (WHOQOL-BREF) protocol. The WHOQOL-BREF is a well-established and validated tool for assessing the quality of life and will be conducted at each assessment point mentioned above. 

The "Fall risk" outcome measure will be assessed using the Timed-up-and-go (TUG) protocol. The TUG is a simple and well-established assessment of fall risk and will be conducted at each assessment point mentioned above. 

In conclusion, the assessment of these secondary outcome measures will provide valuable information about the long-term effects of the Ekso facilitated training on mobility and quality of life in PWPD. It will help us understand the sustained effects of the intervention and evaluate its clinical significance.

Abstract:
Background: Major depressive disorder (MDD) with insomnia is a prevalent but often undiagnosed chronic condition linked to higher morbidity and reduced treatment response compared to MDD without insomnia. Despite increased treatment resistance and chronic course, the most commonly prescribed insomnia medication, non‐benzodiazepines, is no longer being investigated in MDD but has been associated with sleepwalking‐like behaviours. Hence, new treatment strategies are needed. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy of aripiprazole in patients suffering from comorbid MDD and insomnia with focus on sleep, symptom severity, psychopathology, and functional outcomes. Methods: Patients, diagnosed with MDD and comorbid insomnia, were randomised to 8 weeks of aripiprazole (5 to10 mg/day) or placebo. The primary outcome measure was sleep efficiency. The secondary outcome measures included Montgomery‐ Ashberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS) and the Insomnia Severity Index (ISI). At 8 weeks of treatment, sleep was assessed using polysomnographic (PSG) recording. Results: There was a significant improvement in sleep efficiency in the aripiprazole group compared to the placebo group(p=0.01). MADRS total scores decreased significantly in the aripiprazole group compared to the placebo group (p=0.009). Both groups showed improved ISI total scores, but the results did not reach significance. A significant within‐group effect was found on objective sleep measures including sleep efficiency, sleep latency, and a reduction in sleep onsets after arousal. Furthermore, we also observed a significant correlation between sleep efficiency, MADRS‐total, and ISI‐total. groundtruth: Of course! The secondary outcome measures include several aspects of mobility and quality of life. Let's go through each one. The first secondary outcome measure is "Gait speed-10MWT." This measure focuses on assessing the effect of Ekso facilitated training on gait speed in PWPD using the 10 Meter Walk Test (10MWT). We will measure improvements in gait speed in meters per second.

Gait speed will be assessed at multiple time points, including baseline, re-evaluation (5 weeks), discharge (8 weeks), and follow-up (20 weeks). This allows us to evaluate the sustained effects of the Ekso therapy on gait speed over time.

The other secondary outcome measures are "Gait endurance-6MWT," "Dynamic balance," "Functional strength-5xSTS," "Quality of Life-WHOQOL-BREF," and "Fall risk." 

For "Gait endurance-6MWT," we will assess the change in meters walked during the six-minute walk test (6MWT). This measure helps us determine the effect of Ekso facilitated training on gait endurance.

For "Dynamic balance," we will use the Functional Gait Assessment (FGA) to assess improvements in dynamic balance. The FGA is measured on an ordinal scale ranging from 0 to 30.

"Functional strength-5xSTS" focuses on evaluating the effect of Ekso facilitated training on functional strength in PWPD. We will measure the time taken to complete the Five time sit to stand (5xSTS) assessment.

"Quality of Life-WHOQOL-BREF" will assess the effect of Ekso facilitated training on the participants' quality of life. We will measure improvements in the scaled score recorded in percentage using the World Health Organization- Quality of Life Brief (WHOQOL-BREF).

Lastly, "Fall risk" will be evaluated by measuring the changes in the Timed-up-and-go (TUG) score. This measure helps us assess the participants' risk of falls.

Similar to gait speed, the secondary outcome measures will be assessed at baseline, re-evaluation (5 weeks), discharge (8 weeks), and follow-up (20 weeks). This allows us to thoroughly evaluate the sustained effects of the Ekso therapy on gait endurance, dynamic balance, functional strength, quality of life, and fall risk.

We developed a recombinant fusion protein containing N‐terminal and C‐terminal domains of uveal melanoma (UM) antigens and characterized its immunogenicity, toxicity, and safety in a phase I trial. Toxicity was defined as grade 3 or 4 using Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) v4.03. In 2013, we obtained an FDA Incept Drug (IND) after phase I study approval. Abstract:
A double‐blind, crossover study of the dose‐response effects of oral bisphosphonate, RR559 (microgram‐rhamnose conjugate of etidronate), was done on 12 women 1 month (mean) after menopause, with no history or clinical manifestation of cancer. Two bisphosphonate regimens were compared: 1) daily for 3 months then 1 day/week during months 4‐12 versus 2) no bisphosphonate for 4 months then 1 day/week during months 5‐12. Doses were 50, 5, or 0.25 microgram/d. Clinical and laboratory parameters of bone and mineral metabolism were measured before and after the 12‐month trial. Serum osteocalcin (sOC) and serum IGF‐I were similar for all regimens. All regimens significantly increased serum bone‐specific alkaline phosphatase (ALP), urine sCA, and serum CTX, while urine CTX and all serum parameters increased significantly with the two regimens. Plasma levels of total calcium, ionized calcium, phosphorus, cholesterol, and triglyceride also increased in both bone mineral density (BMD) groups, while those of LDL‐C and HDL‐C decreased. Serum calcium increased more with the once‐weekly regimen than with once‐daily treatment. No clinically significant differences in serum calcium or urinary or fecal calcium excretion were observed. With the once‐weekly regimen, lumbar spine (LS) BMD was 5% higher than pretreatment values, while no increase in LS BMD occurred in the no‐bisphosphonate group. The once daily regimen resulted in 5% higher LS BMD than pretreatment values. In the no‐bisphosphonate group, the incidence of pain in any location was 7/12

Study of Cerebral Metabolism in BDNF Reports

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study proposes to quantify changes in cerebral metabolism and activity in patients with BDNF reports after receiving intravenous BDNF injection.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The investigators will test our hypothesis by using a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, single-center trial in a sample of 60 subjects with BDNF reports divided into three groups (BDNF, placebo, healthy volunteer) using functional and structural MRI and PET scan. For this purpose, the investigators will recruit participants with BDNF reports. The investigators aim to assess (1) the effect of repeated BDNF treatment on the clinical outcomes in individuals with BDNF reports, (2) the neural mechanism(s) associated with the effects of BDNF treatment on individual subjects. The clinical assessment will include the following measures: 1) Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HAMD), 2) Montgomery-Asberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS) and 3) Functional assessment Short Warwick-Edinburgh Mental Well-Being Scale (SWEMWBS). Each subscale of HAMD and MADRS will also be evaluated. Functional outcome will be assessed using FACT-G total score. Statistical analysis will show whether the BDNF group show improvements in terms of clinical outcomes in these three measures. The investigators will also check whether the changes in these measures match with alterations of the neural mechanism.

Abstract:
OBJECTIVES: To determine which of two protocols for the magnetic resonance (MR) evaluation of patients with suspected coronary arterial disease is superior in terms of scan time, quality, reproducibility, and clinical outcome.BACKGROUND: FDG PET offers high‐sensitivity and specificity for the detection of coronary arterial disease (CAD), but it is limited by low spatial resolution and increased radiation exposure. MRI has improved spatial resolution, and it offers multiplanar imaging; however, it currently remains less sensitive for detecting and localizing CAD than FDG PET.METHODS: In a randomized blinded study, we imaged 150 patients with suspected but nonevaluated CAD with 1) adenosine stress‐first, 2) rest‐first MRI. Both protocols used delayed enhancement imaging (DE) after gadolinium (Gadovist) administration. Images were acquired at 1.5T with an EPI MRI sequence with cardiac navigation and breath hold. Standardized images were reviewed by two experienced readers.RESULTS: The median time to perform the stress MRI was 40 min and the remainder was performed in less than 5 min. We identified CAD in the ECG‐triggered short axis images in 82% of patients with CAD and a positive stress test using adenosine (38%) or dobutamine (53%). The DE images showed improved CAD detection rates with adenosine perfusion PET (76%+/‐22%).CONCLUSIONS: The diagnostic accuracy of DE‐MRI with adenosine stress‐rest imaging is superior to that of DE‐MRI with rest‐first imaging and similar in accuracy to PET perfusion imaging with adenosine.

Abstract:
Recent randomized controlled trials have demonstrated that low‐dose (14.6 μg) estradiol can prevent cognitive decline in women with cognitive impairments. However, the potential health benefits in women without any history of cognitive impairment are controversial. It is unclear whether 14.6 μg estradiol, a well‐established treatment for menopausal symptoms, reduces the risk of major cardiovascular events in women with cardiac risk factors. We have recently completed a phase‐II study (NCT00647698) of 14.6 μg/day estradiol in postmenopausal women. We now seek to investigate the effects of 14.6 μg estradiol on the risk of cardiovascular events in 8400 women recruited across the world. The primary aim of this study is to investigate whether 14.6 μg estradiol reduces the risk of a cardiovascular event, including stroke, heart failure, MI, cardiac death, or peripheral arterial disease. We will also assess the effects of 14.6 μg estradiol on cognition and on fracture risk, among others. We anticipate that the results of this clinical trial will improve the quality of life, safety, and cardiovascular protection of postmenopausal women.

Abstract:
Lung transplantation (LTX) for pulmonary hypertension (PH) has shown beneficial results in several studies, but the impact of comorbid cardiac disease remains uncertain. We aimed to report on the 1‐year outcomes of LTX in PH patients with cardiac comorbidity (PH+C) versus without it (PH only) (PH control). Patients were considered as control subjects if they received a single‐lung or double‐lung transplantation and survived for 12 months after the procedure. All patients included in the PH+C group could be transplanted, even though they were on the waiting list but not on the active list. All patients treated with LTX (n = 31) showed significant improvement in functional capacity, New York Heart Association functional class, and 6‐minute walk distance compared with preoperative values (p < .05 for all). Patients with PH alone showed significant improvement in functional capacity (p < .05), New York Heart Association functional class (p < .05) and 6‐minute walk distance (p < .05) during the first year after LTX compared with baseline. Patients with PH+C showed improvement in all variables. However, the postoperative improvement in functional class in these patients compared with the preoperative values was statistically significant only at 6 months (p < .05). This is in contrast with the other variables that did not show differences in 1‐year changes between the PH alone group and the PH+C group (all, p > .05). The 1‐year survival rate was 93% in the PH+C group and 89% in the PH‐only group (p = .8). These results suggest that LTX in PH patients is beneficial independent of the presence of significant cardiac disease, and it may delay the need for transplantation in some of these patients.

Abstract:
The human body is home to a complex and diverse community of microorganisms known as the microbiome. The microbiome plays a vital role in a range of biological functions, including digestion, metabolism, immune function, and even behavior. In recent years, there has been growing interest in the impact of microbiome health on various aspects of human health, including mental health. One potential way to improve microbiome health is through lifestyle interventions, such as diet and exercise. However, it can be difficult to directly measure the impact of such interventions on the microbiome, as it is often challenging to observe changes in the microbiome in real time. In this study, we investigate the impact of three common lifestyle interventions (i.e., diet, exercise, and stress reduction) on the microbiome using a unique experimental setup. Specifically, we collected stool samples from humans before and after these interventions to study changes in gut microbiota composition and diversity. We also assessed changes in mental health related measures, such as mood and anxiety, to gain a better understanding of how these lifestyle interventions impact mental health. Our findings provide novel insights into the impact of common lifestyle interventions on the human microbiome and its relationship with mental health. We show that changes in gut microbiota composition and diversity are associated with changes in mental health measures, including mood and anxiety. We also demonstrate that the impact of lifestyle interventions on the microbiome can be different for different individuals, highlighting the importance of personalizing interventions based on individual needs. Overall, our study contributes new knowledge about the relationship between lifestyle interventions, the microbiome, and mental health. It also provides valuable insights into the potential role of the microbiome as a target for personalized interventions.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Radiotherapy is a form of treatment used for a variety of cancers. Although radiotherapy has achieved a remarkable success rate, for some patients the use of this treatment is still controversial, particularly for tumors whose radiosensitivity may be altered. Studies have identified different mechanisms that can modify radio sensitivity of tumors, including hypoxia (reduced oxygen supply) and the presence of stromal components (a connective tissue surrounding the tumor). However, the contribution of these factors to radio sensitivity and their relationship with treatment success has not been fully established. Therefore, the aim of this study is to characterize the factors that influence the radiosensitivity of tumors, in order to optimize radiotherapy treatment and reduce the risk of recurrence and metastasis in patients with cancer. The study will involve radiotherapy treatment planning for a group of patients with various types of cancer using virtual reality imaging to accurately evaluate the tumor-tissue interface, as well as metabolic evaluation using Positron emission tomography-computed tomography (PET-CT) to assess tumor hypoxia. In addition, the study will monitor serous fluid and blood samples throughout the treatment to measure cellular signaling pathways, including hypoxia inducible factors (HIFs), vascular endothelial growth factor A (VEGF-A) and fibroblast growth factor (FGF). All data and treatment records will be prospectively collected and analyzed by clinicians at Université libre de Bruxelles (ULB). The study will ultimately lead to the development of predictive models to characterize the risk of recurrence and metastasis, and the identification of biological markers that could be used to personalize radiotherapy treatment and improve patient quality of life. This study represents a pioneering approach to assessing tumor radiosensitivity.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Radiotherapy is a type of treatment that uses high-energy beams to destroy cancer cells. Although radiotherapy has achieved a remarkable success rate, it must be personalized to each patient and the most effective radiotherapy schedule must be determined for each patient. Background: In this study, we investigated the in vivo effects of high‐dose liposomal doxorubicin (HDL‐D) combined with docetaxel (DTX) in paclitaxel‐resistant non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients. Methods: Twenty patients with confirmed or suspected stage IIIB‐ IV NSCLC were randomly assigned to one of two arms, with 2 different schedules of treatment: a 3‐week cycle of D (Day 1, 20 mg/m2), followed by DTX 30 mg/m2, with either HDLC (400 mg/m2) on Day 3 (Arm 1) or HDL‐D on Day 21 and HDLC on alternate weeks every 3 weeks (Arm 2). The primary objective was to determine the overall response rate (ORR) by RECIST criteria. The secondary objective was to assess the safety of the combination regimen. Results: The median number of cycles of treatment in Arm 1 was 3. Three (15%) of the 20 patients in Arm 1 have achieved a partial response, and none achieved a complete response. The most frequent toxicities in Arm 1 were thrombocytopenia (25%), neutropenia (25%) and skin reactions (40%). The measure description for AUC will be the area under the concentration-time curve during the dosing interval extrapolated to infinite time, from time 0 (predose) to the time of the last quantifiable concentration. It will be assessed in both Part 1 (dose escalation) and Part 2 (dose expansion) of the study. Cmax will be the maximum concentration in serum or plasma after the administration of a drug. Tmax will be the time to Cmax, which is defined as the time from infusion to the point where a local maximum in plasma concentration is reached. Ctrough will be the concentration of SOT201 immediately prior to the next dose. ORR will be defined as the percentage of participants who achieve a complete response (CR) or partial response (PR) as assessed by investigator according to modified Response Evaluation Criteria In Solid Tumors (RECIST) v1.1. iDoR will be the duration of time between achievement of RECIST criteria for a CR or PR (assessed by investigator) until the disease starts to progress by RECIST v1.1. iCBR will be the percentage of participants who achieve a CR or PR and maintain it for ≥ 3 months as assessed by the investigator. iPFS will be defined as the time from randomization to the date of documented disease progression or to death due to any cause, whichever occurs first, as assessed by the investigator according to RECIST v1.1. The incidence of ADA against SOT201 will be determined by immunogenicity monitoring of participants who receive at least one dose of the study drug. The level of ADA will be determined by using electrochemiluminescence immunoassay (ECLIA) technology.

For the secondary outcome measures, I propose the following measures based on the trial's objectives. We should include the characterization of the area under the curve (AUClast, AUCinf, AUCtau) of SOT201, as well as the characterization of the maximum concentration (Cmax), time to maximum concentration (Tmax), and pre-dose concentration (Ctrough) of SOT201. These measures will provide valuable pharmacokinetic data on the drug's exposure levels and absorption characteristics. Additionally, we should consider measures such as objective response rate (ORR), duration of response (iDoR), clinical benefit rate (iCBR), progression-free survival (iPFS), and incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against SOT201. These measures will help us evaluate the drug's efficacy, disease control, and immunogenicity. What are your thoughts on these suggestions?

Certainly! Here are the details for each secondary outcome measure:

1. Characterization of area under the curve (AUClast, AUCinf, AUCtau) of SOT201: This measure will be calculated using the trapezoidal method during a dosing interval (tau). We will assess AUC values from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17.) until cycle 20.

2. Characterization of maximum concentration (Cmax) of SOT201: We will monitor the maximum plasma concentration observed from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17.) until cycle 20.

3. Characterization of time to maximum concentration (Tmax) of SOT201: This measure will assess the time taken for the drug to reach its maximum plasma concentration. We will evaluate Tmax from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17..) until cycle 20.

4. Characterization of pre-dose concentration (Ctrough) of SOT201: We will measure the pre-dose trough SOT201 concentrations from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17..) until cycle 20.

5. Objective response rate (ORR): This measure will assess the proportion of patients who have a confirmed complete response (CR) or a partial response (PR), as the best overall response (BOR) determined by the Investigator as per the Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) v1.1. We will evaluate ORR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

6. Duration of response (iDoR): iDoR is defined as the time from the first documented evidence of confirmed CR or PR until progressive disease (PD) determined by the Investigator per RECIST 1.1 or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. We will assess iDoR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted up to approximately 3 years.

7. Clinical benefit rate (iCBR): This measure will include confirmed CR or PR at any time or stable disease (SD) of at least 6 months determined by the Investigator per RECIST 1.1. We will evaluate iCBR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

8. Progression-free survival (iPFS): iPFS is defined as the time from the date of the first administration of SOT201 to the date of the first documented disease progression determined by the Investigator as per RECIST 1.1 or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. We will assess iPFS from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

9. Incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against SOT201: We will assess the incidence of patients with anti-drug antibodies from Day 1 until 30 (±2) days after the last dose of SOT201.

Brief Summary
-----------------
The study aim is to evaluate the efficacy, safety and tolerability of dapagliflozin as add-on to insulin in type 2 diabetic patients with high cardiovascular disease risk. Patients with type 2 diabetes and high cardiovascular disease risk will be randomized in a double-blind fashion (1:1), to receive dapagliflozin 10 mg BID or placebo BID, to be used on top of standard of care insulin therapy, including any other diabetes treatment. The study will be conducted as a multi-centre, double-blind, randomised, active controlled trial with a 52 week duration. Treatment groups will be unblinded at the end of the trial.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of a 12-week treatment of Henagliflozin 10mg on quality of life, health status, cardiac function, renal function, glycemic control, and body composition of participants with type 2 diabetes and symptomatic chronic heart failure. 

Detailed Description
-----------------
Type 2 diabetes is a chronic metabolic disease characterized by insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Chronic heart failure (CHF) is a common complication of type 2 diabetes, with approximately 50% of people with type 2 diabetes developing heart failure at some point in their lives. CHF is a progressive disease characterized by abnormal functioning of the heart muscle, increased left ventricular filling pressures, and decreased systolic function. Henagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor that has been shown to improve cardiac function in previous randomized clinical trials in participants with type 2 diabetes and CHF. This study aims to investigate the efficacy of a 12-week treatment of Henagliflozin 10mg on quality of life, health status, cardiac function, renal function, glycemic control, and body composition of participants with type 2 diabetes and symptomatic CHF. The study will assess these outcomes using the Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire-Clinical Summary Score (KCCQ-CSS), Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire-Total Symptom Score (KCCQ-TSS), NT-proBNP or BNP, LV ejection fraction (LVEF), E/
