Monitoring the change in E/e' ratio will provide insights into the effect of Henagliflozin on diastolic function and left ventricular filling pressures in participants with type 2 diabetes and chronic heart failure. This measure is crucial for evaluating the impact of Henagliflozin on diastolic function and heart failure status.

Including the "Change From Baseline in UACR at Week 4 and 12" as a secondary outcome measure is a good idea. The urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio (UACR) is a marker of kidney function and is commonly used to assess renal health in patients with diabetes and heart failure. Monitoring the change in UACR will allow you to evaluate the effect of Henagliflozin on renal function and determine if there are any improvements in kidney health over time. This measure is important for assessing the impact of Henagliflozin on renal function in participants with type 2 diabetes and chronic heart failure.

Including the "Change From Baseline in eGFR at Week 4 and 12" as a secondary outcome measure is a great idea. Estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is a key parameter used to assess kidney function and is often used to monitor renal health in patients with diabetes and heart failure. Measuring the change in eGFR will provide valuable information on the effect of Henagliflozin on renal function and kidney health in participants with type 2 diabetes. This measure is essential for evaluating the impact of Henagliflozin on kidney function and overall renal health.

Abstract:
This is a clinical trial designed to investigate the safety and efficacy of linvoseltamab in patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma. Subjects will receive intravenous doses of linvoseltamab over a 30‐minute period for two consecutive days every three weeks. Safety and tolerability will be assessed by monitoring adverse events and laboratory parameters. Serum drug concentrations will be measured to determine the pharmacokinetics of linvoseltamab. The study also aims to evaluate the clinical activity of linvoseltamab by measuring the percentage decrease in monoclonal protein levels in the blood. In addition, the study will evaluate the impact of linvoseltamab on immune system function, by measuring the numbers of B cells, T cells, and natural killer cells in the blood before and after treatment. Immunogenicity evaluation will also be performed to assess the development of antibodies against linvoseltamab. The study will be conducted in multiple centers in the United States and Europe. Patients will be followed up for 24 months after the last dose of linvoseltamab. The study will involve approximately 200 patients.

Sure. Efficacy outcome measures in multiple myeloma (MM) have traditionally focused on complete and partial response rates, duration of response, and overall survival. However, these measures can be limited in their ability to provide real-time insights into treatment response and disease progression due to their lag time between evaluations. Therefore, we will also assess these outcome measures, but in addition, we will also develop real-time endpoints to improve our ability to monitor response to treatment in real time. Some potential real-time endpoints to consider could be minimum residual disease, time to lytic lesion progression, or changes in circulating biomarkers.

For secondary outcome measures, we can assess the median time to progression and overall survival, and the overall response rate using the IMWG response criteria in both Phase 1 and Phase 2, as well as in a subgroup of participants with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma. We can also assess the immunogenicity of Linvoseltamab using an assay that detects anti-drug antibodies (ADAs). 

Abstract:
Therapeutic options for patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM) are limited and novel therapies are needed. Linvoseltamab is a humanized immunoglobulin G1 monoclonal antibody directed against Signal Regulatory Protein-α (SIRPα) that blocks the CD47‐CSF1R interaction, and has showed promising clinical activity in patients with RRMM in a phase 1/ 2 trial. This study will assess the safety and efficacy of Linvoseltamab in participants with RRMM. The primary endpoint is the rate of objective response according to the International Myeloma Working Group Uniform Response Criteria for Multiple Myeloma. Secondary endpoints include time to progression, time to next therapy, response duration, progression‐free survival, and overall survival. Adverse events and changes in laboratory parameters will also be monitored. The study will also assess the immunogenicity of Linvoseltamab. The findings of this study will provide important information on the potential of Linvoseltamab as a treatment option for patients with RRMM.

INTRODUCTION
To date, no approved treatment exists for patients with RRMM who have progressed on at least three lines of therapy. Therefore, there is a need for new treatment options that offer efficacy and tolerability. Linvoseltamab, a humanized immunoglobulin G1 monoclonal antibody, has demonstrated promising efficacy and safety profiles in patients with RRMM in several phase 1/ 2 studies. The current study, referred to as the phase 3, is a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blinded study designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Linvoseltamab in patients with RRMM. Study design
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Patients with bronchiectasis who have been transplanted with autologous lung progenitor cells will have better lung function and a better quality of life.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a multi-center and randomized controlled study. Eligible participants will be randomly assigned into three groups: cell transplantation group, placebo group and standard group. The patients in the placebo group will be injected with the saline. The patients in the standard group will be treated with the standard treatment and the patients in the cell transplantation group will receive autologous lung progenitor cells transplantation. The cell dosage will range from 100 million cells to 10 million cells injected intratracheally every week for 3 consecutive weeks. Pulmonary function test, chest CT scan, 6MWT, cough-related quality of life survey (QLQ-BN20 scale) and patient satisfaction assessment will be evaluated after cell transplantation according to the different doses of lung progenitor cells. The cell dosage will range from 100 million cells to 10 million cells injected intratracheally every week for 3 consecutive weeks.

Abstract:
Background: Bronchiectasis is a chronic pulmonary disease characterized by irreversible bronchial dilatation, which may lead to recurrent episodes of pulmonary exacerbation, poor lung function, persistent bacterial infection and an increased risk of mortality. Despite that the disease causes considerable morbidity and socio‐economic burdens, effective pharmacological treatments are not available yet. Autologous transplantation of lung progenitor cells (LPCs) is currently studied as a cell‐based therapy for bronchiectasis and might provide hope for patients with this condition. P63+ LPCs are promising candidates for treating bronchiectasis as they can differentiate into epithelial and mesenchymal cells, which make it possible to repair damaged tissue. This phase 1/2 clinical trial plans to transplant autologous P63+ LPCs to patients who are suffering from end‐stage bronchiectasis. P63+ LPCs will be harvested from the patient's trachea without the need for invasive bronchoscopies, which makes this method minimally invasive. After cell harvesting, remaining cells will be cultured and expanded ex vivo by epithelial cell specialists. The cells will be transplanted into the patient's airway, which will help repair the damaged bronchi and restore proper lung function. The primary objective of this study is to evaluate the safety of autologous transplantation of P63+ LPCs in patients with end‐stage bronchiectasis. Secondary objectives include assessing the efficacy of this therapy by evaluating changes in FEV1, FVC, FEF25‐75% and total lung capacity (TLC) as well as hospitalization and antibiotic use. Additionally, the role of lung progenitor cells in bronchiectasis pathogenesis will be further investigated by collecting various samples for molecular characterization. The research team will analyze immune responses and inflammatory markers in the lung to determine potential mechanisms of action. This research will provide valuable information on the safety and efficacy of autologous transplantation of LPCs in patients with bronchiectasis. If successful, this cell‐based therapy has the potential to become a promising treatment option for patients with this debilitating disease.

The use of an adhesive sealant combined with a perforated metal plate as a bone substitute in the treatment of a mandibular third molar perforation. Bone substitute and adhesive were tested experimentally and clinically for this purpose. Two female patients with perforations of the lateral wall of the mandible were treated surgically with a bone substitute combined with an adhesive in one patient and a perforated plate combined with an adhesive in the other. The study period was 6 months. After 10 weeks, reparative new bone was visible on the radiographs in both patients. The new bone continued to grow for ten more weeks in the patient in whom adhesive and perforated plate were used. After six months, the radiographs of both patients showed a radiolucent area corresponding to the original perforation. On both patients' maxillary and mandibular radiographs, however, this area was not visible.

This is a double-blind, randomized study to determine if daily 80 mg duloxetine can prevent recurrence of painful paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) symptoms after transplantation. In an additional analysis, the efficacy of daily 80 mg duloxetine for the specific prevention of recurrent microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) in the setting of renal transplantation was also evaluated. A total of 43 renal transplant recipients who had experienced PNH but had normal serum LDH levels at least 6 months before the retransplant were assigned randomly to one of two groups: the duloxetine treatment group (n=23) and the control group who did not receive duloxetine (n=20). Over a six-month observational period, the primary endpoint was the number of painful PNH episodes that occurred after transplantation. Recurrent MAHA was captured as a secondary endpoint. Results: The duloxetine treatment group demonstrated a significantly higher frequency of treatment-discontinuation (23/23 vs 7/20, p=0.002). Despite a lower frequency of painful episodes in the duloxetine treatment group compared to the control group (33.1% vs 54.1%, p<0.001), the difference did not reach statistical significance (p=0.09). In an additional analysis (n=40), nine subjects in the duloxetine treatment group had a recurrence of MAHA after renal transplantation, as compared to 7 subjects in the control group (p=0.12). However, in this analysis, there was no association between the recurrence of MAHA and the occurrence of painful PN

Brief Summary

The purpose of this study is to explore the association between the baseline characteristics of patients and their response to Sotagliflozin treatment. In addition, we want to investigate the pharmacokinetics (PK) and safety of Sotagliflozin

Detailed Description
-----------------
Type 1 Diabetes (T1D), a chronic disease in which the beta cell mass is irreversibly reduced due to an autoimmune T-cell mediated destruction of pancreatic insulin-producing beta cells, remains a clinical challenge. The disease is treated with insulin supplementation, but the optimal insulin regime remains unknown. Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) therapy has been shown to substantially improve glucose control in T1D with a combination of insulin and glucose sensor based algorithm based insulin delivery with no hypoglycemia. Glucagon is an other endogenously secreted hormone, which has beneficial glucodynamic effects in the setting of hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia. Sotagliflozin is a dual sodium glucose co-transporter (SGLT)-1/SGLT-2 inhibitor that has been shown to be beneficial for Type 2 Diabetes (T2D). In this research project, we postulate that, based upon the existing literature, a GLP-1 receptor agonist (GLP-1RA) and a SGLT-1/SGLT-2 inhibitor, possibly in combination, may improve and maintain the glucose control in individuals with T1D. The long-term goal is to develop an efficient treatment of diabetes in general, and to identify the underlying mechanism behind a responsive and a non-responsive phenotype to either insulin alone, GLP-1RA or both, in T1D and T2D. Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
Brief summary of the background of the study The UK has the worst rates of teenage pregnancy in Western Europe, with 18,319 under 16 conceptions and 26,300 live births in England and Wales between 2017 and 2019 . Many reasons for this have been explored including socio-economic factors. It has been suggested that teenage pregnancy may be seen as a coping mechanism for young people who don't have access to, or feel comfortable using contraception . This study is being conducted to explore whether it will improve access to and confidence in effective contraception by working with vulnerable young people in care and exploring whether this reduces their risk of teenage pregnancy. By providing this intervention these young people will receive 8 sessions of health education and support from one of the young people who used this type of service when they found themselves in a similar position. We are aiming to reduce unplanned teenage pregnancy among young people in care. Specifically we are testing the hypothesis that offering contraception intervention delivered by peers, using a groupwork approach and a non judgemental approach, will reduce teenage pregnancy rates in care. Brief summary of objective of the study We will recruit young people who are in care, who are not sexually active, but who are thinking about being sexually active in the next 6 months, to receive an 8 week health education intervention which includes a group based session and three individual sessions. The intervention will be led by Peer Educators, who are previously looked after young people. They will deliver the intervention in a way that will empower young people with regards to making informed decisions about their sexual health and effective contraception.

The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of the treatment of lumbar disc herniation by spinal nerve root ganglion blockade. A double-blind, placebo-controlled study 

Detailed Description
-----------------
Severe lumbar disc herniation can be the cause of sciatic nerve root pain caused by the nerve root nerve root compression of the lumbar spinal nerve root. Spinal ganglion blockade (SGB), also known as epidural nerve root block, has been suggested as a treatment alternative. Spinal ganglion blockade can be performed by performing nerve field blockage with a local anesthetic and steroids and spinal anesthetic. Spinal anesthetic is known to perform the analgesic effect by blocking the conductive nerve function directly at the injured nerve.

Abstract:
Background: The association between depressive symptoms and chronic pain conditions is well‐documented. This cross‐sectional survey study aimed to examine whether depression influences knee pain in knee osteoarthritis (OA) patients, as well as the impact of depression severity on different aspects of their pain experience, including pain intensity and pain interference. Methods: A sample of 200 individuals with knee OA (age: M = 58.92, SD = 10.18; BMI: M = 30.54, SD = 5.17) was recruited from a public healthcare facility and self‐administered scales measuring pain, depression, and other psychological variables. Results: The results indicated a modest negative correlation between depression and pain intensity, but no significant difference in pain intensity was found between those with different levels of depression severity. However, the multiple meds regression results indicated that the relationship between pain intensity and depression severity was indirectly mediated by pain interference. The more severe the depression, the stronger the mediating effect of pain intensity, resulting in greater reduction in activity. However, no significant direct effect of depression severity on activity was found. Conclusion: While our results suggest that depression has a negative influence on pain intensity, the influence of pain interference seems to be stronger, particularly in terms of activity. This study provides important insights for clinicians and researchers in healthcare services, who can use these findings to inform the development of more effective interventions for patients with knee OA and comorbid depression. Moreover, it highlights the role of pain interference as a potential target for intervention to improve treatment outcomes.

Absolutely. Let's go through the secondary outcome measures one by one. The first measure is the Brief Pain Inventory - Numeric Rating Scale. This measure assesses pain intensity by asking about worst and least pain intensity in the past 24 hours, pain on average, and pain right now. It uses an 11-point scale, with zero representing 'no pain' and 10 representing the 'worst imaginable pain'. This measure has been shown to have excellent reliability and validity in people with knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is the Modified Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI). This measure assesses the presence of comorbidities in participants, including knee osteoarthritis. The CCI has been widely used in various patient populations, including knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is endogenous pain modulation, which assesses the efficiency of pain modulation mechanisms in individuals with knee osteoarthritis. We can use the conditioned pain modulation (CPM) testing method to evaluate this measure. By assessing the ascending measure of pressure pain threshold (PPT) at the anterior shin and the conditioning stimulus in the form of forearm ischemia, we can calculate the percent efficiency of CPM (%CPM) as PPT2/PPT1 multiplied by 100. This measure can provide insights into the neurobiological effects of the intervention. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks.

The other secondary outcome measures include pain interference, pain catastrophizing, Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), multi-joint pain assessed through a body diagram, knee awareness, functional leg strength, medication use, adverse events, patient global impression of change, blinding effectiveness, usefulness of the program for managing knee OA, frequency of the program, duration of the program, acceptability of the delivery of the brain stimulation, acceptability of the delivery of the yoga session of the program, likelihood of recommending the program to others with knee OA, burdensomeness of completing questionnaires and physical assessments, adherence rate, and rate of completion of home sessions. 1. "Number of sport units per week, sport disciplines practiced": This measure will provide valuable information on the level of physical activity and sports participation of patients post-surgery. It would quantify the number of sport units per week and the variety of sport disciplines practiced. This will help us evaluate the impact of the surgical intervention on patients' ability to engage in sports.
2. "Length of sport units": Measuring the length of sport units in minutes will give us insight into the intensity and duration of physical activity patients are able to perform post-surgery. This information is important in assessing the functional outcomes and endurance of patients following the surgical intervention.
3. "Range of motion after surgery": Evaluating the range of motion in degrees after surgery is essential in determining the success of the surgical reconstruction in restoring normal joint function. Changes in range of motion can indicate improvements or limitations in mobility and flexibility post-surgery.
4. "Subjective change of instability after surgery": Using a visual analog scale to assess subjective changes in instability post-surgery will provide valuable information on patients' perception of their joint stability. This outcome measure allows for the evaluation of functional outcomes related to stability and balance following the surgical intervention.
5. "Change of pain after surgery": Measuring changes in pain levels using a visual analog scale is important in assessing the effectiveness of the surgical intervention in reducing pain associated with insertional Achilles tendinopathy. Patients' pain levels can significantly impact their ability to participate in sports and physical activities.
6. "Satisfaction with result": Assessing patients' satisfaction with the surgical result using a visual analog scale provides insight into their overall experience and outcomes following the intervention. Patient satisfaction is an important indicator of treatment success and can influence their quality of life and willingness to engage in sports activities.

This measure should also be assessed a minimum of 12 months from surgery to follow-up.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Prostate‐specific antigen (PSA) testing is the current standard for the screening and management of prostate cancer. Nevertheless, PSA testing can cause overdiagnosis and overtreatment of patients with prostate cancer. Moreover, the accuracy of PSA testing can be hampered by the heterogeneity of prostate cancer. Thus, there is a need for a more precise and personalized approach to prostate cancer diagnosis and treatment. METHODS: In this study, we propose to investigate whether choline PET‐CT can be used as an adjunct to PSA testing to improve the accuracy and precision of prostate cancer diagnosis and treatment. We will enroll approximately 100 patients with prostate cancer who underwent PSA testing and have been referred for choline PET‐CT. The primary outcome measure will be the concordance between the results of PSA testing and choline PET‐CT. The secondary outcome measures will be the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV), and accuracy of choline PET‐CT for the detection of clinically significant prostate cancer (CS prostate cancer). RESULTS: The concordance between the results of PSA testing and choline PET‐CT was high (89%). The sensitivity, specificity, PPV, NPV, and accuracy of choline PET‐CT for the detection of CS prostate cancer were 93%, 82%, 88%, 93%, and 91%, respectively. All patients were successfully enrolled in the study and completed the study protocol. CONCLUSIONS: Choline PET‐CT is a promising tool for improving the accuracy and precision of prostate cancer diagnosis and treatment. Our findings suggest that choline PET‐CT can be used as an adjunct to PSA testing to help identify patients with CS prostate cancer and avoid unnecessary biopsies and overtreatment.

Abstract:
PURPOSE: The aim of the study was to investigate the influence of chemotherapy treatment on cardiotoxicity in breast cancer patients.METHODS: Between February 2002 and April 2009, 112 patients with stage II or III breast cancer receiving first‐line adjuvant regimens with taxans (paclitaxel or docetaxel) were enrolled. Cardiac complications were evaluated by echocardiography at a regular interval and when clinical conditions were changed.RESULTS: There were no significant differences in changes in left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) (baseline, 67.8 Â± 5.9%; follow‐up, 66.7 Â± 7.2%) and shortening fraction (baseline, 28.8 Â± 4.6; follow‐up, 27.5 Â± 5.0%) between 39 patients who received trastuzumab and 73 patients who received chemotherapy alone. The mean LVEF of all patients at 48 weeks was 65.3 Â± 6.2%, and the cumulative incidence of cardiotoxicity was 11.5% (pulse <or= .001) after adjuvant paclitaxel or docetaxel. Of 73 patients who did not receive trastuzumab, the cumulative incidence of cardiotoxicity was 13.3%, which was statistically significant (p = .042).CONCLUSION: The incidence of cardiac damage in breast cancer patients receiving chemotherapy for 48 weeks was significantly lower in our study (11.5%, p <or= .002) than reported (15.6%) in previous reports. Prospective studies with a long‐term follow‐up are needed to clarify cardiac complications in breast cancer

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Colorectal cancer is the third most common cancer worldwide and remains the second leading cause of cancer death in the United States. African American (AA) and Hispanic American (HA) populations experience disparities in colorectal cancer incidence, mortality, and screening rates. Peer education programs have demonstrated effectiveness in improving cancer screening rates; however, these programs are not commonly utilized. The main objective of this study is to develop and conduct a needs assessment to identify AAs and HAs' perceived needs and barriers to implementation of a program to conduct home‐based peer education to increase colorectal cancer screening rates among those populations.METHODS: The proposed research will involve conducting a needs assessment using the Intervention Mapping (IM) framework. The target audience of this research is AAs and HAs living within the state of Nebraska who may be eligible to receive a colorectal cancer screening. A total of six focus groups (three AAs and three HAs, each containing six to 10 people), each lasting around an hour in length, will be conducted in a private setting. During the focus groups, we will use a semi‐structured guide to ask participants about their perceptions of colorectal cancer screening and barriers to screening and use a modified peer education curriculum to facilitate group discussion on preferred peer education strategies. Following each focus group, survey tools will be distributed to gauge participants' knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors towards peer education. Quantitative and qualitative data from the focus groups and surveys will be collected and analyzed to generate recommendations for tailoring peer education programs to target AAs and HAs.DISCUSSION: This study fills a critical gap in the literature by providing the first step in the process of translating evidence‐based colorectal cancer screening practices into a culturally and linguistically concordant educational program specific to AA and HA individuals in Nebraska. Such an intervention could significantly reduce disparities in colorectal cancer screening rates and improve health equity.TRIAL REGISTRATION: NCT

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: In Ontario, Canada, the Peer Connect pilot project aims to pilot and evaluate a peer navigation model of care for socially disadvantaged older adults with cancer. To ensure the model is adapted and relevant to socially disadvantaged older adults living in the community, this study aims to qualitatively explore socially disadvantaged older adults' views and perspectives towards navigation services. METHODS: Focus groups and semi‐structured interviews with socially disadvantaged older adults will be combined with a theoretical and literature review to guide an iterative adaptation of the Peer Connect navigation training materials. The interviews and focus groups will be audio‐recorded, transcribed verbatim, and analysed using Framework Analysis. An interim analysis will be conducted after the first 10 interviews, and if needed, the training materials will be adapted to better meet the needs of this population. The study will then proceed as planned. DISCUSSION: This study may help to elicit the facilitators and barriers to the adoption of peer navigation services by socially disadvantaged older adults with cancer and inform the implementation of the navigation program. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Registration NCT05204337; Pre‐results.

Certainly. The antiandrogen drugs that will be used in this study include flutamide, nilutamide, and enzalutamide. The cytotoxic chemotherapy treatments used in this study include docetaxel, cabazitaxel, and prednisone. Radiographic workup will include bone scan, computed tomography, and FDG-PET CT. Study Objectives
-----------------
The objectives of this study is to use FDG-PET -guided radiation therapy for men with metastatic prostate cancer and to determine the prognosis for overall survival and disease control.

Trial Design
-----------------
This is an open-label, prospective observational cohort study to examine the prognosis based on bone metastasis status and FDG uptake by tumors in treatment-naive patients with metastatic prostate cancer. Patients are enrolled after providing informed consent; no randomization takes place.


Intervention / Treatments
-----------------
All enrolled patients receive antiandrogen therapy, bone scan, computed tomography, FDG-positron emission tomography, and radiation therapy for tumor response. The main intervention for this study is the use of FDG-PET-guided radiation therapy, which uses FDG-PET to determine the metabolic status of lesions and to adjust the dose of radiotherapy accordingly.


Detailed Description
-----------------
This prospective cohort study will evaluate patients with metastatic prostate cancer who are undergoing first-line antiandrogen therapy. Patients will be enrolled after providing informed consent. Bone metastasis will be evaluated by bone scan, and FDG-PET will be used to detect metastases other than bone. Patients with FDG-PET-positive lesions will be stratified into two groups: with bone metastasis (group A) or without bone metastasis (group B). FDG-PET will be performed before radiation therapy and during follow-up, and the metabolic response will be evaluated using various indices such as standardized uptake value (SUV). Now, let's move on to the sample size and justification. Can you provide me with those details? 

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: It is important to consider the sample size and justification when conducting clinical trials. The sample size justification should be based on the statistical power (the likelihood of detecting a treatment effect if one exists) and the desired type I error (false positive rate) associated with the trial. In this case, a randomized phase II trial evaluating the efficacy of fludeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG‐PET)‐guided metastasis directed radiation therapy (MDRT) in patients with castration‐sensitive or castration‐resistant prostate cancer with 1‐5 bone metastases. METHODS: Statistical power assumptions include the primary outcome measure (PFS) and secondary outcome measures (PSA response, skeletal‐related events, AEs). The desired power is 80%, a desired type I error (false positive rate) is 10%. The expected PFS difference between Arms 1A and 1B is 0.1 years, the expected PSA response difference is 10% between baseline and post‐MDRT (Arm 1A vs Arm 1B), and the expected AE difference is 10% between Arm 1A and Arm 1B. For each outcome measure, the number of patients needed to enroll is calculated and the total sample size is determined accordingly (88 patients). The final sample size of 176 is needed to achieve the desired power and type I error. RESULTS: The planned sample size of 176 patients is sufficient to detect a treatment benefit for the primary and secondary outcome measures. CONCLUSION: The sample size and justification ensure the validity of the trial results, thereby providing a basis for evidence‐based medicine and decision‐making. The justification process is an important step in trial planning and supports the overall goal of developing evidence‐based interventions for patient care. The trial is ongoing, and the results will contribute to new knowledge on personalized medicine in prostate cancer.

Excellent! Now that we have discussed and finalized the outcome measures, here is the summary of the outcome measures for your clinical trial:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Quality of analgesia measured by visual analogue scale: This measure rates pain severity from 0 to 10, with 0 representing no pain at all and 10 representing the worst intolerable pain. The assessment will be conducted during the first 48 hours.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Parameters of adequate ventilation and oxygenation: Monitoring the PaO2/FiO2 ratio and PaCO2 at regular intervals (1, 2, 3, 4, 8, 16, 24, 36, and 48 hours) to evaluate respiratory function.
- Sedation score using the Ramsay score: Assessing sedation levels every 8 hours for 48 hours using a scale ranging from 1 (agitated and uncomfortable) to 6 (asleep with no response to stimulation).

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a multi-center, multiple-ascending dose (MAD) Phase 1a study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetic (PK) and pharmacodynamic (PD) effects of various KZR-616 doses in participants with type 2 diabetes and chronic kidney disease (CKD). 

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will last for approximately 46 weeks, from Screening to Week 72, and will consist of the following periods: Screening Period (Week -4 to -2), Single Ascending Dose (SAD) Period (Participants in cohort 1 and 2, Weeks -1 to 4), Multiple Ascending Dose (MAD) Period (Cohort 2, Weeks -1 to 72), Follow-up Period (Participants in cohort 1 and 2, Weeks 8 to 72), and Follow-up Period for Efficacy Extension Phase (Participants of all cohorts, Weeks 8 to 72). A total of 6 cohorts with 6 participants per cohort will be enrolled in the study. Participants will receive a single subcutaneous (SC) dose of KZR-616 administered once daily (QD) in a flexible, continuous-dosing format and/or a single SC dose of KZR-616 QD for up to 72 weeks. The study is being conducted in order to support the safety, tolerability and initial indication of the study drug by evaluating multiple

The secondary outcome measures of the study include changes in lung function and exercise capacity from baseline to week 72 and the proportion of participants with ≥1 AE. Changes in lung function will be assessed using forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and forced vital capacity (FVC). Changes in exercise capacity will be measured using the six-minute walking test (6MWT). The incidence of AEs will be reported throughout the study.

The inclusion of multiple secondary outcome measures reflects the multifaceted nature of COPD and the broader aims of this study, which aim to provide a deeper understanding of the long-term impact and safety of Itepekimab in patients with COPD. 

Functional Itepekimab concentrations in serum will be useful in understanding the pharmacokinetic profile and duration of exposure to Itepekimab in participants with COPD. Incidence of anti-drug antibody responses will provide information on the potential for immune-mediated adverse events. 

In terms of the clinical outcome measures, the annualized rate of moderate-to-severe AECOPD provides valuable insights into the effectiveness of Itepekimab in reducing the frequency and severity of exacerbations, which are a key clinical manifestation of COPD. 

SeaCOPD is a crucial aspect of COPD management, as it is associated with increased morbidity, mortality, and healthcare resource utilization. The annualized rate of severe AECOPD provides a measure of the incidence of the most severe exacerbations and allows for comparisons against the background rate of severe exacerbation in the community. 

Time to first moderate-to-severe AECOPD and time to first severe AECOPD are important measures that provide information about the duration of time between Itepekimab administration and the occurrence of exacerbations. Understanding the duration of protection against exacerbations is important for optimizing treatment strategies and reducing the burden of disease. 

The change from baseline in FEV1, SGRQ total score, domain scores, and the EQ-5D-5L single index score and EQ-VAS will provide information on the impact of Itepekimab on health-related quality of life and the overall impact of Itepekimab on patients with COPD. 

In summary, the secondary outcome measures in this study provide comprehensive information on the safety, pharmacokinetics, and efficacy of Itepekimab in patients with COPD. The inclusion of these outcome measures reflects the importance of addressing these key aspects of COPD in order to develop effective and safe treatments.

Of course! The primary outcome measure in cohort B is the pharmacodynamic (PD) effect of LRRK2 inhibitors on LRRK2 kinase activity in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs). We will collect blood samples before and after the administration of the LRRK2 inhibitors and use Western blotting to measure the level of LRRK2 kinase activity. We will measure the change in LRRK2 kinase activity in PBMCs collected before and after the administration of LRRK2 inhibitors to assess the potency of LRRK2 inhibitors. We will also measure the LRRK2 kinase activity in PBMCs collected from a healthy control group to serve as a control group for the analysis. The primary outcome measure description is the change in LRRK2 kinase activity in PBMCs collected before and after the administration of LRRK2 inhibitors. The time frame for this outcome measure depends on the pharmacokinetic (PK) properties of the LRRK2 inhibitors being tested, but it typically takes several hours for the effects of LRRK2 inhibitors to be seen in PBMCs.

Introduction
Stress is a common physical and psychological reaction to various stimuli that can affect individuals in their daily lives. Stress affects people in many ways. Stress can weaken the immune system and cause physical and psychological symptoms, such as depression and anxiety, which can further contribute to disease progression and worsen quality of life (QoL). In particular, when a stressor causes acute physiological stress, it can activate immune responses through various physiological changes in the body, such as increased blood pressure, heart rate, and respiratory rate, and can disrupt the balance of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis. These changes are associated with an increased risk of long-term illness. In contrast, chronic physiological stress can lead to chronic diseases such as obesity, diabetes, depression, and CAD.
People at risk are those who are exposed to stressful stimuli or situations more often or for longer periods. According to a literature survey, stress management is essential for cancer patients, and the degree of stress experienced by patients can influence physiological symptoms and QoL. Patients with cancer may feel overwhelmed by the diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis, and the financial and social burdens of cancer can also add to their stress. As a result, cancer patients may experience depression, anxiety, and anger and may need assistance from family, friends, or healthcare providers.
The prevalence of stress in the general population is known to be high, but it is even higher in specific groups such as front-line workers and those who are unemployed. A higher percentage of patients with CAD have been reported to have suffered from stress than have controls without CAD. The stress of cancer patients is also generally known to be high.
There are many studies on the link between stress and CAD, but most of them are observational studies. The relationship between stress levels and CAD severity has been reported. In this study, we aim to evaluate the psychological stress of CAD patients before and after coronary angiography (CAG), and to determine the factors affecting psychological stress.

Certainly! Here are the specifics: 1. Retention is assessed by evaluating the presence or absence of endocrown restorations using a visual inspection and dental exploration. If the endocrown is retained and secure, a score of 1 is given. If the endocrown is partially or completely lost, a score of 0 is assigned. 2. Marginal discoloration is assessed by evaluating the presence or absence of discoloration of the endocrown margins using a visual examination. If no discoloration is observed, a score of 1 is provided; if the discoloration is minimal or moderate, a score of 0 is given, and if the discoloration is severe, a score of -1 is assigned. 3. Marginal adaptation is assessed by evaluating the degree of conformity between the endocrown and the tooth using a periodontal probe. If the gap is less than 0.5 mm, a score of 1 is assigned; if the gap is between 0.5 and 1mm, a score of 0 is given, and if the gap is greater than 1mm, a score of -1 is recorded. 4. Secondary caries is assessed by examining the tooth in question and checking for the presence or absence of carious lesions. If no such lesions are observed, a score of 1 is assigned, whereas if any carious lesions are present, a score of 0 is given. The outcome measure design sounds comprehensive, and the use of visual inspections, dental explorations, and quantitative assessments will provide valuable information on the clinical performance of the CAD/CAM endocrown restorations.

Abstract:
Objectives/Hypothesis: Awareness of hypertension and associated risks can influence the management of hypertension. This study assessed hypertensive awareness and treatment in Nigerian patients. Methods: A total of 200 uncontrolled, hypertensive adults were randomly selected from a list of adult patients from a private ambulatory outpatient clinic in Enugu, Nigeria. Fasting blood pressure was measured using a validated automated sphygmomanometer. Individuals with systolic blood pressure ≥ 140 mm Hg and/or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 90 mm Hg who had no history of hypertension or had not taken antihypertensive medication in the last one month were enrolled into the study. Questionnaire‐guided interviews were used to screen participants for awareness of hypertension and its associated risks; patients with awareness were questioned about their attitudes and treatment practices. Descriptive statistics were used to summarize the responses. 

Introduction
Physiological adaptations to increased sympathetic activity and vasoconstriction occur in the early stages of hypertension, often with few or no observable symptoms. However, with sustained elevated blood pressure, end‐organ damage may occur. Common causes of sustained hypertension include insulin resistance, chronic kidney disease, sleep apnea, overweight/obesity, and lifestyle factors (e.g., poor nutrition, excessive alcohol intake, and drug substance abuse). Uncontrolled hypertension can lead to a host of complications such as stroke, heart failure, and nephropathy. The risk of complications is increased when hypertension is poorly controlled, a lack of knowledge about the disease and lifestyle choices, lack of access to health facilities, low health-seeking behaviors, and non‐adherence to antihypertensive treatment.
Globally, there was an estimated 1.13 billion adults with raised blood pressure in 2015, contributing to an increase of 7.5 million death per year from stroke and 6.4 million from heart disease. Hypertension is one of the top ten causes of mortality and disability-adjusted life years glob

Abstract:
Introduction: Gingival crevicular fluid (GCF) is an important site for the analysis of molecules, as it is in direct contact with the periodontitis, the microbiota and the systemic circulation. Therefore, it can be an important biological medium for understanding many periodontal diseases. For that reason, GCF research represents a rapidly growing field in biological sciences. Aims: The aim of this article is to present an overview of some of the main aspects in GCF research and an update on the current biomarkers and bioanalytes in GCF. Materials and Methods: To fulfill this review, two searches were made, with "gingival crevicular fluid", "fluid associated with gingival crevicular", " gingival crevicular fluid analysis" and "human gingival crevicular fluid" as the search terms. The inclusion criteria included articles in English with an abstract, published in scientific journals between 2018 and 2021. A total of 190 articles were analyzed. Results: This research has provided an overview of some of the most relevant aspects in GCF research and a detailed update analysis on GCF biomarkers and bioanalytes. It has been possible to determine that all the analyzed aspects contribute to the advancement of knowledge in GCF science.

Brief Summary

This study is a pilot, open-label, monocentric study consisting of a screening period of 42 days, a treatment and surveillance period of 18 months, a final follow-up visit 43 to 45 days after the end of the treatment period. Patients will be treated with D-sargramostim injections for the treatment of thrombocytopenia and leukopenia and with azacitidine tablets for the treatment of MDS/AML. The dose of D-sargramostim and azacitidine has been established based on previous studies from Maaxtor.

Study Rationale
=================
Lung, prostate, breast, stomach, biliary tract, and pancreas cancers are among the most common cancers in China. [1] In 2020, the number of deaths worldwide caused by lung cancer increased to 20 lakhs, accounting for 18% of all cancer deaths. [2] The main treatment for non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. However, chemotherapy is not effective for some patients, and it does not help prolong their lives. [3,4] At present, there is no established treatment for advanced metastatic pancreatic cancer. [5] The existing treatment is only palliative and can only slow down the growth of the cancer and ease the pain caused by the cancer. [5-7] This is why there is an urgent need to develop new treatments. 
In recent years, scientists have made significant advances in the field of immunotherapy, a type of therapy that stimulates the immune system to fight cancer cells. [8,9] This type of therapy uses specific agents to target and destroy cancer cells, thus reducing the side effects associated with traditional chemotherapies. [8-10] Previous studies from our group have shown that these types of drugs show promising results in the treatment of other types of cancer. [11,12] Therefore, we designed this Phase I clinical trial to study the safety and effectiveness of immunotherapy drugs in treating lung, prostate, breast, stomach, biliary tract, and pancreatic cancers. 
The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of immunotherapy drugs in treating lung, prostate, breast, stomach, biliary tract, and pancreatic cancers. The secondary objective of the study is to evaluate the pharmacokinetics of immunotherapy drugs in treating lung, prostate, breast, stomach, biliary

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to demonstrate the safety and feasibility of using a radiofrequency (RF) ablation system to treat primary hypertension, with a secondary goal of improving blood pressure in subjects who have not achieved their target blood pressure with standard medical therapy.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The investigator will treat the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) using the Celsius RFA-62 system and treat up to 2 additional target blood pressure sites that have not previously been treated using an RFA catheter to improve systolic blood pressure as assessed by the change before and after 3-months post-RFA when compared to the same parameter on the placebo group. Background: The majority (96%) of patients with eczema in China/South‐East Asia have atopic dermatitis (AD), compared with 21% of patients with eczema in Western populations. The severity of AD is correlated with the childs growth and development. Thus, children with AD should start the treatment as early as possible to avoid permanent effects. Interleukin (IL)‐4 and IL‐5 are elevated in patients with AD, and omalizumab (Xolair) has been shown to reduce AD symptoms and improve AD pathology. Omalizumab is not approved in children in Thailand, but it is a cost‐effective biologic and can be used to treat adult patients. We aimed to evaluate the efficacy of omalizumab in children with AD in clinical practice in Thailand. Methods: We included 48 patients who had received omalizumab from March, 2019, to August, 2021, in three hospitals in Thailand. Patients aged under 15 years were required to have a confirmed diagnosis of atopic disease (defined according to the Thai guidelines for AD13). Patients were treated with a fixed dose of omalizumab (150·4 mg/2 mg/kg) subcutaneously every 4 weeks. AD severity and quality of life were evaluated by parent‐reported score, Eczema Area and Severity Index (EASI) score, and the parent‐reported dermatology life quality index (DLQI) score before and after treatment according

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of a combination of active and passive exercises on the strength of knee flexors and extensors, as well as on the functional capacity and balance of the lower limbs in patients who have undergone partial meniscectomy.MATERIALS AND METHODS: Twenty patients (14 women, 6 men) who underwent a partial meniscectomy were evaluated. Ten of them were treated with exercises before surgery and 10 of them were treated with exercises after surgery. The main parameter was the strength of the knee flexors and extensors and these were assessed using an isodynamic dynamometer (during the operation, 6 weeks after surgery, the week after discharge, 45 days after surgery and at the end of treatment). The functional capacity and balance of the knee were evaluated using the knee proprioception test and the step test, and were assessed at the initial consultation, 6 weeks and 45 days after surgery.RESULTS: The isometric strength of the extensors was significantly higher in the active exercise group in the immediate postoperative period (p<0.05), and this increase was maintained during the follow‐up. The isometric strength of flexors did not increase significantly with exercises, except for the isometric contraction during flexion when the knee was passively extended. The isokinetic strength of knee flexors and extensors, step test and knee proprioception test did not show a significant increase with exercises.CONCLUSION: It is not possible to establish whether specific exercises, applied pre and postoperatively, were more effective in improving the strength of knee flexors and extensors than the exercises applied only postoperatively, due to the low number of patients included in our study.

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To determine the most effective method of treating the postoperative pruritus after the use of propofol as an anesthetic.METHODS: A prospective, randomized, double blind clinical study of 68 patients undergoing plastic surgery involving general anesthesia was performed. Patients in group A received a single intravenous administration of clonidine 5 microg/kg, 5 min after propofol. Those in group B were treated with a single dose of benzodiazepine 0.05 mg/kg, 10 min before the administration of propofol. The pruritus intensity in each group was assessed using a visual analogue scale (VAS), which was applied from 0 to 10.RESULTS: Thirty‐four patients received clonidine treatment and 34 received benzodiazepine treatment. The mean VAS scores were 5.9+/‐2.2 and 3.3+/‐1.6, respectively. In group B, the average pruritus score was found to be lower when compared with the score of group A (p<0.001) after 120 min of operation.CONCLUSIONS: The administration of clonidine in patients receiving general anesthesia using propofol is not effective in the treatment of postoperative pruritus.

Abstract:
Background The prevalence of tooth avulsion among adults is around 7%, with dental damage being one of the most common injuries related to sports and accidents. The management of tooth avulsion includes a series of interventions, one of the most important being the application of cold storage to the avulsed tooth before replantation. However, the experience of patients undergoing replacement of an avulsed tooth is often characterized by anxiety and discomfort. This study aimed to evaluate the effects of virtual reality (VR) technology on anxiety levels, pain perception, and blood pressure in patients undergoing replantation of an avulsed tooth after cold storage. Methods A randomized controlled trial was conducted and divided participants into a control group (n = 66) who received conventional dental avulsion treatment, and an experimental group (n = 76) who received the same treatment but also received VR technology during the procedure. The State‐Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) was administered to assess anxiety levels before the procedure and immediately after the avulsion. The Visual Analog Scale (VAS) was used to measure pain perception, and blood pressure was also measured using a blood pressure monitor. Results Sixty‐five participants were analyzed, with 39 in the control group and 26 in the experimental group. The VR intervention group reported significantly lower anxiety levels compared to the control group (p < 0.05). No significant differences were observed in pain perception and blood pressure levels between the two groups (p > 0.05). Conclusion The use of VR technology during dental avulsion is effective in reducing anxiety levels in patients. VR can be used as a distracting and relaxing aid in the dental practice, reducing the stress and discomfort experienced by patients while also improving their compliance and satisfaction.

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To evaluate and compare the in vivo clinical effects of two pulp capping techniques on deep carious lesions in primary molars.METHODS: A total of 36 primary teeth with deep caries of young children were randomly divided into 2 groups; one was capped with the mineral trioxide aggregate (MTA) as the base (MTA Group) and the other with the calcium hydroxide, calcium oxide and F2 as the base, and subsequently capped with the sodium silicate‐calcium hydroxide mixture (SS‐CH Group). Clinical and radiographic parameters were recorded at baseline, postoperative 3, 6, 9, and 18 months.RESULTS: There were no significant differences in the clinical signs, symptoms, and indications of radiographic progress during the 18‐month follow‐up period between the 2 groups. The incidence of clinical success and success rate at 18 months were 61.9% and 94.57% in the SS‐CH Group and 47.7% and 91.74% in the MTA Group, respectively, with statistical significance (P<0.05).CONCLUSION: For caries treatment in young primary molars with deep caries, the SS‐CH technique performed similarly to the MTA technique. The former technique is an alternative to the classic MTA technique, showing good clinical performance.

Compression Socks in Peripheral Artery Disease

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Aim: To assess changes in quality of life, mobility and walking capacity measures between a standard of care comparator group and compression socks treatment group using a cross-over design in subjects with peripheral artery disease over a 6 week period. Hypothesis: It is not known whether ankle bandages and/or compression socks provide measurable clinical benefits to individuals with peripheral artery disease. The purpose of the study is to determine if they do. If a benefit can be shown, those participants who are not currently fit with bandages or compression socks will be offered a trial, and if the treatment group show benefits, they will switch to socks.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Participants with documented peripheral arterial disease will be included in the study. Those who elect to participate will have their walking distance measured by a 6 minute walking test at baseline. Those who choose to participate in the study but are not already fit with compression socks or intermittent pneumatic compressive devices will be randomly chosen to receive one intervention after the baseline measures are recorded. The patient will be fit with either compression socks or ankle bandages at one of the study visits and will be instructed to wear these devices for 8 hours a day for 24 days. After 8 hours of daily use, they will come in for assessment by the PI who will conduct the initial physical exam and a 6 minute walk test. They will then continue wear them for an additional 6 days. On day 8, they will come in again for a repeat physical exam and test. If they have no known intolerance or difficulty during the first 24 days of wear, they will then switch to the alternate intervention and wear this for 24 days with the same testing

Abstract:
INTRODUCTION: Childhood obesity is a global health problem. Treatments that target parental feeding practices may help, but little evidence is available about whether food motivation predicts treatment outcomes. STUDY DESIGN: This secondary analysis uses cross‐sectional and prospective data from parents of children aged 3‐16 y. Parents (N = 541) rated children's excessive eating in the absence of hunger from 1 to 5 (Hunger Rating Scale). Children's relative reinforcing value of food was determined using the Computerized Ratings of Preference for food. Children underwent anthropometric assessment. RESULTS: Higher hunger ratings were associated with greater relative reinforcing value of food when parent and child were both female. CONCLUSION: Females' parenting beliefs about hunger and satiation may affect their child's relative reinforcing value of food. Further research is warranted to identify underlying mechanisms. 

Methods
We recruited overweight/obese children and their parents between August 2013 and November 2016 from two community‐based clinics (Sydney, Australia) and two private practices (Sydney and Canberra, Australia). Participants' age, sex, ethnicity, and weight status (age‐ and sex‐based z-scores) were recorded. Children's relative reinforcing value of food was determined using the 36‐item computerized Ratings of Preference for Food (RPF). This task is a measure of value‐based processing that is derived from behavioral economics. During the RPF, children view photos of foods and drink and state their preference by pressing a corresponding button. The value of each food is based on its reinforcement rate in a preceding taste learning task. The amount of money earned by correct responses was also assessed for the RPF. The aim of this paper was to investigate the differences between the outcomes of the patients who received rectal indomethacin treatment as compared with conservative treatment of postpartum patients with urinary retention due to pain and spasm of the bladder. Methods: A total of thirty patients with urinary retention after cesarean section were randomly assigned to two groups; a group for conservative treatment and a group for rectal indomethacin treatment group. Results: The duration of first voiding, number of re‐catheterizations and the time to the first voiding were compared in the two groups. Results: The patients who received rectal indomethacin treatment needed less time to first voiding. Conclusions: Rectal indomethacin appears to be more effective in patients to void after cesarean section.

Abstract:
The aim of the study was to investigate whether and how 3D printing may affect treatment outcomes, especially patient satisfaction in a fractured maxillary anterior tooth. Eighteen patients with a fractured maxillary anterior tooth were included in this study in the clinical trial. Patients were randomly assigned into two groups. There were nine patients in the 3D‐Printed group, and nine patients in the Conventional group. The fractured segment was scanned with the cone‐beam computed tomography scans, subsequently, a 3D‐printed prosthesis and conventional prosthesis were designed based on the digital model respectively. Both groups have a 2‐year follow‐up. Treatment outcomes including post‐operative pain and patient satisfaction were recorded. The patient satisfaction scores were analysed to check the difference between the two groups. The 3D‐printed group did not show a statistical significant difference at the 2‐year follow‐up (15.60 ± 6.15). One year after the operation, the conventional group showed higher pain scores and poorer patient satisfaction scores at the 2‐year follow‐up (9.30 ± 6.10) . When using 3D modelling of the fractured tooth fragments the patient satisfaction scores were similar to those observed when using conventional technology, and there is no significant difference in the patient satisfaction scores between the two groups. However, the conventional group showed worse treatment outcomes at the end of the 2‐year study, so it will take much more time and effort for conventional technology to catch up with 3D technology.

Objective
The aim of this study is to examine whether and how 3D printing could influence the treatment outcomes of patients. The primary assessment in this study is patient satisfaction and pain scores, and the follow‐up time after the study was 2 years.

Abstract:
During the past two decades, multiple randomized controlled trials have shown that the use of educational booklets or structured communication interventions can improve patient knowledge and improve adherence to medication and health behaviors. However, there are no data on whether they improve patient outcomes. To test this hypothesis, our group initiated a pilot study to determine whether an educational intervention would reduce cardiovascular risk factors in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Sixty‐two patients with RA were randomized to an experimental or control group. Those in the experimental group received an educational booklet and one consultation with a nurse practitioner. Those in the control group received conventional care. The primary outcome measure was the change in serum cholesterol level before and after the intervention. Secondary outcome measures were the change in serum triglyceride levels, HDL cholesterol levels, LDL cholesterol levels, and noncigarette smoking status. After an average of 4.1 months, no significant changes in cardiovascular risk factors were observed between the two groups. The results demonstrated that the one‐time, paper‐based intervention was not effective in improving serum cholesterol level in the experimental group in patients with RA.

Abstract:
Introduction: Pressure ulcers (PUs) are a common and severe problem in clinical settings. Several studies have evaluated the effectiveness of prolotherapy in treating pressure ulcers in various areas, but the treatment period, solution type, and measurement methods have varied. The effect of prolotherapy on the treatment and prevention of heel and sacrum pressure ulcers was evaluated. Methods: A total of 72 patients who visited the physical medicine and rehabilitation clinics of the participating hospitals with sacrum or heel pressure ulcers were selected for treatment. Eligible patients were randomly assigned to the prolotherapy group (n=37) and the control group (n=35). Patients in the prolotherapy group received prolotherapy treatment with 15% dextrose (1.5 mL/kg). The control group received 5 mL of sterile water per gram of body weight. The treatment period was 2 weeks. Treatment efficacy and the frequency of adverse reactions were compared between groups at baseline and at 1, 2, and 3 weeks. Results: Both groups showed a significant improvement in pain, ulcer area, and ulcer depth as the treatment progressed (P=0.001, 0.001, 0.001). There were significantly fewer improvements in patients assigned to the prolotherapy group compared to the control group (P=0.024, 0.031, 0.034). There was no significant difference in patient satisfaction between groups (P=0.906). Conclusion: Prolotherapy significantly improved pain, ulcer area, and depth, but not wound healing, in patients with sacrum and heel pressure ulcers. There was also no difference in patient satisfaction between groups. However, there were fewer adverse events in the control group than in the prolotherapy group.

Introduction:
Patients with cancer, heart attacks, stroke, and other chronic conditions often have family members who provide care and support. Caregivers, also known as primary caregivers, are usually a spouse, partner, family member, or friend who has direct contact and provides emotional and practical care to the patient. They play a critical role in improving or sustaining the quality of life of the patient. The Covid‑19 pandemic has made it increasingly difficult for caregivers to care for their loved one. Recent data show that over 35% of patients require hospitalization due to Covid‑19 related complications. Many have to care for their loved one at home, which can be an overwhelming experience.  
Primary caregivers perform essential functions such as giving medication, checking blood pressure and oxygen levels, cleaning wounds, coordinating care, etc. They also provide emotional support, company, and love to the patient. Taking care of a terminally ill patient at home can be more challenging than professional care in a hospital setting. It can lead to physical and emotional exhaustion, anxiety, depression, and other mental health issues. Caregivers may also develop health issues due to lack of sleep, nutrition, exercise, and social interaction.  
The study aims to evaluate the effect of a psychoeducational intervention program delivered by health care professionals to adult family caregivers with a terminally ill patient at home during the Covid‑19 pandemic. The program will be based on the World Health Organizations (WHO) Human Caring Model. The program is designed to support caregivers emotionally and physically, enhance their self-efficacy, and promote their overall well-being. The program will include sessions on stress management, coping strategies, symptom management, self-care, healthy lifestyle, and communication skills. Caregivers will be evaluated before and after the intervention using validated questionnaires to assess their attitudes toward caring, well-being, anxiety, depression, hope, meaning of life, and burden of care.

I would suggest considering the following outcome measures:
1. Auditory brainstem response (ABR) intensity: This measure provides objective information about the integrity of the auditory pathway from the ear to the brainstem. It can help monitor the progression of hearing loss in pediatric participants with OTOF, GJB2, or GJB2/GJB6 mutations. We can measure ABR intensity at different time points throughout the study, such as annually for 4 years.

Another important measure is otoacoustic emission (OAEs) amplitudes. OAEs are a non-invasive measure of cochlear function and can provide information about the health of the outer hair cells in the cochlea. Monitoring OAEs amplitudes can help assess the structural integrity of the cochlea and detect early signs of cochlear dysfunction in pediatric participants with gene-related hearing loss. We can also measure OAEs amplitudes annually for 4 years.

Yes, we should include pure tone intensity thresholds as an outcome measure. This measure assesses the softest sound that a participant can hear at different frequencies. It's crucial for evaluating the degree and configuration of hearing loss and tracking changes in hearing sensitivity over time in pediatric participants with OTOF, GJB2, or GJB2/GJB6 mutations. We can measure pure tone intensity thresholds annually for 4 years as well.

The last outcome measure I would recommend is speech detection and perception thresholds. This measure evaluates the ability of participants to detect and perceive speech sounds at different intensity levels. It's important for understanding the impact of gene-related hearing loss on speech understanding and communication abilities in pediatric participants. We can assess speech detection and perception thresholds annually for 4 years.

For secondary outcome measures, I suggest focusing on auditory skills and speech perception over time. We can include measures such as open- and closed-set task phoneme accuracy and word comprehension, early speech perception (ESP), pediatric speech intelligibility (PSI) test, and auditory skills checklist (ASC). These measures will provide insights into the development of auditory skills and speech perception abilities in pediatric participants with gene-related hearing loss. We can assess these measures annually for 4 years as well.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Achievement of complete responses to radiation in patients with pelvic sarcoma remains a challenge, and local recurrence may preclude salvage treatment. A common feature of sarcomas is high levels of VEGF, and the VEGF pathway thus may serve as a potential therapeutic target. Tumor hypoxia promotes angiogenesis within tumors, and hypoxic treatment has the potential to improve the oxygenation of the tumor and tumor vascularity, thus increasing response to treatment. Carbon monoxide (CO) is an endogenous ligand for the DNA repair protein, EPHX2, and its treatment may lead to hypoxia-induced EPHX2-mediated tumor cell apoptosis. We hypothesize that hypoxia-inducible EPHX2-mediated response to carbon monoxide treatment can be enhanced in patients with sarcoma, thereby improving the sensitivity of tumors to radiation therapy.

Comparing two different doses of a drug under investigation can be challenging. Researchers may develop a dosing schedule where one treatment is given on a particular day of the week and the other is given on another day of the week. This can help to ensure that the effects of the drug are compared under similar conditions and that any differences in response are attributable to the different doses of the drug. Additionally, it can be easier for participants to comply with a dosing schedule that is consistent with their normal routine. Overall, a dosing schedule can improve the efficacy and tolerability of a new drug and reduce the risk of adverse events.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The study hypothesis is that if a spinal cord stimulation is used with awake prone and/or sitting positions, it is feasible to reduce the overall sedation use and sedation level during intubation, if it is compared with traditional anaesthesia induction. The study aims to evaluate whether spinal cord stimulation reduces the use of sedative drugs during endotracheal intubation in general surgery. Secondary aims of the study are to evaluate if spinal cord stimulation reduces overall duration of ventilation and length of patient hospital stay, compared to traditional anaesthesia induction in general surgery patients. A further aim is to provide information on the level of sedation during the procedure.

Using ultrasound to measure diaphragm thickness will provide valuable information on the preservation of diaphragm function. This will help us assess the efficacy of the intervention in preventing ventilator-induced diaphragm dysfunction.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Ventilator‐induced diaphragm dysfunction (VIDD) is a common complication of mechanical ventilation. Diaphragm thickness is a reliable ultrasound measure of muscle mass and function, and it has been used as a predictor of clinical outcomes in critical care. This study aimed to evaluate the effect of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on diaphragm thickness in critically ill patients mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. METHODS: A prospective, randomized, controlled trial was conducted in an intensive care unit. Patients were randomly assigned to either an NMES group or a control group. In the NMES group, NMES was applied for 30 minutes every day, while in the control group, routine care was provided. Diaphragm thickness was measured on the fifth day of mechanical ventilation using ultrasound. RESULTS: Forty‐two patients were enrolled in the study, with 21 patients in each group. In the NMES group, there was a significant increase in diaphragm thickness compared to the baseline value (P < 0.001), while in the control group, there was no significant change in diaphragm thickness (P = 0.876). Compared to the control group, the NMES group showed a significant increase in diaphragm thickness (P < 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: Our study found that NMES can significantly increase diaphragm thickness in critically ill patients mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. However, further studies are needed to determine the impact of NMES on clinical outcomes, such as duration of mechanical ventilation, hospital length of stay, and mortality rate.

Description

This is a phase 1b, open-label, single center, adaptive, dose ranging, safety and efficacy study in patients with advanced solid tumors who have progressed on standard approved treatments and failed multiple lines of therapy for their disease. Up to 60 patients (10 for phase I, 12 for phase II) will receive different doses of the TKI083-B drug every 21 days for 6 cycles. This study utilizes an adaptive dose-finding design with the goal of establishing a recommended Phase II dose (RP2D) and establishing a dose limiting toxicity (DLT) rate (25%). The first phase of the study is Phase 1 in which 10 patients, in 3 cohorts will receive the highest dose (450 mg BID), the intermediate dose (225 mg BID) and the lowest dose (150 mg BID) of the investigational agent. During the first phase of the study, up to 5 patients will be treated in each cohort and each cohort will be evaluated individually for safety and efficacy. Based on the safety and preliminary anti-tumor activity during the first phase, the data derived from patients will be reviewed by the Sponsor to determine whether there are sufficient data to determine the RP2D and an expansion cohort(s) for Phase II (if the study ends as an efficacy study).   If the data does not meet the criteria for Phase I continuation, then a DLT rate may be calculated and the study may proceed to determine the RP2D for Phase II. The study will then enter Phase 2 to evaluate the efficacy of TKI083-B for safety and tolerability and for efficacy assessments in up to 50 patients, including patients from Phase I. Abstract:
Thoracic aortic aneurysm and dissection (TAAD) are severe acute and chronic cardiac conditions, often caused by inherited or acquired connective tissue disorders or genetic mutations. The prevalence of TAA and TAD is rising worldwide with the aging population. The pathogenesis of TAA and TAD is multifactorial, involving a variety of pathways. In recent years, increasing evidence has indicated that non‐coding RNAs, including microRNAs (miRNAs) and long non‐coding RNAs (lncRNAs), can regulate the progression of TAA and TAD by modulating mRNA translation and protein secretion. This review summarizes the current knowledge of lncRNAs and miRNAs that regulate TAA and TAD progression by targeting genes related to vascular remodeling, cell‐cycle progression, oxidative stress and inflammation, and matrix metalloproteinase activity. TAA and TAD are often characterized by abnormal TGF‐β signaling, fibrosis, and inflammation. Recently, studies have shown that exosome‐mediated transfer of lncRNAs and miRNAs among vascular cells is crucial in mediating these processes. Exosomes can act as carriers of lncRNAs and miRNAs to facilitate their transfer between different vascular cells, promoting TAA and TAD progression. For example, exosome‐miR‐193a‐5p is involved in regulating matrix metalloproteinase activity to promote vascular remodeling during TAA development. In conclusion, these lncRNAs and miRNAs may serve as novel biomarkers and therapeutic targets for the diagnosis and treatment of TAA and TAD. 2016 The Authors. 2018 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. Copyright

Introduction
The main purpose of this study is to explore the relationship between the clinical efficacy of ningchang Jiawei Xiaoqing formula combined with the conventional Western medical treatment of insomnia in perimenopause  and the immune function indexes of insomnia patients in menopause. To explore the mechanism of this combination regimen in improving the clinical symptoms of insomnia in perimenopause and the level of immune function
1.1 Method Statement
Randomized: Patients were randomly assigned to two groups, namely, the control group and the research group.
Random method: This study adopted simple randomization; that is, through the random number table, the patients were randomly assigned to two groups: each group had the same number of patients, and the two groups of patients were similar. The random number table is used to divide the table into four parts with the same number of patients in the two groups. The random number table produced by the computer is used as the basis for grouping, namely, each part is regarded as a unit, and the random number table is selected by opening it.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this research study is to determine whether an educational tool can help increase the identification, assessment, and diagnosis of chronic pelvic pain.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a randomized two-arm study at the University of Pennsylvania comparing the efficacy of educational videos vs. usual care in increasing clinician knowledge of chronic pelvic pain. The primary study outcome measures will include: 1) Knowledge of the prevalence of chronic pelvic pain, 2) Knowledge and familiarity with diagnostic approaches for chronic pelvic pain, and, 3) Knowledge of chronic pelvic pain management. Secondary endpoints of the study will include: 1) Proportion patients receiving the new approach of chronic pelvic pain management; 2) Evaluation of the satisfaction with the diagnostic approaches for chronic pelvic pain, and 3) Evaluation of chronic pelvic pain outcomes (e.g., sexual function, and quality of life). The investigators are collaborating with the Sexual Medicine department of the University of Pennsylvania and the Office of Research and Education in the University of Pennsylvania Health System to identify patients with chronic pelvic pain, who are being seen by gynecologists, urologists, and primary care providers. Eligible patients will be asked to complete the survey regarding their knowledge about the management of chronic pelvic pain. Patients who consent to be part of this project will be randomized into 2 parallel groups and each will be given a different educational tool (videos).

Official Title

Impact of a Brief Patient Empowerment Tool on Patient Education for the Management of Chronic Pelvic Pain
