Abstract:
We assess the effectiveness of a one‐week inpatient group program in the treatment of adult patients with a high school‐level education or below with chronic, treatment‐resistant schizophrenia spectrum disorders. 124 clients were randomly assigned to either the experimental or a treatment‐as‐usual (TAU) group. The experimental group received the 2‐hour weekly therapeutic activity program for one week, focusing on social activity and skill development. The TAU group remained on their previously prescribed treatment programs. Patients were assessed at baseline, 5‐weeks post‐treatment and at 6‐months post‐treatment. At 5‐weeks post‐treatment, the experimental group had significantly better improvements (vs. the control group) in negative symptoms of schizophrenia (P=0.038) and social function (P=0.016). No differences were observed regarding changes in other measures in the short‐term. At six‐months post‐treatment, changes on all measures remained significant. The study demonstrates the effectiveness of the 2‐hour weekly group therapeutic activity program in improving the negative symptoms and social functioning in adult patients with a high school level education or below with chronic, treatment‐resistant schizophrenia spectrum disorders.

BACKGROUND
Brief summary in scientific language
=================
Pain is a complex phenomenon that affects different body regions and a wide range of etiologies. It can be caused by muscular complaints, acute or chronic inflammations, fibromyalgia or neuropathy, and can also be caused by psychogenic pain. Psychogenic pain is a pain that has psychological or psychophysical origins. Due to a lack of objective findings and a lack of a clear etiology in terms of the anatomic cause, the existence of the psychogenic pain is controversial and is often rejected. However, it can be found on the one hand in chronic pain patients with an organic cause of the pain, on the other hand also in pain patients without a corresponding organic cause.

This is due to the fact that psychological factors can have a negative effect on the course of the disease as well as on the degree of pain. There are numerous studies in which patients were assigned to a condition with pain and a condition with no pain depending on their psychological burden and in which there was even a higher degree of pain (pain report) in the condition with psychological burden.
In this context, there is increasing mention of a "chronic pain stress experience", where patients' psychosocial stress due to pain leads to a shift towards pain-negative beliefs, which can then become maladaptive and lead to the development of central sensitization. Central sensitization means that patients perceive pain in unstimulated regions and are more sensitive to sensory stimulation than non-pain patients. According to this, the negative consequences of the pain stress experience in our patients lead to a reinforcement of the pain signals in the brain areas and thus worsen the pain symptoms. This pain stress experience should be understood as a maladaptive behavioral pattern, but its assessment is a great challenge, since a multivariate examination and a continuous feedback in the therapy are necessary.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine if physical exercise after colorectal surgery influences health-related quality of life and physical function. Specifically, this study will examine whether the addition of physical exercise during the first 6 weeks of recovery from surgery increases patients' physical function and improves their quality of life in the short-term.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Patients will be recruited from The Ottawa Hospital - General Campus. As soon as surgeons identify a patient eligible for the study, a consent form will be handed to them. If the patient agrees to participate, he/she will complete a questionnaire and the surgeon will decide which of the two groups (exercise vs. control) the patients will be allocated to. Randomization is by sealed envelope. Participants in both groups will be requested to provide their blood, sputum (fluid secretion in the respiratory system) and stool samples at specific intervals for microbiome analyses; the latter will also undergo a gastroenterology consultation, where blood work and a lower endoscopy will take place. Patients in the exercise group will receive an exercise booklet with instructions on doing physical exercise. The main exercise is brisk walking for 20 minutes, which could be divided into two 10-min sessions on weekdays. Patients will be recommended to do this exercise at least 6 days a week. They will receive regular follow-up phone calls from a research nurse to ensure that patients are able to perform the exercise as required and report any adverse effects. Both groups of patients will be followed up by study investigators on the 6th and 12th weeks after being discharged from hospital. Follow-up questionnaires and routine medical assessments will be performed as per study protocol. These include blood, sputum and stool tests. 

Official Title
-----------------
The Effect of Physical Exercise on Health-Related Quality of Life/Patient-Reported Outcomes After Colorectal Surgery: a Prospective Randomized Clinical Trial

Conditions
-----------------
Quality of Life, Patient-Report

Background: Children with intellectual disabilities experience increased challenges in physical activity participation. This is often due to the children’s reduced motor competence. Motor competence refers to an individual’s ability to engage in safe and effective movement which allows for the performance of movement skills. Limited research exists surrounding the effects of interventions to improve children’s motor competence in a school‐based setting. Objectives: This study presents the protocol of a research project which aims to describe the impacts of a teacher‐delivered physical literacy intervention program for primary school children with intellectual disabilities. The primary objective will be to determine the effects of the physical literacy intervention on the physical fitness (e.g., strength, flexibility, endurance) of children with intellectual disabilities who attend mainstream government education in New South Wales, Australia. Design: A pre‐post experimental design using mixed methodology will be utilised which includes both a randomised control trial (RCT) and qualitative study. Participants (n=127) will be randomly allocated to the experimental and control groups. The intervention group will participate in a teacher‐delivered physical literacy intervention program for 16 weeks, and the effects on children’s physical fitness will be determined. Children will undergo testing prior to the intervention (i.e., baseline), post intervention 8 weeks later and post intervention at approximately 16 weeks. Outcomes will be determined through physical fitness testing (e.g., strength, flexibility, endurance) for each child. The qualitative data will consist of semi‐structured interviews with three teachers. Key personnel involved will include: (i) one researcher who will deliver the intervention; (ii) two researchers who will conduct the data analysis, and (iii) one research team member who will be responsible for overall study implementation. ### Aim

The objective of this study is to evaluate the clinical outcomes of a new type of intramedullary reaming device in the treatment of distal femoral fractures. The new device is a modified Reamer and Impacter, designed for minimally invasive intramedullary reaming during distal femoral fracture repair. It is intended to reduce the operation time and allow a more accurate placement of the intramedullary nail. The study will compare the clinical outcomes of patients treated with the new device with those treated with a traditional reaming device.


Primary objectives of the study: The primary objectives of the study are to evaluate the effect of the new device on:
-operation time
-accuracy of the placement of the intramedullary nail
-patient positioning accuracy
-length of hospital stay
-rate of complications

Secondary objectives of the study: The secondary objectives of the study are to evaluate the effect of the new device on:
-functional outcome
-patient satisfaction
-cost of the procedure
-incidence of infection
-incidence of reoperation

Study design
-----------------
This is a non-randomized controlled trial with a historical control group. Patients will be treated with the new device, and their clinical outcomes will be compared with a historical control group of patients who were treated with a traditional reaming device.
Data collection and analysis will follow the CONSORT 2010 guidelines for reporting patient-blinded, randomized controlled trials. Data will be analyzed using standard statistical methods. Results will be presented as mean and standard deviation, and statistical significance will be determined using Student's t-test and Chi-square test. Patient recruitment and follow-up

Nasal steroids use is safe, and could be an effective treatment for seasonal allergic rhinitis (SAR). The objective of this study was to determine the efficacy of a nasal steroid, triamcinolone 44 µg, in preventing the development of SAR. This study is the first, double blind, placebo-controlled, randomized study to analyze the role of pretreatment with topical nasal steroids in the prevention of the development of SAR. The study consists of two phases: screening and treatment. The first phase is carried out during the winter season to confirm that the patient has seasonal allergy. The second phase starts 8-10 days after confirmation and continues to the end of the pollen season (May-June 2007 in Catalonia, Spain). Eligibility criteria include patients between 5 and 40 years of age with the diagnosis of seasonal allergic rhinitis, and with a history of SAR in the preceding three years.

Exclusion criteria include: nasal polyposis or concha bullosa, acute rhinusitis, recent sinus surgery, immunodepression, steroid use, contraindications to steroid treatment, and pregnancy or lactation. Patients will receive either 240 µg of triamcinolone acetonide by nasal spray or a placebo daily. Both nasal sprays are identical in appearance, presentation, packaging and administration (Flixonase Apo 240 µg and Flixonase Placebo 240 µg, LABORATORIOS FERRO, Barcelona, Spain). The efficacy and safety evaluation criteria are based on the consensus statement of the Group for Research and Assessment of Allergies and Rhinoconjunctivitis (Gesraraq) criteria

Design In the intervention group, an intervention program will be conducted for the children 9-13 years old, according to the following parameters:: Frequency: once per week; Duration: 8 weeks; Modality: In-person and online; Duration of classes: 60 minutes. In the intervention group, the theoretical-practical content of the classes will correspond to a total of 24 hours of direct contact with the children. There will be two stages of intervention:

In the first stage, 10-13-year-old children will receive a total of 12 hours of theoretical and practical content. The children will participate together with the parents in activities designed for the intervention. The content of the activities in the first stage is divided into three parts: Physical fitness and health; Physical activity and health, and Adolescence, sports, physical activity and health. Partnership with parents: There will be a space for questions and answers about the content of the classes and the practices presented.

The second stage of the intervention will consist of the application of a 12-hour theoretical-practical content module focused on team sports practice. This stage will be based on the training of 13-year-old children who play five-a-side football. Parents of 13-year-old children will not participate in this stage. All children included in the study will receive a physical activity booklet after participating in all stages of the intervention.
Objective The study has a qualitative dimension, through the collection of field notes. The purpose is to analyze the content that guided the intervention in the first stage.

1. Secondary Objectives 
The secondary objectives of this study are to assess the impact of the intervention on body composition (measured by dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA)). 

2. Secondary Endpoints 
The secondary endpoints of this study are: 

* Change in fasting serum adiponectin at baseline and 12 months. 
* Change in fasting serum leptin at baseline and 12 months. 
* Change in fasting serum resistin at baseline and 12 months. 
* Change in fasting serum interleukin-6 at baseline and 12 months. 
* Change in fasting plasma triiodothyronine (T3) at baseline and 12 months. 
* Change in C-reactive protein at baseline and 12 months. 
* Change in TLC at baseline and 12 months. 

3. Hypothesis(es) 
The hypothesis(s) for this study is that following a low-calorie diet and resistance exercise training intervention, subjects will experience significant reductions in adiposity, markers of adiposity and lipolysis, systemic inflammation, and triiodothyronine levels, and there will be no significant effects on other variables. 

4. Method(s) to be used to evaluate whether this specific aim is achieved 
The specific aim will be evaluated by comparing changes in body composition, markers of adiposity and lipolysis, systemic inflammation, and triiodothyronine levels at baseline and 12 months. 

5. Method(s) to be used to evaluate whether the secondary objectives are achieved 
The secondary objectives will be evaluated by comparing changes in adiponectin, leptin, resistin, and interleukin-6 at baseline and 12 months, and comparing changes in TLC at baseline and 12 months.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this research project is to study the effectiveness of the 'Aging Gracefully' program targeting physical, cognitive and psycho-social health (3Ps) of older adults. The Aging Gracefully program was created by the Institute of Public Health of the University of Ottawa and consists of a 14 weeks weekly exercise program, accompanied by activities for cognitive and psycho-social health, and delivered in groups of between 10 and 12 older adults.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Over the years, it has been demonstrated that exercise training can provide important benefits across the spectrum of domains underlying health as we age - physical, cognitive and psycho-social. These gains include, among others, improved mood, sleep, mental status, and social relationships, as well as the reduction of inflammation, fall risk, and mortality. There is increasing research that suggests that improvements in 1 of the 3 domains may lead to improved function in the other two domains of health, providing evidence for an integrated response to interventions promoting physical, cognitive and psycho-social health over the course of aging. The Aging Gracefully program was created by the Institute of Public Health of the University of Ottawa and consists of a 14-week exercise program, accompanied by activities for cognitive and psycho-social health, and delivered in groups of between 10 and 12 older adults. Participants are supervised every week by two physiotherapists trained in the program. The Aging Gracefully program has been demonstrated to have positive health benefits, and to be well accepted by older adults. The aim of this project is to study the effectiveness of the Aging Gracefully program in improving physical, cognitive and psycho-social health in a population of sedentary older adults living in the community. To do so, a cluster randomized controlled trial will be conducted, wherein 2 groups of 10 to 12 older adults will be put together and randomly assigned to either an experimental group that will receive the Aging Gracefully program or a control group that will be offered regular access to community health and fitness facilities for the same period. Participants will be assessed at baseline, at the end of the 14-week intervention, and after a minimum of 6 months from the end of the intervention. 6. Change of the body image perception: This measure assesses changes in participants' perception of their own body image, providing insights into self-esteem and body satisfaction.
7. Change of the physical activity intention: This measure assesses changes in participants' intentions to engage in physical activity in the future, indicating the sustainability of behavior change.
8. Change of the physical activity psychological need satisfaction according to the Self-Determination Theory at physical education: This measure evaluates changes in participants' satisfaction of psychological needs related to physical education, which is crucial for intrinsic motivation and engagement.
9. Change of the perceived physical self-concept: This measure assesses changes in participants' perceived physical self-concept, which can influence their self-perception and confidence in physical abilities.
10. Change of the sedentary behavior: This measure evaluates changes in sedentary behavior, indicating participants' overall activity patterns and health behaviors.
11. Change of the school satisfaction: This measure assesses changes in participants' satisfaction with school, which can impact their overall well-being and academic engagement.
12. Change of the social identity: This measure evaluates changes in participants' social identity related to physical education or sport, indicating their sense of belonging and motivation.
13. Change of the knowledge related to physical activity and healthy lifestyles: This measure assesses changes in participants' knowledge related to physical activity and healthy lifestyles, indicating the intervention's educational impact.
14. Change of the math fluency calculation: This measure evaluates changes in participants' math fluency calculation skills, providing insights into cognitive abilities beyond physical activity.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Objective The study objective is to assess the safety and efficacy of a combined technique of intermittent self-pressurized nasal airway and high-flow nasal cannula to increase tracheal cannula removal in chronic tracheostomised patients. Design The study investigates the effectiveness and safety of two different rehabilitation techniques among patients with chronic tracheostomy: 1. Standard tracheostomy care and weaning as per standard of care. 2. Standard tracheostomy care plus intermittent nasal pressure and high-flow oxygen therapy via a combined nasal ventilation system The patient can decide him/herself for the method 1 or 2. Method This randomized controlled study included 24 patients. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two experimental groups - standard rehabilitation or rehabilitation with support system plus active expiratory muscle training. Each patient will be followed for a total of one year. During this period, the participants in the standard rehabilitation group will undergo a conventional course of intervention, while for those in the experimental group there will be additional daily training sessions of 30-60 minutes. For patients who are willing to undergo the tracheostomy removal procedure and deemed suitable by the treating physician, the nasal ventilation system will be used during the period of home mechanical ventilation before the tracheal cannula removal procedure. The duration of home mechanical ventilation is determined by the attending physician. The duration of tracheal cannula removal is also determined by the attending physician, based on clinical evaluation.

Let's move on to the recruitment and follow-up plan.

For recruitment, we will identify potential eligible patients undergoing tracheal tube removal in the Swiss Paraplegic Centre Nottwil. We will screen for inclusion and exclusion criteria, and provide them with the necessary information about the study. Patients can provide consent before the first study-related assessment.

For follow-up, patients will undergo in-person assessments at the following time points: 4 days, 1 month, and 3 months post-decannulation. The in-person assessment will include data collection on secondary outcome measures and the collection of physical characteristics.

Primary outcome measures will include physical complications post-decannulation (i.e., occurrence of cough, hoarseness, and ineffective respiration), reintubation rates, rate of recannulation post-decannulation, and death rates for 3 months post-decannulation. We will collect data at different time points: 4 days, 1 month, and 3 months post-decannulation for physical complications and 1 week pre-decannulation and 3 months post-decannulation for reintubation, recannulation, and death rates. Second outcome measures will include types of decannulation-related physical complications (e.g., excessive secretion, altered respiratory frequency, respiratory insufficiency, respiratory infections, neurological symptoms, sleep apnea, intratracheal complications, and tracheostomy-related complications) for 3 months post-decannulation, candidate prognostic factors for physical complications post-decannulation, and patients' perspectives on decannulation outcomes. We will collect data at 1 week pre-decannulation and 3 months post-decannulation for these outcome measures. 

Inclusion criteria for participants:
1. Adult patient> 18 years
2. Tracheostomy treatment for more than 3 weeks
3. Clinical decision to decannulate
4. No clinically significant symptoms
5. Able to communicate effectively
6. Fluent in German, French, Italian or English
7. Provision of written, informed consent
8. Signed agreement by the responsible physician
9. Signed agreement by the responsible nursing staff
10. Signed agreement by caregiver
11. Signed agreement by the responsible patient
12. Availability of a caregiver who assists the patient during the decannulation process

Exclusion criteria for participants: 
1. No clinically significant symptoms
2. No tracheal mucus
3. No tracheal patency
4. Clinical decision to keep the tracheostomy cannula
5. No provision of informed consent as patients with decisional incapacity or patients who are unable to speak, understand, or read the Swiss German language
6. Significantly abnormal laboratory or other test results
7. Severe co-morbidities

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), associated with obesity, metabolic syndrome, and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), develops in the liver and causes abnormally high levels of lipids. NAFLD is one of the leading causes of death in the United States. Obesity, dietary modifications, and physical activity are recommended as initial treatments. In the event that these interventions fail, we believe that bariatric surgery may be a treatment option. Because bariatric surgery is invasive, associated with major risks, and potentially accompanied by nutrient deficits, a noninvasive and safe pharmacologic regimen to control weight might be preferable.MATERNALS AND METHODS: This open‐label, nonblinded randomized control trial will evaluate the efficacy of naltrexone, a central appetite suppressant, and metformin, an insulin‐sensitizing agent, in improving steatosis in patients with T2DM and coexisting NAFLD who are overweight or obese (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m2). Participants will have metabolic syndrome, which is currently a main exclusion criterion. These drugs have been shown to reduce body weight in patients with obesity, and metformin may improve NAFLD by improving glycemic control, increasing insulin sensitivity, decreasing inflammatory markers, and modifying factors such as glutamine. Naltrexone‐plus‐metformin therapy would offer both short‐ and long‐term weight reduction effects combined with the advantages of reducing hepatocyte fat accumulation, while also eliminating the risks associated with bariatric surgery. The researchers are interested in determining whether a corticosteroid injection at the tendon-bone attachment site will reduce the pain, improve functionality, and restore patients to work sooner than a peri-articular intra-articular injection. The research team's study involves two different corticosteroid injection locations within the elbow joint that will be employed to manage the symptoms of lateral epicondylitis. Patients will receive either a local corticosteroid injection in the tendon-bone interface (i.e. the origin of the wrist and finger extensor tendons, or a local peri-articular corticosteroid injection at the elbow joint. The research team's study will examine whether one treatment is better than another in patients who have lateral epicondylitis. For comparison, patient ratings of pain and symptoms will be analyzed. The effectiveness of the treatment will be assessed by comparing the patient ratings of recovery and the number of days missed from work in each group of patients. Abstract:
Objectives: The aim of the present study was to determine the prevalence of urinary abnormalities in children with spinal dysraphism (SD) referred to the pediatric neurosurgery clinic. Patients and methods: Ninety children underwent evaluation with ultrasonography, including renal and bladder ultrasonography. All children underwent cystography after administration of phenazopyridine. Patients with SD were divided into two groups (group 1, no neurologic findings; group 2, neurologic findings). Cystometry was performed in the presence of bladder abnormalities in both groups. Results: Ultrasonography demonstrated that 34% of patients had abnormalities in the upper urinary tract. Cystography demonstrated detrusor hypocontractility in 25%, poor bladder compliance in 22.5%, vesicoureteric reflux in 22.5%, and neurogenic bladder in 22.5%. Conclusion: Bladder abnormalities were high and neurogenic bladder was one of the main causes of this condition. Urodynamic studies should be performed in patients with abnormalities in ultrasonography.

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
Excessive alcohol consumption may result in several harmful conditions and diseases. Liver disease or injury caused by alcohol is the leading cause of death and liver transplant in the United States. Alcohol-related fatty liver disease (ARFLD) can develop along the disease continuum from simple steatosis, steatohepatitis (alcoholic hepatitis), fibrosis, cirrhosis.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Excessive alcohol consumption may result in several harmful conditions and diseases. Liver disease or injury caused by alcohol is the leading cause of death and liver transplant in the United States. Alcohol-related fatty liver disease (ARFLD) can develop along the disease continuum from simple steatosis, steatohepatitis (alcoholic hepatitis), fibrosis, cirrhosis. These changes can go unrecognized until the late stages of fibrosis and cirrhosis, when patients present with symptoms of abdominal pain, weakness, malaise, and jaundice. A significant number of individuals develop cirrhosis and complications such as ascites, encephalopathy, and portal hypertension. Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is defined by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual, 5th Edition (DSM-5) as a spectrum of problems related to AUD due to the physical and mental effects of alcohol and the inability to limit use due to strong cravings and dependence. Patients with AUD have a 60% higher mortality rate and a 2.5-fold increased risk of end-stage liver disease than non-alcoholic patients. Although there has been recent interest in exploring the effects of alcohol on the human brain, the use of imaging biomarkers to assess alcohol neurotoxicity has been limited to small sample sizes, with no studies using magnetic resonance spectroscopy imaging (MRSI) to measure the metabolite changes caused by alcohol intoxication that occur in the brain, specifically the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC). Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The purpose of this study was to investigate the effect of a pre‐examination of the oral temperature, the oral hygiene and the diet on the post‐operative oral temperature, the diet and oral health.METHODS: 120 participants of both sexes were assigned to the test (N=60) and control (N=60) groups.RESULT: An increase in the oral temperature (P < 0.05) and the number of teeth with caries (P < 0.05) and the absence of saliva (P < 0.05) were detected in the participants of the test group. At the same time, the duration of the surgical procedure (P = 0.04) was higher in the control group. The occurrence of nausea and vomiting in the recovery period, the consumption of food and drinks in the recovery room, and the need for antibiotic and antimicrobial therapy were lower in the participants of the test group. Participants of the control group were more likely to experience post‐operative nausea.CONCLUSIONS: The pre‐operative examination of the oral temperature, oral health and the diet could reduce the risk of the post‐operative complications after the surgery for breast cancer.

Study Design
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Background: Preconception care is important in optimizing maternal health and pregnancy outcomes. One component of preconception care is sexual health. Sexual health should be a priority for pregnant women as it is a critical aspect of their overall health and well-being. Yet, it remains a sensitive and understudied topic in preconception care. Objective: To examine the impact of a pregnancy-specific sexual education program on the sexual lives of women undergoing prenatal care. Methods: A multi-site, cluster-randomized trial was conducted in 22 OB/GYN offices in California. The intervention group received the sexual health component, and the control received a generic prenatal class. The primary outcome was the Frequency Scale for Vaginal Intercourse score at the 4-week follow-up. This project was IRB approved, and written consent was obtained from all participants. Results: The intervention had no significant effect on sexuality-related outcomes (the Frequency Scale for Vaginal Intercourse, the Cumulative Index of Sexual Function [CISf], and sexual satisfaction). However, the intervention had a positive impact on improving communication with partners regarding sexual satisfaction and pregnancy planning. Conclusions: The pregnancy-specific sexual education program did not significantly change the sexuality-related outcomes of women undergoing prenatal care. However, it positively impacted participants' communication with partners regarding sexual satisfaction and pregnancy planning.

Abstract:
The purpose of this research is to study the effects of the combination of trivalent phosphorus (P3) and trivalent manganese (Mn3) in a new formulation of 5mM (Mn3) and 1mM (P3) in patients with an Alzheimer Disease. Methods: A total of 31 patients with an Alzheimer Disease were enrolled in this clinical trial from January 2017 to December 2021. Patients were divided in two groups: Group A (Mn3) and Group B (Mn3+P3) with 2mM as a placebo. All patients have received a treatment with 1mM P3 and 1mM Mn3 for about 2 months. Results: All patients have completed the cognitive test and physical examination. Cognitive function has been improved in both groups, while there was a better improvement in the group B with Mn3+P3 treatment. The motor function has been improved in all patients. Conclusion: The combination of trivalent phosphorus (P3) and trivalent manganese (Mn3) in a new formulation of 5mM (Mn3) and 1mM (P3) could be effective for improving cognitive function in patients with an Alzheimer Disease. Further studies are needed to confirm these results.

Based on the current design, we are planning to use the log-rank test to compare the overall survival rates (OSR) between the study groups. We will use the Kaplan-Meier method to estimate OSR and corresponding 95% confidence intervals (CIs). We will also assess the hazard ratio (HR) of OSR using Cox proportional hazards regression. We will perform a subgroup analysis to explore potential differences in OSR between patients with different types of tumors or prior therapy. To evaluate immune-related adverse events (AEs), we will summarize the number, severity, and duration of AEs based on the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) v5.0 criteria. We will calculate absolute frequencies and relative frequencies of each type of AE within each treatment group. We will also analyze the relationship between AEs and clinical outcomes. To evaluate disease-free survival (DFS) rates within each treatment group, we will use Kaplan-Meier methods and the log-rank test to compare DFS rates between groups. We will calculate the DFS rate at 2 years. To assess overall survival (OS) rates within each treatment group, we will use Kaplan-Meier methods and the log-rank test to compare OSR between groups. We will calculate the OSR at 5 years. Finally, we will perform sensitivity analysis to assess the impact of different baseline characteristics on treatment response and survival outcomes. Abstract:
A randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, multicenter study was conducted in 298 patients with advanced non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Patients who did not progress after receiving standard platinum‐based induction chemotherapy (three cycles of carboplatin plus paclitaxel every 3 weeks) received topotecan or matching placebo every 4 weeks for up to eight cycles. The primary endpoint, to evaluate survival, was based on overall survival (OS) and time to tumor progression (TTP). After a minimum of 48 weeks (11 cycles), progression occurred in more than 75% of the patients. The median OS and median TTP for all patients were 212 days [95% confidence interval (CI) = 193‐232] and 145 days (139‐154), respectively. No significant differences in median OS or median TTP were observed between the two groups of patients (P = 0.939 and 0.262, respectively). However, the time to response rate and the complete response rate with topotecan were significantly higher than those with placebo (P = 0.000 and 0.005, respectively). The primary endpoint of OS was difficult to evaluate because progression was observed in more than 75% of patients after a minimum follow‐up of only 11 cycles. This observation indicates that the NSCLC treatment protocol used in phase II trials lacks a proper schedule with an induction period after completing three cycles of platinum‐based chemotherapy. The most appropriate schedule for the subsequent chemotherapy regimen should also be considered before the induction chemotherapy, together with the inclusion of a sufficient number of cycles, to evaluate the efficacy in terms of OS.

Study Design
=================
 Study type
=================
Interventional

Condition
=================
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

Intervention
=================
We plan to recruit healthy adults with no active or past respiratory diseases for our study. Subjects will be randomized into two groups: one will receive oral NVP-2203 while the other will receive a placebo. We will give participants a single oral dose of NVP-2203 (or the placebo) at the study start and repeat the dose after 33 days. Blood samples will be collected throughout the study to evaluate the pharmacokinetics of the drug. The participants may also undergo pulmonary function tests, electrocardiograms, and laboratory tests for safety monitoring. 

Pulmonary function tests include spirometry, which measures important parameters such as forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) and forced vital capacity (FVC). These tests can help us understand the drug's respiratory effects and potential impact on lung function. Electrocardiograms will provide us with insights into cardiac safety, and laboratory tests will help us monitor overall safety and tolerability. 

We choose to use oral administration as the route of administration for NVP-2203, as it is user-friendly and convenient. Additionally, it allows for a longer residence time of the drug in the body than inhalation. Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
The central goals of radiation oncology are to preserve organ function while still providing a therapeutic dose of radiation to the cancerous tissue. A technique called volumetric modulated arc therapy (VMAT) allows the radiation dosage received by all normal and targeted organs to be modeled in three dimensions, with a computer controlling the radiation delivery by rotating the gantry around the patient while simultaneously controlling the gantry speed. It aims to improve the safety of the treatment plan by better targeting dose delivery to the cancerous areas. The purpose of this research is to assess the efficacy of VMAT therapy in a sample of patients diagnosed with uveal melanoma. This study involves assessing the progression of the cancer, side effects associated with the treatment, and the patients' overall survival.

Detailed Description
-----------------
There are up to 1,800 people diagnosed with primary uveal melanoma per year. Uveal melanoma is typically treated with radiation because uveal melanomas are highly radiation-responsive tumors, with a very high probability of regression. There is no standard of care regarding the radiation treatment itself, with many treatment plans varying by institution. The goal of this research study is to determine the efficacy of a rotational radiation technique on survival outcomes compared to a conventional radiation treatment plan. Participants will be asked if they would like to participate in this research study, and those who participate will have blood draws, blood and tissue samples taken at the time of enucleation, and be asked to complete surveys throughout the study period. In addition, participants' medical records will be reviewed after their treatment, and then participants will be monitored monthly for the first year, every 3 months for years 2 to 4, and then annually for an additional 10 years. Participants will also receive phone calls monthly for the first year of the study and then annually for the duration of the study.

Official Title
-----------------
Does the Choice of a Rotational vs. a Conventional Radiation Therapy Plan Impact 5-yr Overall Survival in Patients With Primary Uveal Melan

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: A clinical trial was conducted to evaluate repetitive blood brain barrier opening for Alzheimer's disease.METHODS: We recruited 10 patients with mild Alzheimer's disease. A focused ultrasound system was used to cause transient BBB opening, which allowed for the passage of a gadolinium‐based contrast agent into the brain. MRI imaging was used to evaluate the effectiveness of the BBB opening. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) biomarkers were measured to study inflammatory and vascular markers.RESULTS: MR imaging findings after contrast‐enhanced BBB opening revealed no major adverse events directly related to the focused ultrasound procedure. There was a trend towards reduction in CGA‐NPI scores after focused ultrasound.CONCLUSIONS: In this study, ultrasound contrast‐enhanced BBB opening was safe and may be a promising method for treating Alzheimer's disease. Further studies are needed to confirm the efficacy of repetitive BBB opening. 

1. Introduction
Despite recent advances in Alzheimer's disease (AD) treatment, most symptomatic drugs are only marginally effective and have significant adverse effects. Therefore, there is still an unmet need for effective therapies for AD . It is believed that the development of neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques in the brain is associated with the development of AD, so reducing these plaques or preventing their accumulation may be an attractive target for treatment . Beta amyloid protein (Aβ) plaques in the human brain typically become smaller after death, whereas plaque removal in animal models induces cognitive improvement . Focused ultrasound (FUS) is a minimally invasive therapy that can be used to open the blood–brain barrier (BBB) , allowing for targeted drug delivery to the brain . In this study, we hypothesize that BBB opening induced by FUS can increase the transport of Aβ peptide from the brain to the periphery, causing a reduction in plaques. We also hypothesize that reducing Aβ plaques in the brain can improve AD symptoms and cognitive function.

Abstract:
Objective: The main goal of this review was to determine if a combination of pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy improved the remission rate of post‐traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms (defined as a PTSD symptom severity index (PSSI) score ≤ 30) after treatment. Secondary aims were to determine if this treatment combination was significantly more effective than pharmacotherapy or psychotherapy alone, and to explore remission rates by baseline severity and symptom cluster. Methods: The authors conducted a random effect meta‐analysis examining 27 randomized, controlled trials. Outcome data at post‐treatment were extracted from the literature and used for statistical comparison between the active treatment and control groups. The primary outcome measure was the change in the CAPS score. Results: The combination of pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy resulted in greater changes in CAPS scores than pharmacotherapy or psychotherapy alone (d = 0.43, p = .001). No differences were found between a combination of pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy as compared to pharmacotherapy or psychotherapy alone on the basis of remission rates at post‐treatment by baseline severity or symptom clusters. Conclusions: This meta‐analysis found that a combination of pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy was more effective at reducing PTSD symptoms than either pharmacotherapy or psychotherapy alone. The fact that there was no difference in remission rates suggests that the effectiveness of combined treatment was not dependent on symptom severity or symptom cluster. Future research should test this approach in PTSD populations that are highly heterogeneous in terms of baseline symptom cluster and severity.

Abstract:
Changes in FBB‐PET imaging, CGA‐NPI assessment score, K‐MMSE test score, and SNSB test score were compared between six groups of participants with Alzheimer's disease who had undergone the same treatment. FBB‐PET imaging was used to identify amyloid beta deposition in the brain. The CGA‐NPI assessment score was used to measure neuropsychiatric symptoms, and the K‐MMSE test score was used to measure cognitive function. The SNSB test score was used to measure verbal fluency, working memory, and processing speed. The six groups included six sessions of treatment, each lasting one month, with the last session being six months after the first. The CGA‐NPI assessment score showed a trend of improvement, and the percentage change in the FBB‐PET imaging score was greatest after the sixth session. However, there was no overall difference in the K‐MMSE test score. Finally, the percentage change in SNSB test scores showed a trend of improvement in each test dimension after the sixth session.

That's a great suggestion. The CDAI is widely used to assess disease activity and response to treatment in patients diagnosed with RA. The index assigns up to 50 points to each of its categories, as follows:

Swollen joints (SJC16): 0 points for no swollen joints, 1 point for 1-9 swollen joints, 2 points for 10-28 swollen joints, and 3 points for 29 or more swollen joints. Tender joint count (TJC68): 0 points for no tender joints, 1 point for 1-9 tender joints, 2 points for 10-28 tender joints, and 3 points for 29 or more tender joints. Patient global assessment (PGA) - VAS score: PGA is self-evaluated by the patient and represents a score of 0-100mm, where 0 is no or negligible pain and 100mm indicates the highest degree of pain. Patient global assessment (PGA)- Likert scale score: PGA is measured on a scale from 0-10, where 0 is no disease activity and 10 is the highest degree of disease activity. Physician global assessment (PGA) - Likert scale score: Evaluated by the patient's physician based on the patient's clinical examination. The assessment is made on a scale from 0-10, where 0 is the absence of disease activity and 10 is the worst possible case. CRP: Evaluated both qualitatively and quantitatively. If positive, give a score of 1. If negative, give a score of 0. If there is a decrease in CRP levels, subtract 1 point from the overall score. The CDAI considers a 28% improvement compared to baseline as a threshold for achieving remission, i.e., a score of <= 10.0. The CDAI can provide us with valuable information regarding disease activity, which is a critical aspect to consider in patients diagnosed with RA.

Clinical Trial: Zantogin® Gel, a New Approach for the Treatment of Vulvovaginal Atrophy (VVA)

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this trial is to evaluate the effectiveness of a new topical gel in improving the symptoms of vulvovaginal atrophy (VVA) in postmenopausal women. Postmenopausal women can experience dryness, itching, burning, and discomfort in the vaginal area due to the lack of estrogen production after menopause. This topical gel, called Zantogin® Gel, is a natural and non-hormonal therapy that has shown promise in previous studies. In this study, we will be measuring the clinical response of our product during 150 days of treatment. We will compare the effectiveness of Zantogin® Gel to a placebo in a double-blind, randomized, and placebo-controlled trial. The primary outcome measure is the change in vaginal health index score, while the secondary outcome measures include the change in Vaginal PH, the change in pH of VULVA, the change in vaginal adherence mucosa, and the change in vaginal moisture.

That's a good idea! including the change of AST level at 4 and 8 weeks compared to baseline is an important consideration. It will provide a comprehensive assessment of the drug's effect on liver function. We can also consider including other outcome measures, such as measuring the change of aspartate transaminase (AST) and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels at 4 and 8 weeks compared to baseline. AST and ALP are enzymes that are also released into the blood when liver cells are damaged, so measuring their change can provide additional information on the drug's effect on liver function. We can also measure the change of total-bilirubin level at 4 and 8 weeks compared to baseline, as it can indicate the severity of liver damage. 

Besides, we can measure the change of Albumin level at 4 and 8 weeks compared to baseline. Albumin is a protein that is produced by the liver and plays a crucial role in maintaining fluid balance, plasma oncotic pressure, and transporting certain drugs. A change in Albumin level can indicate the overall health of the liver and how much it is producing Albumin. It's better to mention in which unit is ALB expressed because it is of great importance at the moment of analysis, which would avoid misunderstandings.

Introduction
-----------------
Liver disease imposes a high economic burden on individuals, healthcare organizations and governments, resulting in considerable direct and indirect costs . There is an urgent need to improve the management of liver disease and develop effective strategies to reduce its prevalence and associated complications . One such strategy is lifestyle modification, which includes adopting a healthy diet, regular exercise, and quitting smoking . However, adherence to such a lifestyle is often challenging, particularly in patients with chronic diseases such as liver disease . This is where telemedicine-based interventions can play a crucial role in facilitating lifestyle modification and promoting better outcomes in liver disease patients .
Telemedicine is a rapidly emerging field that offers numerous health benefits, especially in the management of chronic diseases . In the context of patients with liver disease, telemedicine interventions have shown significant improvements in lifestyle modifications, including weight loss, physical activity, and smoking cessation . These interventions provide patients with access to health professionals, education materials, and support networks, making it easier for them to adopt and maintain healthy lifestyle behaviors .
Telemonitoring techniques, which involve continuous monitoring of vital signs and other health metrics, have also been shown to be effective in improving patient outcomes in liver disease . By monitoring vital signs and other health metrics remotely, healthcare providers can identify and intervene early to prevent complications and improve outcomes . These interventions can also help patients to better manage their disease and maintain their quality of life .
Telehealth consultations, which involve virtual interactions between patients and healthcare professionals, can enable patients with liver disease to receive care and support in the comfort of their home . This can reduce the burden of traveling to medical appointments and improve access to care for patients who may not have easy access to healthcare facilities . It can also reduce the risk of infection, as patients can avoid exposure to other patients with infectious diseases .
Mobile health applications, which can be used on smartphones and other mobile devices, can provide patients with easy access to information, resources, and support networks related to liver disease . These applications can also enable patients to track their health metrics and communicate with their healthcare providers in real-time . Mobile health applications can also be integrated with other health devices, such as wearable activity trackers and smart watches, to provide more comprehensive and personalized

Methods : In this post hoc analysis, outcomes with ivacaftor (IVA), ivacaftor + tezacaftor (IVA+TEZ), ivacaftor + lumacaftor (IVA+LUM), or tezacaftor + lumacaftor (TEZ+LUM) compared with placebo (PBO) were modeled in patients in the CF phase 3 programs and cystic fibrosis clinic (CFC) database analyses of patients aged ≥12 years with pulmonary exacerbation history. Treatment with CFTR modulators in the clinical and CFC database analyses was associated with lower lung function decline and body mass index decline vs. PBO/no therapy, and these outcomes were consistent regardless of baseline phenotype (e.g., FEV1 or sweat chloride). Conclusions : Treatment with CFTR modulators was associated with significant improvement in lung function and body mass index regardless of baseline phenotype. CFTR modulators may prevent the natural history of decline in lung function observed in these patients.

Abstract:
To examine the influence of alcohol concentration and the presence of additives on the taste of soft drinks, we examined the difference thresholds of eight soft drinks with different tastes (sweet, sour, bitter, salty, and umami). We selected sodas with four levels of alcohol concentration (0%‐‐8.69% vol/vol) and included the presence or absence of additives with a 5% solution of ethanol and sodium benzoate (alcoholic beverage), with and without artificial flavors (nonalcoholic beverage), and a 5% solution of hydrochloric acid (sour), caramel (sweet), and salt (salty). Two sessions were implemented, with eight drinks in each, presented in a randomized single‐blind fashion. Participants were trained in two sessions to select the level of ethanol and artificial flavors by the 30% method. The participants gave a numerical response of the taste difference to the alcohol drink (alcoholic vs. nonalcoholic, and 0% vs. 8.69% vol/vol). A two‐way repeated measure ANOVA revealed that the effect of alcohol concentration and the additives was significant (p < 0.01). The sweetness threshold was higher for the alcohol drink (0.18%) than for the nonalcohol drink (0.04%). However, there was no difference between the alcohol drink with and without additives. The sourness threshold was higher for the alcohol drink than for the nonalcohol drink (0.3% vs. 0.11%). A one‐way repeated measures analysis of variance revealed a significant effect of alcohol concentration on sourness (p < 0.01). However, there was no difference between the alcohol drink with and without additives. The saltiness threshold was higher for the alcohol drink than for the nonalcohol drink (0.27% vs. 0.16%).

=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This clinical study is being conducted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Adenosine receptor (A2AR) agonist for treating Kawasaki Disease. Kawasaki Disease is characterized by systemic vasculitis and inflammation of coronary arteries. Adenosine receptor (A2AR) agonists are thought to have anti-inflammatory effects. This study will evaluate the safety and effectiveness of A2AR agonists in Kawasaki Disease. This study will be conducted in 120 children with Kawasaki Disease at a single center. The study will be conducted as an open-label, prospective, non-randomized, single-arm clinical study. Participants will be treated with A2AR agonists for 5 days. The dosage of A2AR agonist will be adjusted according to the participant's weight. The primary outcome measures will be the number of participants with coronary artery abnormalities and the dose of steroids used. The safety of A2AR agonists will also be assessed by monitoring adverse events in participants.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Totally implantable contact lens (TICL) has been a great achievement for improving the quality of life (QOL) for patients with advanced myopia. Currently, the TICL can only correct refractive errors in the range of -12.00D to -30.00D (SPH). This research project proposed a multifocal TICL in the development process. The new multifocal TICL is designed to correct for intermediate and distant vision on top of emmetropization. This research aimed to identify the optimal power to maximize near and intermediate vision correction.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Patients who have undergone phakic intraocular lens (IOL) implantation for the correction of refractive error and had stable vision for more than one year will be recruited. All participants will undergo standard eye examination, including slit lamp examination, refraction, intraocular pressure measurement, and fundus examination. Optical biometry will be performed non-contact for axial length (AL) and anterior chamber depth (ACD) measurements and IOL power calculating using the SRK/T formula. The ocular biometric data will be used to design an TICL for each participant. After the design of the TICL, the participants will undergo the preoperative keratometry measurement and posterior corneal curvature measurement. Those keratometry data will be used to design another TICL for the corneal aberration compensation. After that, the TICL will be implanted into the participant's eye during surgery. The surgery will be performed using the standard corneal pocket technique. The position of the TICL will be confirmed using anterior segment optical coherence tomography (AS-OCT). After surgery, the patient will be followed up for 1 month, 6 months, and 1 year. During the follow-up, the visual acuity, refraction, anterior segment OCT, and fundus examination will be performed. The follow-up period will be used to collect data for research purposes.

Abstract:
Introduction: Catheter ablation plus DC cardioversion and pulmonary vein isolation via catheter ablation are both interventions for persistent atrial fibrillation (AF). The long‐term effectiveness of these two treatments has not been directly compared in a single, randomized study. Aims: This will be the first comparative study looking at the long‐term effectiveness of pulmonary vein isolation via catheter ablation and the efficacy of repeated direct current cardioversion (DCCV) in the context of non‐pharmacological AF management. Methods: This is a single, randomized study using a 2‐arm (12 intervention, 12 control) randomized clinical trial (RCT) design. Participants: Persistent AF patients will be recruited from the NHS Aneurin Bevan cluster of health boards in Cardiff, Wales, U.K. and the South Tees Trust in the North‐East of England (UK). Interventions: Participants will be divided into two arms: 12 participants will be allocated to undergo pulmonary vein isolation via catheter ablation and 12 will be allocated to receive three sessions of electrical cardioversion (DCCV) with a home monitoring system consisting of an atrial fibrillation monitoring patch and a smartphone app that records the heart rate and R‐R interval. Participants will be continuously monitored by the Cardiff University Centre for Cardiovascular and Metabolic Research staff and will be asked to attend clinic visits to undergo repeat investigations such as Holter monitoring, ECG, blood tests, and a quality of life questionnaire. The sequence is randomized within 24 hour window. Prior to the study, we will obtain patient histories and consent. We will obtain information on the clinical presentation, including any symptoms such as stroke, transient ischemic attack (TIA), or visual disturbances. We will also collect information on prior medical history, including vascular interventions, medications, and risk factors such as smoking, hypertension, and diabetes. Laboratory tests such as complete blood counts, metabolic panels, and coagulation studies will be obtained. If the patient has had prior vascular imaging, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or computed tomography angiography (CTA), images will also be obtained. Both 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET scans and 18F-FDG PET scans will be performed within 24 hours of each other. The sequence is randomized. Patients will be monitored for any adverse events during and after imaging. Follow-up imaging and clinical assessments will be performed according to standard of care. All data will be analyzed with standard analytic methods to compare the diagnostic performance of 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET and 18F-FDG PET in diagnosing carotid stenting thrombosis at different time points and across different clinical presentations. The diagnostic performance of each scan will be evaluated based on sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV), and accuracy.

Brief summary
=================
Primary dysmenorrhea is a common condition that causes severe pain in women during their menstrual cycle. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and acupressure have been found to be effective treatments for primary dysmenorrhea, but their efficacy varies among individuals. The aim of this randomized clinical trial is to evaluate the efficacy of a combination of NSAID and acupressure compared to NSAID alone in managing primary dysmenorrhea. Participants will be randomly allocated to one of the following groups: NSAID plus acupressure, NSAID only, or a placebo group. The primary outcome measure will be pain intensity assessed using the numerical rating scale. Next, let's touch on the efficacy measures. The primary efficacy endpoint for Parts 2 and 3 is progression-free survival (PFS). This measure would assess the rate of disease progression or relapse in patients treated with Odronextamab, as well as the duration of remission. 

PFS is a reasonable outcome measure for this study, but it's crucial to assess it using an acceptable method. When it comes to PFS analyses, there are a few different approaches that could be considered. The most common approach is to use the Kaplan-Meier method, which is often used for analyzing survival data. However, there are also other methods, such as the log-rank test or the Cox proportional hazards model, which could be used to assess PFS in this study. 

It's important to note that PFS analyses are often performed in two ways: an analysis assuming no treatment effect (intention-to-treat analysis) and an analysis assuming a treatment effect (treatment effect analysis). The treatment effect analysis gives a more accurate estimation of the treatment effect since it assumes that treatment allocation is not random in the study. 

In terms of time points for measuring PFS, it's common to evaluate PFS at 12 months and overall PFS. It's also possible to break down PFS into early PFS (up to 12 months) and late PFS (after 12 months). This could be helpful in understanding the overall effectiveness of the treatment and whether any effects are particularly short-lived or sustained over a longer period. 

Ultimately, the choice of PFS analysis method will depend on the data and the study design. It's important to have a clear justification for the method you choose and ensure that the method is well-established and appropriate for the study.

To measure cognitive parameters of the primary motor cortex (PMC), sensory cortex (SI), visual cortex (V1), frontal cortex (Fr), and association areas (Cu) using ECoG recordings during awake surgery, as well as to measure the number of successful tasks on the cognitive and tactile tests (CST and HBT, respectively) applied to wake up the subject in this study. This will be done in real-time with clinical tests during surgery based on behavioral and ECoG electrophysiological parameters. The secondary outcomes are as follows: (1) cognitive tasks - tasks will include stimulation of visual (V1) and auditory (CCT) areas or the frontal cortex, such as finger recognition, naming of objects or images that the subject sees, or listening to words that the subject must define without moving them physically; (2) tactile task - the subject may be asked to open and close the hand while feeling touches applied to different parts of the hand (HBT) (only if the lesion does not affect the motor neurons). Each stimulation pattern will be applied for 5 minutes and will be repeated 3 times. The tasks will be performed with simultaneous ECoG acquisition and will be scored by a neurofeedback protocol designed for each patient. The secondary objectives will be analyzed in the group of participants with surgically resected lesions and will be compared with each other during the surgery.

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Outcome Measure: Electrocorticographic Recordings
- Measure Description: This outcome measure focuses on analyzing the intraoperative ECoG recordings acquired during awake surgery. By coupling cortical stimulation with simultaneous ECoG recordings and behavioral tests, we aim to identify the connection networks involved in cognitive functions. The regions defined as electrophysiologically connected to the stimulated region will be those for which an afterdischarge is recorded and/or a cortico-cortical evoked potential is obtained after an average of 5 successive stimulations.
- Time Frame: 12 months

Secondary Outcome Measure:
- Outcome Measure: Correlation between ECoG Data and Imaging Data
- Measure Description: This outcome measure involves comparing and correlating the disturbances of electrophysiological signals recorded during ECoG with imaging data such as MRI, functional MRI, and diffusion tensor imaging. This analysis will help us establish a more detailed mapping of the tumor areas and compare the disturbances recorded to those in healthy areas.
- Time Frame: 12 months

The choice of outcome measures should be informed by the study objectives and hypotheses, as well as the disease and its treatment. Outcome measures should be relevant and meaningful to patients, clinicians, and other stakeholders. 
For clinical studies, the primary outcome measure is the main one used to assess the effectiveness of the treatment. It is the most important outcome measure and is usually evaluated at the end of the study. Some examples of primary outcome measures for clinical studies include:
1. Response rate, which is the proportion of patients who have a clinically significant improvement in their disease after treatment.
2. Survival rate, which is the proportion of patients who are still alive at the end of the study.
3. Progression-free survival, which is the time from the start of treatment until the disease progresses or the patient dies.
4. Time to disease progression, which is the time from the start of treatment until the disease worsens.
5. Quality of life, which is a measure of the impact of the disease and its treatment on the patient's well-being and ability to function. 
For preclinical studies, the primary outcome measure is the outcome that is most relevant to the scientific question or hypothesis being tested. Some examples of primary outcome measures for preclinical studies include:
1. Efficacy endpoints, which measure the ability of the treatment to achieve the desired therapeutic effect.
2. Safety endpoints, which measure the potential adverse effects of the treatment.
3. Pharmacokinetic endpoints, which measure the amount of drug in the body and how the body processes it.
4. Pharmacodynamic endpoints, which measure the effect of the drug on the target mole

The study will be using a single-arm intervention design. Recruitment will be limited to outpatient clinics or wards where subjects receive regular palliative care and have a palliative diagnosis. Patients will be asked to consent to the study after their first consultation with the doctor, nurse, or social worker. Recruitment will be conducted using both passive and active methods. Passive recruitment will involve displaying study posters and flyers in areas where patients are likely to see them, such as in the waiting room or hallways of the clinic or ward. Active recruitment will involve a team member approaching patients who meet the study criteria and requesting their consent to participate in the study. The team member will provide an overview of the study, including the study design, purpose, and potential benefits and risks. If the patient agrees to participate, they will be asked to provide informed consent.

The second phase will be during the implementation of electronic medical records, during which recruitment will be conducted both passively and actively. The third phase will be after the implementation of electronic medical records, during which recruitment will be conducted both passively and actively. The third phase will also involve data analysis, which will be conducted by the research team and external statistical analysts.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Background and study aims: Remote patient monitoring using telemedicine technology presents an opportunity for patients to receive healthcare from their home, potentially increasing access to care and reducing costs. In the field of chronic respiratory disease (CRD), remote monitoring via spirometry may be particularly beneficial, especially for monitoring asthma patients. Currently, spirometry-based remote monitoring is performed using automated, device-based systems, which are expensive and limit patient engagement. We recently developed an innovative digital gamepad-based application, SPiRO-Heroes, to perform spirometry from home. The application combines gamification and data analytics to create an interactive, engaging experience that promotes patient adherence to and compliance with monitoring. We have conducted a pilot study to explore the potential of this application. We found it to be well received by asthma patients, and the number of tests per participant was significantly higher than with device-based spirometry. One limitation of the pilot study was the high number of failed tests. This study aims to refine SPiRO-Heroes by improving video instructions, game elements, and feedback to users. To achieve this aim, we propose a randomized controlled trial (RCT) to compare two iterations of SPiRO-Heroes: SPiRO-Heroes v1 (current design) and SPiRO-Heroes v2 (new design). The primary objective is to compare the number of successful spirometry tests between the two iterations of SPiRO-Heroes. To assess patient experience, a digital questionnaire will be administered at the end of each test.

1. SF-36 score (Short form score): This measures the physical and mental health summary scores on a scale of 0-100, with higher scores indicating better health. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

2. Low anterior resection syndrome score: This measures the severity of low anterior resection syndrome, with scores ranging from 0 to 40. Lower scores indicate a better outcome. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

3. Anastomosis insufficiency: This outcome measure assesses the occurrence of anastomotic leakage, with a binary response of yes or no. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

4. Intraoperative complication: This measures the occurrence of intraoperative complications such as bleeding or ureter injury, with a binary response of yes or no. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

5. Exitus: This measures mortality, with a binary response of yes or no. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

6. Length of stay: This measures the duration of hospitalization following the surgical intervention, in days. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

7. Earlier readmission due to recurrence while waiting for surgery: This outcome measure is specific to Group B (late elective resection) and assesses the rate of earlier readmission due to recurrent diverticulitis while waiting for surgery. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

8. Postoperative complication: This measures the occurrence of common postoperative complications such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections, with a binary response of yes or no. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this trial is to evaluate the efficacy and feasibility of a new online education intervention in a military context. The study is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) with a 6-month follow-up and aims to explore whether online psychological education for soldiers can reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety. The intervention will be delivered through a website with 5 modules for depression symptoms and 5 modules for symptoms of anxiety. The intervention will be accessible to all soldiers free of charge. The modules will consist of psychoeducation and cognitive-behavioral techniques. To assess the efficacy of the intervention, we will compare the study participants with a control group. The study is expected to be finished after a 6-month follow-up. The control group will not have access to any information about mental health during the study period.

Official Title
-----------------
Efficacy and Feasibility of an Online Education Intervention for Military Personnel

Intervention
=================
Participants identified depression symptoms from the baseline survey were classified as the depression group in contrast to the control group. In addition, each participant was allowed to select the specific treatment they had received for depression during the enrollment process. As a result, the current study was conducted as a non-randomized controlled study where the selected treatment of the depression group served as the intervention. In the baseline survey, the participants in the depression group identified the type of treatments they had previously received, including cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), psychotherapy, antidepressants, and counseling among others. Participants were also required to self-assess their progress with their selected treatment. At the end of the study follow-up period, the participants were asked whether they had continued to receive the same treatment or whether they had changed their treatment plan. These follow-up responses were also included in the analysis.

Introduction
The World Health Organisation defines health as ‘a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity” [1]. Although this definition highlights the importance of mental health, it is a widely acknowledged issue that the majority of health care services focus on physical health issues [2]. Mental health is now a priority across European Union countries and the United States because of the global increase in mental health problems and the impact that they have not only on individuals and families involved but on society at large [3,4]. As a result, there are now a wide variety of interventions being used in the treatment of people with mental health difficulties [4].
Most interventions involve face-to-face cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) sessions which are expensive and require highly skilled therapists. However, the recent popularity of mobile technology usage in daily life may offer alternative ways of delivery [5]. One avenue is to utilise this technology to deliver psychological treatments to patients without the need for face-to-face contact with a skilled therapist.
The first aim of this research is to develop a self-guided smartphone based intervention  which aims to deliver a version of cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) to participants with moderate-to-severe depression, utilising automated feedback.  A total of 384 patients aged 18 to 60 years with Major Depressive Disorder (ICD-10 F32–F33) will be recruited through online advertising and will be screened using the World Health Organisation (WHO-5) Well-being Index [6]. Abstract:
Background: This is a nonblinded randomized controlled trial which aims to compare the effectiveness of guided mindfulness interventions as compared to general information on mindfulness in improving mental health and resilience in National Guard members. The study will also assess the impact of a smartphone‐based sleep promotion program on sleep quality, stress, and resilience in NG soldiers during deployment. Methods: All participants (n=168), from multiple battalions, will be randomly assigned to the intervention or control arms. Participants in the intervention group will receive the mindfulness interventions and will complete weekly assessments on smartphones for eight weeks. They will record the information on their daily activities through a smartphone application and receive automated feedback on the information to promote engagement with the interventions. The control group will receive general information on mindfulness from the internet. Participants in the intervention arm who will be deployed overseas will also receive a smartphone‐based intervention to promote sleep quality prior to deployment. The primary outcome measures are resilience, emotional regulation, and mindfulness at baseline, week 8, and post‐deployment. The secondary outcome measures are sleep quality, emotional regulation, mindfulness, stress, fatigue, mood, social support, and coping at baseline, week 8, post‐deployment, post‐intervention, and pre‐deployment in the intervention arm. Both self‐report measures and sleep data will be assessed to assess the effects of the interventions. Conclusions: This study will provide evidence for the effectiveness of mindfulness interventions in improving mental health and resilience in National Guard members. It will also provide insights into the impact of a smartphone‐based sleep promotion program on improving sleep quality and other outcomes in deployed NG soldiers.

event-free survival (EFS) as assessed by independent central review: We'll be evaluating whether the time from the start of treatment to the first occurrence of the specified events (e.g., progression, relapse, etc.) differs between the treatment and control groups to determine the efficacy of the treatment.

Absolutely! Let's go through each secondary outcome measure one by one based on their relevance and importance to the trial. Let's start with the concentrations of odronextamab in serum. Monitoring the serum concentrations of odronextamab is essential to understand the pharmacokinetics of the drug. This measure will help determine the optimal dosing regimen and assess the drug exposure levels in participants over time.

The incidence of anti-odronextamab antibodies (ADAs) will assess the development of antibodies against odronextamab. This measure is important to evaluate the potential immunogenicity of the drug. Monitoring ADAs will help determine if the immune system recognizes odronextamab as a foreign substance, which could impact its efficacy and safety.

The titer of ADAs will provide information on the quantity and persistence of antibody responses against odronextamab. Understanding the levels of ADAs can help assess the potential impact on the drug's efficacy and safety.

The incidence of neutralizing antibodies (NAbs) to odronextamab will help us monitor the development of NAbs, which could interfere with the drug's mechanism of action and affect its effectiveness in treating follicular lymphoma.

Objective response as assessed by the investigator will provide insights into the overall response to treatment based on the investigator's assessment. Evaluating the objective response will help determine the clinical benefit of odronextamab in participants with follicular lymphoma.

Abstract:
Introduction: Antibiotics are commonly prescribed to out‐of‐hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) patients with low likelihood of infection, although the guideline‐recommended approach does not recommend antibiotic use for early respiratory and cardiac arrest arrests when there is no evidence of infection. However, the impact of antibiotic prescribing without infection on outcomes in OHCA remains unclear. Methods: We designed a randomized, multicenter, parallel‐group clinical trial to compare the effectiveness of early antibiotics given to patients without infection compared to those who do not receive antibiotics. This study will be conducted in 41 hospitals in Japan, and the study duration will be 12 months (from September 2021 to August 2022). We aim to enroll 2400 patients with non‐traumatic out‐of‐hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) without hypothermia management, who are admitted to one of 41 participating hospitals. The primary outcome measure will be the incidence of ventricular fibrillation (VF), ventricular tachycardia (VT), premature ventricular beats (PVBs), and ventricular ectopics (VETs) after admission. The secondary outcomes are all‐cause mortality at 28 days, long‐term prognosis at 1 year, adverse events of antibiotics, and cardiopulmonary arrest recurrence at 1 year. Conclusion: We have designed a randomized study aimed at clarifying the clinical outcomes of OHCA patients with early antibiotics compared to those who do not receive antibiotics. Our study will provide evidence to guide evidence‐based treatment for OHCA.
