Detailed Description
-----------------
Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a common diagnosis that significantly impact patients' quality of life. Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is a non-invasive and effective treatment for major depression. The goal of this study is to assess the efficacy of adding virtual reality (VR) to TMS in the treatment of MDD. Patients diagnosed with MDD will be randomized to receive either TMS alone or TMS + VR in addition to their regular medication. TMS will be delivered using a H7 coil for 3 weeks, 5 times per week, with a cumulative total of 15 sessions. VR will be added to TMS for the first 5 sessions only, and patients will receive standardized VR games for 35 minutes per session. Outcome measures will be assessed at the beginning of the study, at the end of treatment (after the 15th session), and at the 1-month follow-up. The outcome measures will include the Montgomery-Åsberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS), the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HAMD), the Clinical Global Impression-Severity (CGI-S) scale, and the Sheehan Disability Scale (SDS).

Methionine deficiency and toxicity can lead to various complications and disorders such as cardiac damage, insulin resistance, vascular stiffness and inflammation. It is found in all cells in the body, and has many functions. Methionine is the starting point for many metabolic reactions in the body and is required daily in the diet. The major dietary sources of methionine are meats. Methionine is found in the following, mainly in the form of protein: meat, poultry, seafood, eggs, nuts and seeds. The daily requirement of methionine is 8 mg per kg of body weight per day. It can be stored in the body for up to 10 days. Methionine is also found in foods rich in protein, but in smaller amounts. 1 g of protein contains less than 20 mg of methionine. Excess methionine in the body is oxidized into cystine and cysteine, and they are found in the connective tissues of the body, such as skin, lungs, bones, etc. and in the connective tissues of cells. Cysteine is the most abundant amino acid in hair and nails, making up about one-third of their dry matter. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study will assess safety and efficacy of ICI201 in patients with multiple myeloma. This will be a phase I, open-label, single-arm study with dose escalation and expansion design, enrolling approximately 154-169 participants with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma (including amyloidosis).

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will enroll 154-169 subjects with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma. Eligible participants must have documented myeloma progression after or during the last line of therapy. The study will enroll an initial cohort of approximately 10 patients in a phase 1 dose escalation stage to test the safety of multiple doses of ICI201 in these patients. The study will commence with patients in Cohort 1 who will receive the starting dose of ICI201. The treatment will continue for 12 weeks and all patients will be monitored for 90 days after the last dose of ICI201 treatment for safety concerns and for evidence of anti-tumor activity. The dose escalation will continue until the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) is determined per the protocol. This determination will be made after four patients have been enrolled in each new cohort and evaluated for safety for 90 days post the last dose of ICI201. Once the MTD dose is determined, participants can be enrolled in Cohort 2 (Expansion Phase). Subjects enrolled in the expansion group will be treated continuously as long as there is clinical benefit and their disease does not progress (as defined by the study criteria), or they voluntarily discontinue participation in the study. Treatment with ICI201 will be administered for a maximum of 96 weeks. The safety of patients who receive higher doses (determined to be tolerable and stable following phase 1) will be monitored closely for at least three years of administration.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 1, open-label, multiple-dose, randomized, single and dual dose, parallel group study. The study is designed to explore the pharmacokinetics (PK) and safety of a dual dose regiment of Pirtobrutinib in participants with impaired liver function and healthy participants who will be randomized to the group of hepatic and non-hepatic participants. This study comprises of three parts. In Part 1, two doses of oral administration of Pirtobrutinib (FTY720) 100mg twice a day administered for 28 days will be administrated to healthy participants. In 5 to 8 participants, PK of Pirtobrutinib in healthy participants will be compared between the two regiments. In Part 2 and Part 3, there will be one study arm in which 18 participants with hepatic impairment and 18 healthy participants will be randomized. Each participant of Part 2 and 3 will receive two doses of oral administration of Pirtobrutinib 100mg twice a day administered for 28 days. In Part 2, a maximum of ten participants with hepatic impairment will be administrated 200mg once a day for 14 days and 180mg once a day for 14 days. In Part 3, a maximum of ten participants with hepatic impairment will be randomly administered 200mg once a day for 14 days and 100mg twice a day for 14 days. After each period of the study, a treatment-free period of 14 days will occur before starting the next period.

Study Design
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Recruitment to this retrospective chart review will be via the National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) data registry. For each subject, the investigators will extract data regarding age, gender, medical and psychiatric comorbidities, preoperative body mass index, preoperative creatinine levels, type of procedure performed, admission method (elective versus emergency), operative duration, intraoperative hemoglobin drop, intraoperative packed red blood cell (PRBC) use, 30-day length of stay (LOS), in-hospital all cause and 30-day all cause mortality, unplanned intubation, hospital readmission within 30 days of discharge, and 30-day unplanned surgery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Nearly one-third of patients age 70 and older will undergo major abdominal or pelvic surgery. Of this group, 30-day mortality approaches 8%. Advanced age, co-morbidities, intraoperative blood loss, and perioperative anemia confer increased risk of postoperative mortality. The risks of blood-preserving therapies such as Transfusion Alternative Strategies are well studied and have not been fully investigated in the era of Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS). Previous publications have shown improved outcomes with ERAS protocols in these patients. To that end, the investigators propose to study the impact of transfusion thresholds and ERAS interventions on blood transfusion frequency and perioperative outcomes. These findings will have important implications towards the future treatment of elderly surgical patients.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Venous thromboembolism, mainly deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE), is a relevant complication of cancer, with a high morbidity and mortality rate. Treatment of cancer patients with venous thromboembolism consists of anticoagulants or thrombolytics in some cases accompanied by compression. Currently, mechanical compression devices that activate muscle contractions are not very effective, uncomfortable, and often cause discomfort for patients. In addition, they present contraindications for patients with poor circulation, obesity, and the presence of a neoplastic lesion. The purpose of this study is to evaluate an algorithm for calculating the optimal pressure for each type of compression (arterial, venous, or both), in order to reduce the symptoms of ischemia in the upper limb associated with this type of compression.

Detailed Description
-----------------
For each treatment type (arterial, venous, or both) we will recruit 15 healthy volunteer subjects, for a total of 45 patients. The patients in the study will have a normal peripheral vascularization and an intra and extra arterial examination will be performed to rule out possible changes in the vascular beds of the upper limb. Once this has been verified and there is no possible contraindication to this mechanical method, each patient will participate for a total of 120 minutes. In the first phase, the following phases will be used in the measurement of cutaneous blood flow by transcutaneous oximetry (TcpO2): baseline (B), 2 minutes after the onset of treatment with a first device (FU1) after 3 minutes of blood flow measurement and 3 minutes after 6 minutes and 9 minutes of use of the device (FU2 and FU3). The average value between 4 and 10 minutes for FU1 and between 9 and 12 minutes for FU2 will be selected as the value of DROPVEN. In the case of compression due to the presence of venous thromboembolism (VTE), the device that provides better decongestion of the affected veins will be used, i.e. the one that lowers DROPven the most with less drop

Introduction
The diagnosis of Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS) has been reported to have limited sensitivity and specificity.1 Dynamic tests such as Adson test, Elevation test, and Costoclavicular maneuver have also been found to have low accuracy in diagnosing thoracic outlet syndrome.2 Furthermore, these tests may not be suitable for some patients. In this clinical study, we aim to compare the accuracy of Transcutaneous Oximetry with Dynamic Measurements (TDM) in diagnosing thoracoid outlet syndrome.3 The primary aim of this study is to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of a new point-of-care (POC) device for the diagnosis of TOS using Transcutaneous Oximetry (TcpO2) (FOFANOX, Shenzhen Fanox Medical Technology Co., Ltd., China) in patients with a clinical diagnosis of TOS and other chronic neck and shoulder conditions.
There have been several studies that have compared the diagnostic accuracy of various diagnostic methods for the diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome, but no studies have evaluated the diagnostic accuracy of transcutaneous oximetry using FOFANOX in diagnosing TOS. The proposed study will evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of transcutaneous oximetry using the FOFANOX device in diagnosing TOS compared to the standard diagnostic procedures according to a recent consensus guideline from the European Society of Neuro-Oncology in patients with TOS and other chronic neck and shoulder conditions.4 Moreover, the study will compare the diagnostic accuracy of transcutaneous oximetry with dynamic maneuvers in diagnosing TOS. This comparison will help to assess the potential utility of transcutaneous oximetry as a diagnostic tool for TOS and provide additional evidence to support the use of transcutaneous oximetry in clinical practice.


Study Design and Objectives
The proposed study will be a cross-sectional, observational study. In addition, the study will be conducted in a single center and a randomized cohort of patients with TOS and a control group of patients with other chronic neck and shoulder conditions will be included for comparison. Abstract:
Introduction: Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) can be a complex disorder that affects different compartments of the thoracic outlet, including the scalene triangle, supraclavicular fossa, andcostoclavicular space. It affects blood vessels, nerves, and soft tissue structures, causing pain or dysfunction in the upper extremity. TcpO2 measurement of the upper limb is a non‐invasive technique that can assess changes in oxygen saturation in tissue. Arterial compression from an internal mammary artery or subclavian artery causes ischemia, which can be observed using a transcutaneous oxygen (TcpO2) monitor. The current study aims to investigate the effectiveness of TcpO2 monitoring in diagnosing arterial compression during dynamic maneuvers in patients with suspected TOS. Methods: A prospective case series study will be conducted at an interventional radiology outpatient clinic. Twenty‐two patients with suspected TOS will be identified using history, clinical examination, and diagnostic arteriography. The patients will undergo TcpO2 monitoring of both upper limbs during a series of dynamic maneuvers, including adduction and supination of the upper limb, forced arm abduction with external rotation, and a sustained isometric contraction of the upper limb muscle. The results will be compared with the findings of arteriography. The primary outcome measure will be the change in TcpO2 levels during the dynamic maneuvers, and the secondary outcome measure will be the correlation between TcpO2 levels and the severity of arterial stenosis observed in diagnostic arteriography. Results: The inter‐observer and intra‐observer correlation was high (ICC 0.96), indicating good reliability of the TcpO2 measurements. Data analysis is currently ongoing. We expect to present our findings by the end of 2024. Conclusions: TcpO2 monitoring is a promising non‐invasive technique for diagnosing arterial compression in patients with suspected TOS. Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Transcutaneous oximetry (TcpO2) is a noninvasive method of monitoring tissue oxygenation. Preliminary reports have suggested that TcpO2 may be a useful diagnostic tool for thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) by detecting changes in upper extremity oxygenation levels during artery or vein compression maneuvers. However, the relationship between TcpO2 and arterial stenosis is not well established. The purpose of this study was to investigate the relation between digital TcpO2 measurements and the degree of arterial stenosis using digital subtraction angiography in patients with TOS. METHODS: Forty‐two consecutive patients with TOS who underwent diagnostic arteriography were included in the study. TcpO2 measurements were obtained using a noninvasive bedside device (Integra 500P, Integra Life Sciences, Plainsboro, NJ, USA) at the distal palmar crease of both hands. Digital TcpO2 measurements were performed at resting and dynamic conditions. Patients with arterial stenosis ≥50% on arteriography were classified as "arterial stenosis group," and patients with normal arteriography were classified as "control group." The correlation between TcpO2 measurements and arterial stenosis was examined using nonparametric Spearman correlation analysis and multiple linear regression. The receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve was constructed to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of TcpO2 for arterial stenosis. RESULTS: TcpO2 measurements at resting conditions were not significantly different between the arterial stenosis and the control group. However, during dynamic compression of superficial veins with a Valsalva maneuver, the change in TcpO2 values was greater in the arterial stenosis group than in the control group (‐10.1 ± 8.7 vs. +2.2 ± 5.2, P = 0.015). Brief summary
=================
The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) versus standard of care dressings (control group) in preventing wound dehiscence in patients undergoing cardiac surgery requiring median sternotomy. It will be a prospective, single-center, non-randomized clinical trial with a pre-test post-test type I design. The study will include two groups: an intervention group (NPWT) and a control group (standard of care dressing). Participants will be evaluated at baseline and during the hospital stay up to 90 days. Wound healing complications, healing rate, dressing repair requirements, and length of hospital stay will be evaluated as outcomes.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: People with spinal cord injury experience numerous health problems, including low quality of life due to disability, physical inactivity, and low cardiorespiratory fitness. Complementary treatments, such as yoga therapy and physiotherapy, may have therapeutic benefits for this population. PURPOSE: The main aim of this study is to investigate whether the use of a virtual coaching approach improves physical activity, physical fitness, body composition, and quality of life in patients with fibromyalgia and sedentary behavior. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial; Virtual control: The virtual coaching intervention group will receive remote follow‐up for 12 weeks with support from a personal digital coach, including exercise recommendations, videos, and online resources. The intervention is divided into two phases: familiarization sessions (weeks 1‐2) and a 12‐wk. intervention (weeks 3‐14). The control group will participate in a conventional, in‐person rehabilitation program over 8 wks. It consists of three core components: physical activity including aerobic and resistance training, behavioral change interventions, and an educational component. The study assessments are conducted within 1 week before the start of the intervention (T0, baseline, prior to the intervention) and after 6 (T1) and 12 weeks (T2, end of the intervention) during the intervention phase, and after 24 weeks (T3, follow‐up) after the end of the intervention phase. SETTING: Physical medicine and rehabilitation hospital in Germany. POPULATION: The target population will comprise 88 patients with fibromyalgia identified by the 2016 ACR criteria, aged 18‐65 years, and with a Body Mass Index between 18.5 and 39.9 kg/m2. The study includes participants with fibromyalgia symptoms or diagnosed with fibromyalgia, no contraindications for yoga therapy or physiotherapy, willingness to use a smartphone, informed consent, and age over 18 years. Abstract:
Background: Musculoskeletal diseases such as osteoarthritis and ankylosing spondylitis are associated with pain, disability, and reduced participation in physical activity and work. It has become imperative to monitor these musculoskeletal conditions to provide accurate assessment and appropriate treatment strategies. Currently, there are limited and inconsistent outcome measures to evaluate the impact of these conditions on physical function in a valid and reliable manner. However, the Patient‐Reported Upper Limb Function (PRULF) is a novel patient‐reported outcome measure that has been developed to assess the self‐perceived change in upper limb function among patients with these conditions. Its validity, reliability, and responsiveness have been demonstrated in previous studies. Purpose: The aim of this study was to compare the psychometric properties of the French version of the PRULF and the French version of the Modified Ashworth Scale (FVS‐MAS) in patients with osteoarthritis and ankylosing spondylitis (AS) compared to healthy volunteers. Methods and Results: This cross‐sectional study involved a sample of 105 patients, 52 with osteoarthritis and 53 with AS. The FVS‐MAS was used to measure muscle stiffness, and the PRULF was used to evaluate the self‐perceived level of physical function. An internal consistency analysis revealed good reliability for both the FVS‐MAS (Cronbach's alpha = .64) and PRULF (Cronbach's alpha = .75). The FVS‐MAS had a mean score of 0 in the healthy group and 1.9 in the patient group, with a significant difference between groups (p < .001). Pearson's correlation analysis showed a significant positive correlation between the FVS‐MAS and PRULF scores for both the Osteoarthritis (r = 0.61, p < .001) and AS

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: This phase II study was performed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a new combination immunotherapy regimen for treatment‐resistant myeloma.METHODS: Patients were randomized to receive bortezomib, melphalan and prednisone for six 28‐day cycles (21‐days on and 7‐days off), followed (after 9 cycles) by maintenance of oral melphalan and prednisone until disease progression was detected. The primary objective was to evaluate overall response. Secondary objectives were overall survival, disease‐free and progression‐free survival, and frequency of toxicities.RESULTS: Forty patients were randomized (23 melphalan, 17 bortezomib). Response rate was 82.3% (95% CI, 67‐93.8%) after 9 cycles with no treatment‐related deaths. There was no progression in 15 patients, and median post‐transplantation survival was 24 months. The estimated median duration of maintenance‐free survival was 21.1 months. Although the study did not meet its primary end point of a 3 year progression‐free survival rate of 70%, the 3 year rate was still highly significant at 55.3% (P = 0.011).CONCLUSION: The novel bortezomib, melphalan and prednisone immunotherapy regimen represents a feasible and effective therapeutic strategy for relapsing myeloma.Tilan is a small molecule (MW 405) that acts as a selective and reversible inhibitor of PI3K. Great! We have covered all the outcome measures for your trial. Here is a summary of the full outcome measures:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Evolution of the axSPA global activity score (fatigue, pain, stiffness): Change in the BASDAI score, assessed via a self-administered questionnaire, between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Evolution of the axSPA global activity score (fatigue, pain, stiffness): Change in the BASDAI score, assessed via a self-administered questionnaire, between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Functional impact: Change in self-assessment of functional capacity during daily tasks using the BASFI score between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Health-related quality of life: Change in the patient's self-assessment via the SF-36 scale between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Anxiety and depression: Change in the patient's self-assessment via the HAD scale between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Respiratory capacity: Measurement of chest expansion between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Spinal and axial mobility (maximum active amplitudes - sagittal plane): Change in measurement of maximum active amplitudes in orthostatism of the thoraco-lumbar spine in the sagittal plane between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Spinal and axial mobility (degrees of kyphosis and lordosis): Change in measurement of the degrees of kyphosis and lordosis while standing between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Spinal and axial mobility (maximum active amplitudes - frontal plane): Change in measurement of maximum active amplitudes in orthostatism of the thoraco-lumbar spine in the frontal plane between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Spinal and axial mobility (podobarometric treadmill): Change in measurement of the spatiotemporal analysis of gait on a podobarometric treadmill between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Axial mobility: Change in BASMI score, reflecting the level of restriction in axial mobility, between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.

Abstract:
This paper discusses the effects of a virtual reality tool on pain management in hospitalized chronic pain patients. This tool allows patients to virtually experience activities that are unavailable to them due to their condition. During a randomized controlled trial, patients with chronic pain were randomly assigned to an experimental group or a control group, both of which received standard medical care. The experimental group had access to the virtual reality tool, while the control group did not. Outcomes of pain (pain intensity, perceived exacerbations in pain, interference with work‐related tasks, and pain‐related psychological features), use of resources, satisfaction with medical care, quality of life, level of anxiety and depression, emotional state (positive or negative affect), and patient‐doctor communication were evaluated. It was observed that patients in the experimental group experienced less pain (p = .005) compared to the control group. In addition, they showed a greater improvement in pain intensity (p < .001), a decrease In perceived exacerbations in pain (p = .004), and an increase in the pain threshold (p < .001). Also, the experimental group showed an increased level of satisfaction with their medical care (p = .012), and their perceived use of resources was significantly lower (p = .002). The experimental group also showed a significant reduction in anxiety levels (p = .033) and an increase in positive emotions (p = .039). The study concluded that the use of a virtual reality tool is a promising approach for pain management in chronic pain patients, improving their quality of life, emotional state, and communication with their health care providers.

Introduction
=================
Acupuncture is one of the oldest medical practices in the world. It is a form of therapy in which thin needles are inserted into specific points on the body to promote health and healing. There is growing evidence that acupuncture may be effective in treating a wide range of conditions, including fertility challenges. In fact, numerous studies have shown that acupuncture can improve the success rates of IVF treatment. However, it is still not clear exactly how acupuncture works to improve fertility in women with IVF. This is an exploratory study that aims to investigate the mechanisms underlying the beneficial effects of acupuncture on IVF outcomes. Study design
=================
This is a randomized, controlled trial that will be conducted at a single fertility center in China. The study will include 100 women who are undergoing IVF treatment. Of these, 50 women will receive acupuncture treatment in addition to their usual IVF protocol, while the other 50 women will receive standard care alone. The acupuncture treatment protocol will consist of 10 sessions of acupuncture over a 5 week period, beginning 1 week before the start of the IVF protocol. Study interventions
=================
Participants in the acupuncture group will receive acupuncture treatment in addition to their usual IVF treatment protocol. Acupuncture will be administered by trained acupuncturists using sterile, single-use needles. The needles will be inserted into specific points on the body that have been shown to promote fertility. The treatment protocol will consist of 10 sessions over a 5 week period, beginning 1 week before the start of the IVF protocol. The acupuncture sessions will last for 30 minutes each. Participants in the control group will receive standard care alone. After the study interventions have been completed, participants in both groups will undergo standard IVF treatment, which will include ovarian stimulation, egg retrieval, and embryo transfer. Outcome measures
=================
The primary outcome measure for this study will be the pregnancy rate, defined as the proportion of women who become pregnant after the IV

Introduction
Surgery, radiotherapy, and hormonal and cytotoxic therapy are the standard treatment modalities of prostate cancer (PCa); however, all can induce erectile dysfunction (ED) with impaired quality of life in cancer survivors. Recently, a new, non-invasive treatment based on non-surgical ultrasound techniques such as low intensity shock waves (LiSWT) was developed for restoring penile haemodynamics and improving erectile function (EF). We are currently enrolling in prospective, randomized, 
sham controlled (RCT) and open-label clinical trials (NCT03976561). In the SHRUB study, we are aiming to obtain evidence of the effect of 8 weekly sessions of LiSWT on EF by using an innovative, validated, smartphone-based questionnaire (Smart Prostate) and the erection hardness score (EHS). This methodological design makes the SHRUB-Study unique, as it aims to test the effect of LiSWT on daily sexual performance of patients with ED under treatment for PCa.
To date, studies investigating the effect of LiSWT on EF are limited, and most have used placebo controls by either using sham stimulation or a placebo device, so their findings lack statistical power in terms of the effect size. This pilot study aims to evaluate the effect of our LiSWT technology on EF using the Smart Prostate questionnaire, an innovative tool that was designed specifically for this trial and provides an accurate and reliable analysis of the patients’ daily erection patterns and sexual activity. The SHRUB-Study will be conducted at the Erectile Function Center of the University Hospital of Heidelberg, Germany.

Study Objective
The aim of the study is to evaluate and compare the efficacy, safety, tolerance, and durability of weekly low intensity shock waves (LiSWT, Swiss Dolor Clast, SDCC) on ED of PCa patients following radical radiotherapy by using a new, smartphone-based questionnaire (Smart Prostate) and the erection hardness score (

Abstract:
PURPOSE: To compare the surgical outcomes of the conventional and the posterior approach for the removal of the sacrocolpopexy using a dome‐shaped and double V‐shaped mesh. METHODS: A prospective, single‐institution, randomized study was performed. A dome‐shaped and double V‐shaped mesh were used in the conventional and posterior approach groups. Sixty‐six women with a prolapse of the POP‐quantification (POP‐Q) stage II or higher, underwent an abdominal laparoscopic sacrocolpopexy in this study. The POP‐Q measurements were performed preoperatively and 6 months postoperatively. The operative time and complication rates were recorded. Data were compared between the groups. RESULTS: The conventional and the posterior approach groups totaled 33 and 33 women, respectively. The difference among the POP‐Q stage values was statistically significant with respect to the three‐point evaluation of the descensus stage, Apex stage, and Total stage at 6 months postoperatively. The difference among the POP‐Q stage values of the Apex stage was statistically significant preoperatively. CONCLUSION: A better apical support can be achieved with the double V‐shape mesh by use of the posterior approach as compared to the dome‐shaped mesh via the conventional approach.

model_response: The Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC) is a self-reported questionnaire that measures pain, stiffness, and disability due to osteoarthritis. It consists of 24 items and takes approximately 5-10 minutes to complete. The questionnaire assesses pain, stiffness, and disability in three subscales, which can be evaluated separately or summed up to provide a score for total function. It has been widely used in clinical trials and has shown good reliability and validity in measuring functional limitations in patients with osteoarthritis.

Abstract:
Background: The objective of this randomised single‐blinded study was to compare the effects of vibration therapy or conventional quadriceps training (QT), in patients with knee osteoarthritis. The secondary outcomes in this study included muscle strength using the handgrip dynamometer (in kg) and muscle activity by means of electromyography (in µV). Results: We performed in total 81 evaluations and included 75% power (80% if possible) and a two‐sided alpha level of 5%. After 30 minutes of application, vibration and QT demonstrated significant differences compared with the baseline. The vibration therapy group presented a higher muscle activity than the conventional QT and control groups throughout the training period. The conventional QT and vibration groups presented significant muscle strength increases compared with the baseline. Conclusion: The application of vibration therapy and QT can be combined as an ergogenic aid in the treatment of knee osteoarthritis without adverse effects.

Abstract:
Currently, little is known about what causes the low treatment response and poor prognosis of patients with advanced head and neck cancer. Aim: To analyze the prognostic factors for the treatment response. Methods: The medical records of 104 patients with advanced head and neck cancer who underwent radiotherapy between 2014 and 2018 were retrospectively reviewed. Clinical characteristics were evaluated, and the prognostic factors for the primary objectives were explored by using univariate and multivariate analyses. Results: The two‐ and five‐year local control rates were 0.30% and 0.21%. The two‐ and five‐year disease‐free survival (DFS) rates were 10.92% and 8.59%. The two‐ and five‐year progression‐free survival (PFS) rates were 6.35% and 5.29%. The two‐ and five‐year overall survival (OS) rates were 22.86% and 10.96%, respectively. On univariate analysis, high T stage, positive lymph nodes, advanced N stage, smoking, a high tumor grade, and the lack of previous treatment were associated with poor DFS (P < 0.05). Multivariate analysis identified only tumor grade as an independent prognostic factor for DFS (P = 0.030). In the multivariate analysis, advanced N stage, the lack of previous radiotherapy. (P = 0.002) and tumor grade were predictive factors of PFS. The OS analysis identified advanced N stage, high T stage, a high tumor grade, and the lack of previous treatment as independent risk factors for poor survival. Conclusion: For patients with poor prognosis (high T stage, advanced N stage, or advanced tumor grade), a novel treatment for head and neck cancer is required to improve survival.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to assess the quality of evidence and certainty in relation to clinical and economic outcomes from studies related to the clinical practice of total joint arthroplasty.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Four interventional clinical trials and five preliminary economic evaluation studies have been identified for this study. The economic analyses will be completed by the investigators once the corresponding clinical trial manuscripts have been published. The quality of economic evaluation studies that relate to the clinical practice of total joint replacement (hip and/or knee) will be assessed using the Checklist for Reporting a Health Economic Evaluation (CHEERIE). The data for these will be collected via the CHEERIE Checklist. The study population consists of the authors of primary economic evaluation studies that report health and economic outcomes from randomized controlled trials (RCTs). Outcomes for patients (quality-adjusted life years, health-related quality of life, hospital length of stay, costs, and cost-effectiveness) will be collected. For patients reporting pain scores, an improvement of 30% is clinically important. Outcomes for health care payers (costs) will be compared based on unit cost estimates extracted from the studies (e.g., cost per quality-adjusted life year (QALY)). Study results will compare the difference between groups and the percentage of studies in which at least 80% of patients showed moderate to marked pain relief, were cost-effective, and/or were highly clinically recommended.

Motion sparing fusion with only one (metallic) intramedullary implant (e.g. interspinous cage, interbody cage, endoscopy instruments, etc.);

Abstract:
Post‐partum contraceptive (PPC) methods provide a unique opportunity to understand drug metabolism and drug metabolizing enzymes (DMEs) in pregnancy, and can inform drug‐drug interactions (DDIs) and drug safety. Aims: Phenytoin is a widely‐used antiepileptic and inhibits multiple drug‐metabolizing enzymes. Procedural risk assessment for PPC failure may be facilitated with a test compound that serves as a probe DDI. The CYP2B6 probe drug rufinamide is in late stage development but has never been studied in women of childbearing potential (WOCBP). We performed a randomized open‐label, three‐period crossover pharmacokinetic (PK) trial to assess PK of rufinamide and its potential to determine DME capacity in young women taking phenytoin. Methods: WOCBP taking phenytoin were randomized to receive intravenous (IV) boluses of rufinamide in one of three periods. On another day, the woman received a non‐pharmacokinetic procedure to determine her non‐reproducible phenytoin levels. Results: In 34 young women, the rufinamide PK profile after IV dosing was similar to that in non‐pregnant adults. For the same IV rufinamide dose, mean rufinamide area under the curve (AUCinf) and Cmax were significantly higher in women taking high dose phenytoin compared to women taking lower dose phenytoin and women not taking phenytoin, indicating that CYP2B6 was likely inhibited in 6 women (median Cmax of >250ng/mL) and saturated in 5 women. The AUCratio (ratio of rufinamide AUCin pregnant women to that in non‐pregnant adults) was 2.0 ± 0.

Brief summary
=================
Spinal fusion is a common surgical procedure used to stabilize spinal deformities and disorders, with more than 400,000 procedures performed annually worldwide. Devices used during these surgeries include, but are not limited to, Advanced Energy, Robotics and Navigation, Interbodies and Biologics, Other Spinal Hardware, and/or Rods and Screws. Medtronic is currently developing and/or marketing these devices to assist surgeons performing spinal surgery. Medtronic is interested in learning about the use of these devices for spinal fusion surgery. Therefore, Medtronic is sponsoring a study to monitor the performance of these devices when used in spinal fusion surgery. Subjects in this study undergo spinal fusion surgery and will be followed up to 5 years post-procedure depending on the device(s) used.

The secondary outcome measures include complications related to the device(s). This will be assessed over the duration of the study by tracking and recording all device-related complications that occur during surgery, up to 24 months post-procedure, and 12 months after device removal. The investigator will perform any necessary revisions and make any relevant reports. Additionally, the investigator will report to Medtronic any implant-related surgical issues that occur during or following surgery.

Wonderful! Here are the full outcome measures for the clinical trial:

Primary Outcome Measures:
1. Surgical success (for any Medtronic eligible market-released Advanced Energy device(s) used): Defined by amount of blood loss, total operation time, length of stay in the hospital, and investigator opinion on device assistance. Assessed up to 24 months.
2. Fusion success (for any Medtronic eligible market-released Interbodies and Biologics, Other Spinal Hardware, and/or Rods and Screws device(s) used): Assessed at 12 months using radiographic evidence.
3. Surgical performance (for any Medtronic eligible market-released Powered Systems, Instruments, and Imaging device(s) used): Rate at which the device directly assists in the completion of surgery. Assessed at the index surgery.
4. Device performance (for any Medtronic eligible market-released Robotics and Navigation device(s) used): Planned number of screws compared to screws device assisted with placement. Validation of screw placement for navigation devices. Assessed up to 24 months.
5. Deformity correction (for any Medtronic eligible market-released Spinal Tethers device(s) used): Defined by change of Cobb angle at 12 months and up to 24 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Rate of device-related adverse events (for any Medtronic eligible market-released Cranial & Spinal Technologies (CST) device(s) used): Aligned with ISO 14155 standards. Assessed up to 24 months.
2. Stabilization (for any Medtronic eligible market-released device(s) used from the following product groups: Interbodies and Biologics, Other Spinal Hardware, Rods and Screws): Assessed up to 12 months through radiographic evidence.
3. Deformity correction (for specified Medtronic eligible market-released device(s) used from the Rods and Screws product group): Change of Cobb angle at the 12-month postoperative visit compared to baseline. Assessed up to 12 months.

Loss of appetite, poor intestinal function, etc., often occur after major abdominal surgery, which leads to poor postoperative recovery of patients, and increases the incidence of postoperative complications. Most patients in the inpatient ward have a meal of 12 hours after surgery. However, this is a very long period of time for patients who have just undergone surgery, and it is easy to cause delayed gastric emptying, intestinal obstruction and other complications. Therefore, in this study, early supplementary parenteral nutrition will be used, and patients still have a certain degree of hunger after surgery, and it is suitable to continue oral nutrition intake. It can improve their intestinal function and improve the nutritional status of patients, effectively avoiding postoperative complications, reducing treatment costs in hospitals, and reducing the medical burden on patients.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The role of robotics in rehabilitation following stroke is still limited by the lack of robust evidence on its effectiveness. This study aims to assess the effects of Upper Extremity (UE) Rehabilitation robot‐assisted therapy (RA) vs. conventional Upper Extremity (UE) therapy on UE motor function, disability, and quality of life in patients with chronic stroke. METHODS: A two‐site randomized controlled trial design will be used. Thirty stable chronic stroke patients will randomized to receive either UE RA vs. conventional UE therapy in addition to standard occupational therapy for 40 session within six weeks. The UE motor function would be assessed by the Fugl‐Meyer (FM‐UE), Wolf Motor Function Test (WMFT), Modified Ashworth scale (MAS), Box and Block Test (BBT), Movement imagery questionnaire‐Revised (MIQ‐R) before and immediately after intervention and at the three‐month follow‐up. To evaluate the motor control, the FM‐UE would be re‐assessed with the patients' eyes closed at the same sessions. The disability would be assessed by the FIM scale, the Rivermead assessment of motor impairation, and the Barthel index. The quality of life would be measured by the Korean version of Stroke Impact Scale (K‐SIS) at the three‐month follow‐up. DISCUSSION: This study would be the first

The other secondary outcome measure can be the number of participants satisfied with the robotic rehabilitation. INTRODUCTION:
Stroke is a leading cause of disability worldwide, affecting over 85 million people globally and causing long-term disabilities in approximately half of its survivors. Robotic rehabilitation (RR) provides an innovative approach to physical therapy by providing repetitive, structured, and intensive training in a controlled environment. The benefits of RR include improved functional outcomes, reduced pain, and improved quality of life. However, the acceptability and satisfaction of using RR devices for stroke patients remains unclear. To address this gap, we propose to conduct a prospective study to evaluate the experiences and perspectives of stroke patients and physiotherapists using RR devices. The study aims to quantify the acceptance and satisfaction levels with RR devices, collect qualitative feedback on RR device usage, and explore the correlations between satisfaction levels and outcomes. 
METHODS:
The study will involve both qualitative and quantitative components. The study design will include a cross-sectional survey and a longitudinal intervention study. To quantify acceptance and satisfaction levels, we will use semi-structured surveys and questionnaires to collect data. For the qualitative component, we will conduct semi-structured interviews to collect in-depth feedback on the RR intervention from both stroke patients and physiotherapists. The study will be conducted at the Rehabilitation Department of a university hospital in Turkey. For patient recruitment, we will approach stroke patients undergoing physical therapy and physiotherapy professionals. The inclusion criteria for patients will include a diagnosis of stroke, no prior RR exposure, and an ability to provide informed consent. The inclusion criteria for therapists will include a minimum of two years of experience in stroke rehabilitation and an ability to provide informed consent. Data collection will be conducted during a single visit to the clinic. 
RESULTS:
The preliminary data from the study demonstrated a high level of acceptance and satisfaction with robotic rehabilitation among both patient and therapist groups. Our findings revealed that the majority of patients (85%) and therapists (90%) reported high acceptability and satisfaction levels with the RR intervention.

Yes, certainly! AUC and Cmax will help us assess the bioequivalence of the two formulations. 
The area under the curve (AUC) is a measure of the total amount of Lamotrigine in the bloodstream over a specific period of time. It can help us determine if the two formulations deliver the same amount of drug to the body. 
The maximal plasma concentration (Cmax) is the highest concentration of Lamotrigine in the bloodstream at any time during the dosing interval. It can help us determine if the two formulations deliver the same maximum drug concentration to the body. 
Both of these measures are important for assessing bioequivalence because they provide information about the drug's absorption, distribution, and elimination from the body.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Neuroglide is a novel mobile application that uses virtual reality technology to help people relax, reduce stress and anxiety. The Neuroglide app aims to provide a calming and immersive experience with 360° spherical visuals and binaural audio sounds. The Neuroglide app uses a scientific method based on research to provide a relaxing and healing experience. The app features two types of relaxation programs: a single short session and a longer session designed with sleep in mind. To create the Neuroglide app, the investigator conducted a literature review to identify optimal frequencies for sleep, relaxation, and stress reduction. This literature review led to the identification of the three most common frequencies for relaxation: 10 Hz, 14 Hz, and 18 Hz. The Neuroglide app uses these frequencies to create a harmonious and immersive experience. To ensure that the Neuroglide app is effective, the investigator conducted a pilot study with 20 healthy participants. The results of this study showed that the Neuroglide app reduces stress and anxiety and can be used to support sleep.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The Neuroglide app is a new kind of application that uses 360° virtual reality technology to help people relax on their own time and in their own environment. The purpose of Neuroglide is to create an immersive and relaxing experience through a customized app with 360° spherical visuals and customized binaural audio sounds. The app is designed so that you can use it anytime, anywhere, and is available for both iOS and Android devices. The Neuroglide app is designed for anyone who wants to relax, reduce stress, and improve their overall mood. It is especially useful for people who suffer from anxiety, depression, or stress-related conditions. You will be sent a 16GB SD card containing videos and audio files to your email address

The Visual Analog Scale (VAS) is a simple, non-invasive tool that is commonly used to assess pain levels in patients. It consists of a 100-millimetre (mm) line with no marked units, where the left end represents no pain and the right end represents the worst pain imaginable . Patients indicate their pain level by marking their response on the line . The distance from the left end of the line is then measured in mm to provide a quantitative measure of the patient's pain level. This measure can be taken at different time points, such as at baseline, during Neuroglide treatment, and 1 hour after PCT treatment, to evaluate the effect of the intervention on pain levels over time. There are few studies evaluating the effectiveness of newer oral anticoagulants (OACs) during the early post-operative period after ablation of AF, and there are no studies evaluating their effectiveness when treatment is initiated pre-operatively . OACs are recommended for all patients with non-valvular AF with at least one risk factor in the latest European Society of Cardiology (ESC) guidelines. However, in addition to the benefits of OAC therapy, there are also some concerns, such as a higher risk of bleeding during the early post-operative period. As a result, there is a significant interest in pre-operative anti-thrombotic prophylaxis.

The dysbiosis index is a 5-scale index that measures the imbalance in gut microbiota composition. A DI above 2 indicates a microbiota profile that differs significantly from a normobiotic reference collection. Higher values on the index indicate more severe dysbiosis. Assessing the dysbiosis index at the 12-month mark after FMT would provide valuable insights into the impact of fecal microbiota transplantation on restoring a healthy gut microbiota composition in patients with IBS.

Abstract:
Background: We hypothesized that preoperative intravenous administration of dexmedetomidine decreases postoperative opioid consumption and morphine requirements in patients submitted to total knee arthroplasty. This study was the aim to evaluate the efficacy of intravenous dexmedetomidine as a bolus followed by a continuous infusion. Methods: Patients were randomly assigned to either a study group that received a loading intravenous bolus of dexmedetomidine (0.5 µg/kg) followed by a continuous infusion of 0.3 µg/kg per hour (n = 30) or a control group that received a loading intravenous bolus of normal saline followed by a continuous infusion of normal saline (n = 30). The primary outcome measure was opioid consumption in the first 24 postoperative hours. Morphine requirements for the first 24 postoperative hours were determined by the area under the curve (AUC) as a secondary outcome measure. Perioperative complications and adverse events were also recorded. Results: Total opioid consumption was significantly lower in the study group than in the control group (98.7 vs. 151.5 mg; P = 0.012). Furthermore, the AUC for morphine was also significantly lower in the experimental group than in the control group (585.54 vs. 901.4 mg; P = 0.003). There were no significant intergroup differences in hemodynamic variables. Conclusions: Preoperative intravenous administration of dexmedetomidine decreased postoperative opioid consumption after total knee arthroplasty, highlighting the positive effects of this drug in a perioperative context. Copyright © 2016 Elsevier Inc.

Abstract:
Rationale: In patients at increased cardiovascular risk, colchicine reduces major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) after non‐cardiac surgery. Methods: In a double‐blind, randomised, placebo‐controlled study, we investigated whether colchicine can also prevent peri‐operative myocardial injury or events after non‐cardiac surgery. Patients with a history of coronary artery disease or multiple risk factors received colchicine or placebo in the early postoperative period. We aimed to recruit 1000 participants. Main outcomes: The primary outcome was peri‐operative myocardial injury, defined as a ≥14 ng/l increase in high sensitivity C‐Reactive protein (hs‐cTnT) from baseline. Secondary outcomes were MACE, as well as new‐onset atrial fibrillation. Results: Out of 3305 participants, we recruited 1537 and 1520 participants to the colchicine or placebo group, respectively. In the overall study population, peri‐operative hs‐cTnT increase (primary outcome) occurred in 26.9% of the patients, of whom 22.6% also had an increase in cardiac troponin I. Peri‐operative myocardial injury was associated with a longer hospital stay, higher mortality and more complications, but it did not predict an adverse outcome or mortality 90 days after surgery. Conclusion: Colchicine therapy after major non‐cardiac surgery did not prevent peri‐operative myocardial injury or MACE. Although the study is underpowered and a further assessment on the benefit of colchicine needs to be done, the findings may lead to the development of new targets to modify the peri‐operative cardiovascular risk.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Major Adverse Cardiovascular Events: Assess the proportion of patients developing MACE, including acute coronary syndrome, new/worsening congestive heart failure, coronary revascularization, stroke, all-cause mortality, and cardiovascular death. Time frame: until the 30th postoperative day.
2. New Onset Atrial Fibrillation: Assess the proportion of patients developing new-onset atrial fibrillation. Time frame: from the beginning of surgery until the 30th postoperative day or discharge.
3. Postoperative high sensitive cardiac Troponin T concentrations: Compare postoperative hs-cTnT concentrations between study groups. Monitor until the fourth postoperative day.
4. Long-term cardiovascular outcome: Assess the proportion of patients developing MACE as a marker of long-term postoperative outcome. Time frame: until 1 year after surgery.

Abstract:
To evaluate the pharmacokinetics, safety, and bioequivalence of an experimental formulation of mequitazine (MK‐877) to its reference formulation (MK‐877). This was a randomized, 2‐phase, crossover study in healthy adult subjects. Subjects (n = 12) received orally a single 12 and 24 mg dose of MK‐877 at the beginning of each phase. Mean PK parameters were well within the 80% to 125% required by the FDA for establishing bioequivalence. The observed geometric mean ratios ranged from 0.91 to 1.13. A sensitivity analysis on geometric mean ratios was performed, using unchanged values based on Ctrough. This revealed that the adjusted geometric mean ratios remained within the requirements and further supported the results obtained from the covariance analysis. Safety was determined by adverse event assessments that determined no clinically meaningful differences between the 2 doses of the study medication.

This measure evaluates the non-adjusted and baseline-adjusted PK parameters for nicotine, including the peak plasma concentration of nicotine and its active metabolites. As with the previous measures, it will be assessed at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use. [/SUB]

Abstract:
Aims and Objectives: Many tobacco products are known to contain nicotine or nicotine‐related alkaloids. The aim of this study was to compare blood nicotine levels of smokers of conventional cigarettes with smokeless and nicotine‐free cigarettes. Backgroud: No studies have compared the blood nicotine level induced by smokeless cigarettes and conventional cigarettes.Methods: Smokers who smoked 1‐10 cigarettes a day volunteered in this study. The test was performed in randomized order. Participants smoked 7 cigarettes of each type in each session. Blood samples were obtained 20 min after smoking the first 3 cigarettes, every 30 min after that until time of the Cmax, and after 8h. Blood samples were analyzed for nicotine, e‐nicotine, and their metabolites, cotinine, and the nicotine/cotinine ratio. Results: Plasma cotinine levels induced by conventional cigarettes (1.57±0.06μg/mL) were significantly higher than those induced by smokeless cigarettes (0.81±0.02μg/mL) and nicotine‐free cigarettes (0.05±0.05μg/mL) (p<0.05). Plasma cotinine induction levels of smokeless cigarettes were significantly higher than those of nicotine‐free cigarettes (p<0.05). Conclusion: Smokeless cigarettes have the potential to reduce the risk for second‐hand.

Excellent. Now, let's discuss the primary outcome measures for your study. Based on the information you've provided, there are several primary outcome measures. The first one is the AUC from timepoint 0 to infinity (AUCinf). This measure assesses the non-adjusted and baseline-adjusted PK parameters for nicotine, including the area under the curve from timepoint 0 to infinity. It will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Another primary outcome measure is the AUC from timepoint 0 to timepoint t (AUC0-t). This measure evaluates the non-adjusted and baseline-adjusted PK parameters for nicotine, including the area under the curve from timepoint 0 to a specific timepoint. Similar to the previous measure, it will be assessed at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Yes, there are a few more primary outcome measures we should consider. The AUC from timepoint 0 to 30 minutes (AUC0-30min) and AUC from timepoint 0 to 60 minutes (AUC0-60min) are important measures for assessing the early exposure and bioavailability of nicotine. They will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Both Cmax and Tmax are important primary outcome measures. Cmax assesses the maximum plasma concentration of nicotine achieved after IP use, while Tmax measures the time it takes to reach the maximum plasma concentration. These measures provide insights into the rate of absorption and the peak exposure of nicotine. They will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Certainly. The first secondary outcome measure is the in vivo extracted amount (mg/unit) of nicotine for each investigational product. This measure helps evaluate the efficiency of nicotine delivery and the consistency of nicotine content in the pouches. It will be assessed at visits 2 to 4.

Another secondary outcome measure is the in vivo extracted fraction (%) of nicotine for each investigational product. This measure provides information on the bioavailability and release characteristics of nicotine from the pouches. It will also be evaluated at visits 2 to 4.

Yes, there are a few more secondary outcome measures. We should assess the highest recorded increase (Emax) in pulse rate from baseline, which helps evaluate the acute physiological effects of nicotine on cardiovascular function. Additionally, we should measure the mean score for each palatability question 30 minutes after the start of IP use, which provides insights into taste, flavor, and overall user experience. We should also evaluate urge-to-use, product-liking, intent-to-use-again, and onset-of-effect after IP use to assess user satisfaction and behavioral responses. Finally, we should monitor the frequency, seriousness, and intensity of adverse events (AEs) to ensure participant safety throughout the study.

Abstract:
Objective: As a result of progress in the treatment of diabetes mellitus, the incidence of hypoglycemia, especially severe hypoglycemia, often becomes the limiting factor for intensification of treatment and achievement of recommended blood glucose (BG) levels. The aim of the study was to estimate the effectiveness in the prevention of severe hypoglycemic episodes of a single dose of a glucagon preparation (Rapiglucagon) stored at room temperature. Material and methods: The study comprised a randomized multicenter double‐blind placebo‐controlled clinical trial. Patients with type 1 diabetes treated with continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion (CSII) were divided into two groups with an unequal sample size. One hundred and twenty six patients were randomly assigned to either the intervention or the control group. In the intervention group, the patients received at each meal a preparation with glucagon in the form of dry powder containing 3 mg of glucagon; in the control group, patients received an equivalent dose of placebo. The primary outcome measure was a reduction in the frequency of hypoglycemic episodes in the intervention group and in the control group. Results: Among the studied patients, 78 (62.0%) were assigned to the intervention group, and 48 (38.0%) were assigned to the control group. There was a significant decrease in the frequency of severe hypoglycemic episodes in the intervention group in comparison with the control group: 3.30 ± 4.06 episodes in the intervention group and 7.14 ± 7.73 episodes in the control group (p = 0.0240). There was also a significant decrease in the risk of developing a hypoglycemic episode among patients in the intervention group in comparison with the control group: RR = 0.42 [95% CI 0.16–0.89], p = 0.0240. Conclusion: As far as we know, the results of this study are the first that show the efficacy of glucagon tablets in preventing severe hypoglycemic episodes.

Abstract:
Background: Pediatric burns are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and the choice of fluid therapy is crucial for effective treatment. Albumin is a protein found in the blood that plays a vital role in maintaining the circulation of fluids, and its administration has been shown to improve patient outcomes in burn patients. Methods: This study aimed to assess the effects of albumin administration in pediatric burn patients undergoing resuscitation with crystalloids. The study population was pediatric burn patients of 5‐15 years of age, who required at least 20% burn surface area. Patients were randomized into two groups: albumin group (receiving albumin in addition to crystalloids) and crystalloid group (receiving crystalloids only). The primary outcome was the resuscitation volume on day 2 of admission, and the secondary outcomes included requirements of inotropic support and mortality. Results: A total of 100 patients were enrolled, 50 in each group. The median (interquartile range) resuscitation volume was 7.8 (5.0‐12.1) ml/kg/% burn surface area in the albumin group and 9.6 (6.5‐14.0) ml/kg/% burn surface area in the crystalloid group (p = 0.01). Changes in liver enzymes, such as ALT and AST, were included as secondary outcome measures because they provide additional information on liver function. ALT and AST are commonly used markers for detecting liver damage and inflammation, so they can help assess the impact of SIM01 on liver health. Moreover, elevated levels of ALT and AST are associated with an increased risk of liver fibrosis and cirrhosis, making these markers valuable in monitoring disease progression. 

Changes in fasting lipid and HbA1c levels were included as secondary outcome measures because they can provide insights into the impact of SIM01 on metabolic health. Fasting lipid levels, such as total cholesterol, triglycerides, and high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, are important markers of cardiovascular risk. HbA1c is a marker of long-term blood glucose control and is related to the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus. 

Changes in body mass index (BMI), body waist circumference, and interleukin-6 (IL-6) levels were included as secondary outcome measures because they provide information on anthropometric measures, obesity, and immune response. BMI is a commonly used measure of obesity, and a high BMI is a risk factor for NAFLD. Body waist circumference is a measure of abdominal obesity, which is closely associated with insulin resistance and liver damage. IL-6 is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that is elevated in NAFLD and is implicated in the development of liver fibrosis. 

Overall, the secondary outcome measures provide valuable information on the impact of SIM01 on various aspects of liver function, metabolic health, body weight management, and immune response. Together, these measurements provide a comprehensive evaluation of the effects of SIM01 on female subjects with NAFLD.

Changes in fasting lipid and HbA1c levels were included as secondary outcome measures because they provide insight into improvements in metabolic health and glycemic control. Metabolic dysfunction is common in NAFLD patients, and the observed changes in lipid and HbA1c levels can indicate potential improvements in these areas.

The study will measure the changes in lipid profiles and HbA1c levels after 3 months of taking SIM01. This time frame allows for a sufficient duration to observe potential changes in metabolic function. It aligns with the study's goal of assessing the short-term effects of SIM01 on metabolic parameters in NAFLD patients.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The goal of this research study is to better understand how long it takes for HIV to develop in the body of a patient treated with a PrEP drug. Participants need to be healthy, have no HIV infection, and must agree to take the PrEP medication every day for at least 5.5 years. Participants also must not start antiretroviral therapy (ART) for at least 1 year, unless HIV is observed in blood in both standard lab tests (not blood taken from participants). This is an effort to collect more data about the timing of HIV spread in the body, a step toward understanding the effectiveness of PrEP drugs.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Further understanding how long it takes for HIV to develop in uninfected, human cells is important in the evaluation of antiretroviral medications and their use as prophylactics. This study evaluates an investigational drug (FTC-TDF) that is being studied as a treatment, and possibly as a cure, for HIV infection. The medication is approved by FDA for use as PrEP. It is taken by individuals to prevent contracting HIV. The study has been divided into two phases. There is an initial study, Preexposure Prophylaxis for Uninfected Volunteers (PREPARE), and a subsequent, long-term study called the Prep Plus Initiative (P+). This study, a substudy of P+, follows a small number of P+ participants (volunteers) over time. As P+ volunteers reach certain timepoints over a 5.5-year period (approximately 6, 12 and 60 months), they will collect blood samples or, in some cases, provide additional blood samples, at which time their participation in this study will end. The duration of time that these volunteers are followed will allow us to see if HIV spreads in the body, and how soon it spreads. Because HIV is a retrovirus, this research will involve repeated blood draws. This study is currently recruiting participants.

Abstract:
To assess the potential benefits of treatment with sertraline in patients with bipolar I disorder (BDI) and cognitive symptoms. One hundred eleven patients were evaluated pre‐therapeutically and after 1 week and 4 weeks of treatment in a randomized double‐blind design. Forty‐three patients were randomized to the sertraline group, while 35 patients were randomized to the placebo group. The primary endpoint was "cognitive symptom severity". The mean score of the MADRS‐Cog 11, as well as cognitive capacity, was significantly reduced in the sertraline group (P = 0.036). In the placebo group, we found no significant changes in these parameters. In the sertraline group, serotonin and dopamine transporter binding capacity, assessed by SPECT, significantly increased after 1 week (P < 0.001) and 4 weeks (P = 0.009). In contrast, serotonin and dopamine binding capacity did not change in the placebo group during the study. We conclude that sertraline improves cognitive capacity in patients with an acute manic or hypomanic episode of BDI, possibly by increasing SERT and DAT binding capacity.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
B-12 is a naturally occurring vitamin that is a methyl-donor and folate is the major methyl donor in the body. Methylation is essential for many biochemical reactions involved in the normal functioning of the body. The body's capacity to methylate in adults decreases with aging. Several studies also suggest that levels of folate and B-12 can be below the recommended levels in elderly people. B-12 deficiency has been linked to neurodegenerative diseases and poor memory. Studies have shown that folate and B-12 deficiency may also be linked to the Alzheimer's disease pathophysiology. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of high dose and folate plus B-12 combination compared to folic acid alone or placebo therapy in elderly people with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and normal B-12 levels who are at risk for Alzheimer's disease. Participants in the study will be randomly assigned to receive intramuscular (IM) injections of active B-12, folate and B-12 in combination (active treatment), folate and placebo B-12 injections (placebo treatment), or placebo injections (placebo treatment). Participants will be treated for six weeks and will be evaluated at three months.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Individuals eligible for treatment will be randomly assigned to receive either a B-12 injection and folic acid, or a folic acid injection and placebo B-12 (control), or placebo injections (randomization in a 1:1:1 ratio) every week for six weeks after the baseline visit. After six weeks of therapy, all participants will be evaluated with clinical tests and blood tests for neurodegenerative markers and methylation (folate, B-12).

Abstract:
Introduction: Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorders are common in patients with myofascial pain and limited mandibular movement, so it is important to perform early diagnosis and treatment to avoid irreversible joint damage. A high temperature and electrical stimulation (HTE) device produces far‐infrared and 700 Hz low‐intensity pulsed voltage that activate the TMJ and periodontal ligament, thereby decreasing pain and enhancing joint movement. However, there is a lack of studies on the use of HTE for patients with TMJ disorders. Objectives: To determine whether HTE can improve TMJ movements and pain and the degree of dental occlusion in patients with primary TMJ disorders that are resistant to non‐invasive interventions over a period of 6 weeks. Materials and Methods: Patients with primary TMJ disorders who were resistant to non‐invasive treatment were divided into two groups: experimental (n = 10) and control (n = 10). The treatment group was given HTE therapy, and the control group was given a placebo intervention. Both groups wore splints, received physical therapy, and participated in weekly follow‐up visits for 4 weeks. Outcomes 30, 60, and 120 days after the treatment were measured, and improvements in TMJ movement, pain, and occlusion were compared between the two groups. Results: Compared with the placebo group, the experimental group showed significant improvements in TMJ movements (p < 0.05), pain (p < 0.05), and occlusion (p < 0.05). Conclusions: The results of this study indicate that HTE therapy can improve TMJ movement, pain, and occlusion in patients with primary TMJ disorders that are resistant to non‐invasive interventions and can be used as a reliable therapeutic option. Abstract:
Rationale: Cumulative evidence in animal and human studies suggests an involvement of the default mode network (DMN) and its dysfunction in the aging brain. In humans, several studies have shown that the aging brain is characterized by specific alterations in DMN function. Moreover, there is evidence that stimulation of the occipital cortex with rTMS and cathodal tDCS can reduce the intensity of DMN activation during resting state. To date the majority of interventional studies used clinical populations (i.e. AD). In this study we will assess the cognitive and clinical effects of occipital cathodal tDCS to assess cognitive functions in AD patients. The primary aim is to compare the effect of sham and real stimulation on the intensity of DMN (at the group and individual level) in an early diagnostic stage of AD. A secondary aim is to assess the effect of real and sham stimulation to assess cognitive functions. Methods: AD patients (n=38), with mild cognitive impairment, will be recruited by the medical unit. Patients will be randomly assigned sham or real stimulation in 2 (2.5mA, 2MHz) sessions lasting 15' with a one‐week interval. Primary outcome measure: Change in functional connectivity of DMN at the group level on rs‐fMRI following real‐tDCS compared to sham‐tDCS in AD patients. DMN is defined based on the meta‐analytic results of Shu et al. (2009). Secondary outcome measure: Change in activation of cortical regions involved in the cognitive function of interest at pre‐test and post‐test on fMRI. Abstract:
Background and aims: Recent evidence suggests that Alzheimer's Disease (AD) is a complex dynamic syndrome involving brain network interactions as opposed to disease‐specific processes within isolated brain regions. Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) can modulate activity in target brain areas and disrupt network connectivity. This project investigates the effects of repetitive TMS (rTMS) on functional connectivity of the default mode network (DMN) in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) due to AD. Methods: 18 APOE4positive patients with MCI due to AD and 18 matched healthy controls were enrolled. Each participant underwent baseline functional connectivity MRI (fMRI) and resting‐state TMS‐EEG. All participants received a four‐day course of real‐rTMS or sham‐rTMS, which consisted of 15 daily 25‐min sessions. Afterward, functional connectivity MRI and TMS‐EEG were repeated. Data processing and analysis will be used to assess the effects of rTMS on functional connectivity measures. Discussion: We hypothesize that a four‐day course of real‐rTMS will improve DMN connectivity compared to sham‐rTMS, especially in APOE4positive patients with MCI due to AD. Conclusions: This study will provide further understanding of the inter‐regional network interactions in Alzheimer's disease and may provide insight into the development of more effective treatments. 2016 Elsevier Ltd. and AIHF. All rights reserved.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: LGBT+ individuals in Turkey face discrimination and unfair treatment in the healthcare system. OBJECTIVE: To estimate Obstetrics and Gynecology residents and experts' knowledge, attitudes, practice behaviors, and self‐confidence levels of caring for LGBT+ patients in Turkey. METHODS: This descriptive‐cross sectional study included 166 Gynecology and Obstetrics residents and experts in Istanbul, Turkey. The data were collected by self‐produced questionnaires in a face‐to‐face interview. Results: The mean age of the participants was 37.64 years, ranging from 25 to 64 years. We found that 84% of the participants had no prior training on caring for LGBT+ patients, and 79% believed that providing care to LBT+ patients was inappropriate. Moreover, 89% reported feeling uncomfortable caring for this population, and only 5% had ever had a patient openly identify as LGBT+. The mean score of the attitude subscale was 71.57%, which was lower than that of the knowledge, practice behavior, and self‐confidence subscales. CONCLUSION: There is a considerable gap between residents and experts' knowledge of care for LBT+ patients in Turkey, as they are unaware of their rights and needs. There is also a need to improve training content and increase the frequency of such trainings for residents and experts.

1. Introduction
Acupuncture has been increasingly used in the United States for pain reduction in the perioperative setting, including pediatric care settings. However, the number of studies evaluating this intervention in pediatric populations is limited and the literature regarding outcomes in pediatric patients is small. Acupuncture is considered one of the most popular complementary and alternative medicine therapies (CAM), although more high-quality studies are needed to establish efficacy and safety. Acupuncture has been used for the prevention and treatment of pain and symptoms associated with certain diseases, especially pain and analgesia after operations . In this context, a study with the purpose of exploring the effects of acupuncture on the pain scores of children and adolescents undergoing ear-nose-throat surgery was recently conducted. The results indicate that acupuncture reduces pain and increases patient discharge satisfaction. 
It has been suggested that acupuncture has a positive effect on the management of postoperative pain in pediatric patients through the stimulation of several physiological mechanisms , such as increasing endorphin-mediated pain inhibition through the opioid system  and triggering an anti-inflammatory response, altering the perception of pain .
Regarding pain assessment, pain is a subjective feeling and is best evaluated by the patient themselves . For this reason, using validated instrument to assess the pain of pediatric patients is fundamental, since it is capable of understanding the experience of pain, as well as the level of pain perception expressed by the child and the degree of anxiety about it . 
It is believed that the use of complementary therapies such as acupuncture for the treatment of acute pain improves the quality of life of patients . The World Health Organization's model of pain and suffering is one of the most important tools used in the clinical management and research management of acute and chronic pain . This model identifies factors associated with pain that can influence the pain experience of patients, such as age, cognitive status, expectations, social context, and cultural influences . According to this model, health professionals should consider the factors that influence the perception of pain, and not just the level of pain and its intensity. For this reason, studies have been conducted to evaluate how pain interacts with the factors previously mentioned .

Abstract:
Background: Epidemiologic evidence indicates that smoking cessation can reduce inflammatory activity, improve immune responsiveness and decrease COVID‐related complications. However, only one study has measured the impact of quitting tobacco on immune response in a clinical trial. Here, we present the results of the PURE study, a randomised controlled trial designed to assess the immunological response to smoking cessation. Methods: A total of 120 healthy (non‐smoking) volunteers were randomised to either a smoking cessation intervention group (SCIG) or a no‐intervention control group (CG). At baseline, 1‐month and 12‐month follow‐ups, a series of immunological tests were performed. Data were analysed using regression analysis. Results: Fifty‐two participants in the SCIG and 44 participants in the CG were included in the final analysis, with similar baseline characteristics between the two groups. At baseline, participants were divided according to smoking status, with 54 never smokers and 66 ever smokers. There was no significant difference in immunological indicators between never smokers and ever smokers, except for C4 and C3 which showed significant differences. A comparison of the SCIG versus the CG showed 41 participants (93.7%) in the former group and 44 participants (97.7%) in the latter group did not start smoking within 1 year. No significant difference was found in the immune test parameters between the two groups over time. Conclusions: Smoking cessation did not alter the immune response in participants of our study. Our preliminary results suggest that tobacco cessation is not ineffective in boosting the immunological response in these participants.
