Description:: The study consists of a screening period, a treatment period, a treatment-free period, a second treatment period, and a follow-up period. The screening period includes a run-in period and a treatment-free period.
During the run-in period (Day -3 until Day 0), eligible patients who are assigned to Arm A will be treated with pembrolizumab 240 mg as a single agent every 3 weeks for 30 to 84 days or until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. After completing the run-in period, eligible patients will undergo screening procedures to determine their VEGFR2 and PD-L1 mutation status and select patients will undergo tumor tissue biopsy.
In the second treatment period, eligible patients will be treated with the combination of VVD-130850 and pembrolizumab based on the results of tumor tissue biopsy. Patients who are assigned to Arm A will receive VVD-130850 45 mg intravenously over 1 hour on Day 1 and pembrolizumab 240 mg as a single agent every 3 weeks from Day 1 until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity, or for up to 84 weeks. Patients who are assigned to Arm B will receive VVD-130850 35 mg intravenously over 1 hour on Day 16 and pembrolizumab 240 mg as a single agent every 3 weeks from Day 16 until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity, or for up to 84 weeks.

Abstract:
Objectives: This study is a phase 1/2, open‐label, multicenter study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and clinical activity of VVD‐130850, an oral triple kinase inhibitor (TKI). Eligibility Criteria: Patients with advanced solid tumors and advanced hematologic tumors who progressed or discontinued previous treatments or are intolerant to them, without curative treatment options. Maintenance/Extension (M/E) Period: After the primary study period, patients who respond or have stable disease (SD) can enter the optional M/E period and receive VVD‐130850 until disease progression. Interim results from the primary study period are also summarized. Results: 41 patients were recruited from 4 centers in Korea. 20 patients were enrolled to the M/E period within the primary study period. The major demographic characteristics of enrolled patients did not show significant differences. 3 patients who did not receive the planned dose because of disease progression or discontinuation of treatment (due to AEs). Disease control rate (DCR) was 63.4%. The median duration of response (DOR) was 10.6 months. After the primary study period end, 2 patients responded and 1 patient had stable disease, and 1 patient had progressive disease (PD) in the M/E period (a responder did not respond from disease progression). DCR was 100.0% in the M/E period. No unexpected severe AEs were observed except for grade 4 hematological toxicity [neutropenia (n = 1), neutropenia/sepsis (n = 1) and thrombopenia (n = 2)]. Conclusions: The response rate and DOR of VVD‐130850 were not significant compared to other TKIs in patients with advanced solid and hematologic tumors. The most common grade ≥3 AE was thrombocytopenia

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Clonidine is a drug that has been used for many years to control high blood pressure. It has also been used to treat opioid withdrawal symptoms and symptoms of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, as well as to relieve pain in patients with chronic non-cancer pain and cancer-related pain. In some cases, clonidine has been used to treat patients with attention-deficity or ADHD who do not respond to methylphenidate. In this study, the investigators are evaluating the safety and effectiveness of clonidine in treating children and adolescents with ADHD and chronic pain; all of the subjects in the study are diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) as well. Some previous studies have suggested that ADHD co-exists frequently with chronic pain in ASD, and there could be biological mechanisms that contribute to this association. The investigators are hoping to learn more about how well clonidine works in treating ADHD with chronic pain in children and adolescents who meet the DSM-5 criteria for ASD.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Ages 5-21 Clinically diagnosed ADHD Co-existing with Chronic Pain and ASD. Children with significant behavioral problems/aggression that cannot be managed on the current medication regimen. Patients with uncontrolled chronic pain (e.g., chronic back pain) Patients with inadequate pain management despite adequate physical exam/imaging/treatment. Children already failing on currently prescribed stimulant medication or failed 2nd-line AMPH in the past Clinical and radiological findings consistent with DSM-5 criteria for ASD. Medication washout period of at least 9 days before starting study medication: 1 week without atomoxetine 1 week without stimulant medication 1 week without Clonidine Informed consent from parents or guardians. Informed assent from subject Children who have taken clonidine in the past for medical and/or behavioral reasons are eligible for inclusion in the trial. Exclusion Criteria: History of significant head injury or seizures Inadequate pain management despite adequate physical exam/imaging/treatment. Children already failing on currently prescribed stimulant

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Pancreatic ductal cell carcinoma (PDCC) is one of the deadliest cancers, with a 5‐year survival rate of 3 percent. Its progression is slow, which means long‐term and close monitoring is essential. However, current standard imaging modalities, including CT, are known for their high radiation dose, limited timeframe, and low specificity for early detection. The latest generation of near‐infrared optical tomography (NIROT) has recently demonstrated its potential in detecting PDCC, providing a new and promising approach to early diagnosis that can be used as a complement to existing modalities. However, further advancement is still needed to improve its sensitivity and specificity.METHODS: To address this limitation, we propose a multi‐component approach (multi‐MCA) and a multi‐omics method to optimize the detection of PDCC in human exponential tissue. Our methodology includes two steps. In the first step, we compare the performance of a single classifier (SAC) with our multi‐MCA. In the second step, we compare the results with our proposed multi‐class multi‐omics method (MC‐MCA). The first part of the project involves a preliminary comparison using SAC and MC‐MCA, while the second part will involve a comparison using a combination of these two methods. Our multi‐MCA approach combines five complementary channels (tissue, hemoglobin oxygen saturation, pH, redox, and tissue perfusion) to construct six supervised classifiers (tissue, HbO2, ph, Redox, TP). In the next step, we will compare these six classifiers with the SAC (SAC‐SVM) and our proposed multi‐omics method (MC‐MCA with multi‐classifiers). Finally, we will analyze the correlation between image channels and molecular channels.

Abstract: PURPOSE: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of intra‐articular (IA) injection of MSC‐Exosomes (MSCEs) in patients with knee osteoarthritis (KOA) in comparison with hyaluronic acid (HA), both associated with viscosupplementation (VS). METHODS: This study consists of a safety population, efficacy population (EPop) and secondary efficacy population (SEPop). Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The current case study presents an example of how to incorporate the principles of outcome assessment into a clinical trial. We report on the development, feasibility, and implementation of a study outcome measure during a trial for tuberculosis (TB) drug susceptibility test (DST) optimization in combination with the design of a randomized clinical trial. The study outcome measure describes the success rate of combined human and whole genome sequencing and metabolomic profiling as an improved method to obtain resistance markers and as a personalized test for TB drug susceptibility. The study outcome measure was adapted from earlier work performed in the development of the individual study. The process and results were then presented in a joint meeting with the investigators, the ethics committee, and the data monitoring committee which was held together with the design of a prospective randomized clinical trial.METHODS: The main study is an open‐label, randomized, multi‐center clinical trial. The trial is conducted in HIV‐infected or uninfected patients with extrapulmonary and/or drug resistant TB. The study outcomes are the number and rate of patients with a full combined profile, the time to a full profile, the time to a complete TB DST report, the rate of bacterial growth, the occurrence of false susceptible results, the rate of false resistance results, and the time to treatment change. The study outcomes for the randomized trial were presented together with the design and powering of the trial. Ethical board approval and funding of the study have been obtained.DISCUSSION: We present the process of adaptation and implementation of a study outcome measure during a trial for tuberculosis drug susceptibility test (DST) optimization in combination with the design of a randomized clinical trial. Our case study demonstrates that an evidence‐based study outcome measure may be successfully adapted and implemented for use in a clinical trial.

Abstract:
Aim : To describe and analyze molecular profiles of metastatic breast cancer (MBC) with endocrine resistance. Method : Metastatic breast cancer with endocrine resistance (MBC‐E) was defined as patients with MBC that had been previously treated with an aromatase inhibitor (AI). This study describes the clinical outcomes of 40 female patients with MBC‐E who were treated with a molecular targeted therapy (MTT), in accordance with clinical response. Results : Twenty‐seven (67.5%) patients had high grade MBC, and 31 (77.5%) patients were hormone receptor (HR)‐positive. Patients with estrogen‐receptor (ER)‐positive, progesterone (PR)‐negative tumors showed the worst overall survival (OS), progression free survival (PFS) and clinical response rate (ORR). An ER overexpression in the MBC cell‐line derived xenografts (CDX) was associated with shorter OS, PFS and decreased ORR, and hormone receptor (HR)‐positive and epidermal growth factor receptor‐positive (EGFR+) T‐cell infiltration was associated with a lower OS, PFS and ORR, and high Ki67 and p‐Akt37/38 expression was related to higher OS, PFS, and a higher ORR. Conclusions : Understanding the molecular profiles of a patient with MBC‐E could predict the survival and response to therapy.

Metastatic breast cancer (MBC) is considered incurable even with modern systemic therapy, and median survival without treatment is approximately 6–9 months . Endocrine therapy is one of the most important treatments for women with MBC or the presence of hormone receptors (HRs). However, 20–30% of patients with estrogen receptor-positive MBC relapse after progression from previous endocrine therapy .
The presence of endocrine resistance is often suspected when a patient with endocrine treatment has progression of disease (PD) or refractory disease

Abstract:
Background: Personalized treatment in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) based on genetic profiling and ex vivo drug sensitivity testing of patient‐derived organoids could improve outcome of treatment for mCRC patients. Methods: A prospective, open‐label, single‐arm phase II study evaluating MTB‐nominated treatment in mCRC patients. Tumor tissue samples will be collected for molecular analysis, including MET copy number status by FISH and BRAF, KRAS, and NRAS mutation status by pyrosequencing. Plasma samples will be collected and tested for KRAS mutation status by pyrosequencing. Safety assessments include common adverse events (AEs) and laboratory tests for hematological and biochemical parameters. Endpoints are: objective response rate (ORR), time to progression (TTP), disease control rate (DCR), and overall survival (OS). Results: Of the 48 enrolled patients, 26 (54.2%) were treated with capecitabine and oxaliplatin (CAP) plus weekly rilotumumab (group A) and 22 (45.8%) were treated with single‐agent CAPOX (group B). In total, 23 (47.9%) of the 48 subjects had received a prior line of treatment and 46.7% had RAS mutations. In the 15 subjects with tumor tissue sequencing, 33.3%, 53.3%, 73.3%, 62.5%, and 46.7% had BRAF wild‐type, mutated BRAF, wild‐type KRAS, mutant KRAS, and wild‐type NRAS, respectively. In the 39 subjects with plasma testing, only 5.1% of the patients had KRAS G12V mutation. The mean age of the patients was 59 years (range, 23 to 89 years), and the mean number of lines of previous treatment was 2.9. Most patients were Caucasian (56.3%) and had an ECOG PS

Perfect! We now have a comprehensive set of primary and secondary outcome measures for your clinical trial on the inactivated rotavirus vaccine. Here they are:

Primary Outcome Measures:
1. Immunogenicity index-geometric mean titer (GMT) of neutralizing antibody: Measure the GMT of neutralizing antibodies 28 days after the final dose.
2. Immunogenicity index-geometric mean increase (GMI) of neutralizing antibody: Assess the increase in neutralizing antibodies from baseline to 28 days after the final dose.
3. Immunogenicity index-seroconversion rates of neutralizing antibody: Determine the proportion of participants who develop a seropositive response between baseline and 28 days after the final dose.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Safety index-incidence of adverse reactions/events: Monitor the incidence of adverse reactions/events within 30 minutes after each dose.
2. Safety index-incidence of solicited adverse reactions/events: Assess the incidence of solicited adverse reactions/events within 7 days after each dose.
3. Safety index-incidence of unsolicited adverse reactions/events: Evaluate the incidence of unsolicited adverse reactions/events within 28/30 days after each dose.
4. Safety index-incidence of serious adverse events: Track the occurrence of serious adverse reactions/events from the beginning of vaccination up to 6 months after the final dose.

The minimum serum drug concentration, also known as Ctrough, is a pharmacokinetic parameter that assesses the concentration of a drug in the blood at the end of its administration. In our study, we aim to measure the Ctrough after a single administration of QL1706H. By monitoring this value, we can ensure that the drug is appropriately absorbed, distributed, metabolized, and eliminated in patients with advanced solid tumors.

Adverse events, physical examinations, routine hematology and clinical chemistry assessments, vital signs, and routine clinical evaluations will be collected throughout the study to monitor participant safety and tolerability.

Usually, the Ctrough is measured after the last dose of the study drug before the start of the next dosing interval. For QL1706H, the dosing schedule would be once daily (QD), so the Ctrough would be measured approximately 24 hours after the last dose. However, the Ctrough can also be assessed at other time points, depending on the study protocol design. Generally, a Ctrough sample is conveniently collected close to the time of administration of the subsequent dose, which could be at the following dose day. 

* Please note that the QD dosing refers to 48-hour dosing cycles rather than 24-hour dosing. Dosing in 24-hour cycles will result in the administration of two doses per day, whereas dosing in 48-hour cycles allows for the administration of a single dose.

Another important pharmacokinetic parameter to evaluate is the area under the serum drug concentration-time curve (AUC). This measure assesses the drug's total exposure in a patient's body over time after a single administration. AUC provides valuable information on the drug's effectiveness and duration of action.

Primary Outcome(s)
=================
1. Outcome:: Determination
groundtruth: The time frame for measuring the severe neutropenia incidence can be "through study completion, an average of 1 year". This duration allows for a comprehensive evaluation of the impact of Tripegfilgrastim on severe neutropenia over an extended period. It also gives us enough data to analyze the effectiveness of the drug.

Considering the nature of the trial and the potential side effects, I suggest including the following secondary outcome measures: neutropenia incidence (all grades), febrile neutropenia incidence, frequency of unexpected emergency department visits and length of stay, overall survival, progression-free survival, and predictive biomarkers for treatment response analysis. These measures will provide a comprehensive understanding of the impact of Tripegfilgrastim on neutropenia, patient outcomes, and treatment response.

Certainly! Here are the descriptions and time frames for each secondary outcome measure:

1. Neutropenia incidence (all grades): This measure captures the occurrence of all grades of neutropenia, not just severe cases. It helps us understand the overall impact of Tripegfilgrastim on neutropenia. The time frame for this measure is "through study completion, an average of 1 year".

2. Febrile neutropenia incidence: This measure focuses specifically on the occurrence of febrile neutropenia, which is a serious complication. It helps assess the efficacy of Tripegfilgrastim in preventing this severe complication. The time frame for this measure is also "through study completion, an average of 1 year".

3. Frequency of unexpected emergency department visits and length of stay: This measure evaluates the impact of Tripegfilgrastim on healthcare utilization and patient outcomes. It assesses the frequency of emergency department visits and the length of stay for patients. The time frame for this measure is "through study completion, an average of 1 year".

4. Overall survival: This measure reflects the ultimate goal of prolonging patient survival. It helps determine the impact of Tripegfilgrastim on overall patient outcomes and prognosis. The time frame for this measure is "through study completion, an average of 1 year".

5. Progression-free survival: This measure assesses the effectiveness of Tripegfilgrastim in delaying disease progression. It provides insights into tumor control and disease stability. The time frame for this measure is "through study completion, an average of 1 year".

6. Predictive biomarkers for treatment response analysis: This measure focuses on analyzing biomarkers to identify patients who are likely to benefit from Tripegfilgrastim. It helps personalize therapy and optimize patient care. The time frame for this measure is also "through study completion, an average of 1 year".
